alphabetical letter x x
The seventh letter of the alphabet: called xaA='N [and xaA (respecting which latter see the letter b)]. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice]; and of those termed Haloqiy~ap [i. e. faucial, or guttural]: its place of utterance is the same as that of g [which differs from it in being vocal]. (L.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Six hundred.]

xaA xA
and xaA='N: see the letter x, and arts. xwA^ and xY.

xaAtuwnN xAtwn
: see art. xtn.

xaAnaqaAhN xAnq xAnqAh xAnqAp
and xaAnaqaAhiY~N: see art. xnq.

1 xab~a xb
, (A, L, K,) sec. pers. xabibota, like Ealimota, aor. yaxab~u, inf. n. xib~N; (S, L, K; *) or xab~a, [sec. pers. xababota,] aor. yaxub~u, like yaqotulu, inf. n. xab~N; (Msb; [in which xib~N is regarded as a simple subst.; but I doubt the correctness of this, and of the verb's being like qatala;]) He (a man) was, or became, deceitful, (Msb, K, TA,) wicked, dishonest, or dissimulating, (K, TA,) and a mischief-maker: (TA:) [or] he was, or became, a great deceiver, or very deceitful, (S, A, L, K, TA,) wicked and deceitful, and a mischief-maker. (S, * A, * L, TA.) [In the K and TA, neither the aor. nor the inf. n. of xab~a as signifying “ he was, or became, a great deceiver, or very deceitful, ” is specified; nor the sec. pers. of the pret., which indicates the form of the aor.] ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] xab~a signifies also He alighted and abode in a depressed tract of ground, in order that his place might be unknown, from a motive of niggardliness [to avoid claims upon his hospitality, thus deceiving passers by]. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And He denied, or refused, what he possessed. (K.) ＝ -A2- xab~a, (S, A, K,) aor. yuxub~u, with damm, (S, A,) deviating from a general rule, accord. to which an intrans. v. of this class [of the measure faEala] should be with kesr, (MF,) inf. n. xab~N (S, K) and xababN and xabiybN, (S, A, K,) He went the pace, or in the manner, denoted by xababN as explained below; said of a horse; (S, A, K;) as also ↓Axtb~: (Th, K:) and in like manner said of a man. (TA.) You say, jaAw^uwA taxub~u bihimu Ald~awaAb~u [They came, the beasts going with them the pace, or in the manner, termed xababN]. (A.) And xab~a fiY AlA^amori, aor.
xabu3a
, inf. n. xababN, He hastened to begin the affair. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xab~a, (aor. yaxub~u, TA, [inf. n. xab~N,]) said of the sea, (tropical:) It was, or became, agitated, or in a state of commotion; (T, S, A, K, TA;) the waves dashing together, and the winds whirling; (T, A, TA;) such being the case at a certain period, when the ships make for the shore, for safety, or cast anchor. (T, TA.) You say, A^aSaAbahumu Alxab~u (tropical:) Agitation, or commotion, of the sea, with a whirling of the winds, befell them: (T, A, TA:) or ASAbhm xab~N, i. e. xab~a bihimu AlbaHoru (tropical:) The sea became agitated, or in a state of commotion, with them. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Also, said of the dust, (tropical:) It rose high: (JK, TA:) and (tropical:) it ran along. (TA.) ― -b4- And said of a plant, or of herbage, (tropical:) It became tall. (JK, S, A, K.)

2 xb~b xbb
, (JK, S, A, K,) inf. n. taxobiybN, (JK, TA,) He deceived another; (S, K;) namely, another's young man, or slave: (S:) or deceived much or greatly: (Har p. 591:) and he corrupted another; (JK, A, TA;) namely, another's male or female slave. (TA.) You say, xb~b Ealayohi Sadiyqahu, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) and Eabodahu, and Haliylatahu, (A,) He corrupted, and rendered disaffected to him, (Aboo-Bekr, A,) his friend, (Aboo-Bekr,) and his male slave, and his wife. (A.) ＝ -A2- He bound his arm, or hand, with a xib~ap, i. e. a piece of rag like a fillet. (A, TA.) ＝ -A3- It (one's flesh) wasted so that there appeared streaks upon the skin. (TA.) ＝ -A4- See also R. Q. 1.

3 xAb~ xAb
: see muxaAb~N. [It seems that xAb~hu, if used, signifies He acted treacherously towards him, and took him unawares.] ― -b2- And [the inf. n.] muxaAb~apN signifies The being heavy, or sluggish, and holding back from a thing. (JK.)

4 Axb~ A^xAb A^xb Axb xAb xb xbA
He made a horse to go the pace, or in the manner, denoted by xababN as explained below. (S, A, K.)

8 Axtb~ A^xtb Axtb {xtb
: see 1. ＝ -A2- Axtb~ mino vawobih xub~apF, (S,) or, xib~apF, and Axtb~ vawobahu, (JK,) He took forth [or, app., tore] from his garment a piece of ray like a fillet. (S.)

R. Q. 1 xaboxaba xbxb
He (a man, TA) acted perfidiously, unfaithfully, faithlessly, or treacherously. (K.) ＝ -A2- He was, or became, lax, flaccid, or flabby, in the belly. (K.) [See also xaboxabapF, below; and see R. Q. 2.] ＝ -A3- xaboxaba Eani AlZ~ahiyrapi He stayed until the mid-day heat had become assuaged, and the air was cool: (K:) or the phrase is xaboxaba Eanohu mina AlZ~ahiyrapi. (TA.) [Hence, in a trad. relating to the postponement of the noon prayers,] xaboxibuwA Eanokumo mina AlZ~ahiyrapi, (S,) or fiY AlZ~ahiyrapi, (JK, [but the former is more probably the correct phrase,]) Stay ye until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool: (JK, S:) it is originally ↓xab~abuwA, and is altered therefrom for the purpose of distinction: (S in the present art.:) or originally baxobixuwA. (S in art. bx.)

R. Q. 2 taxaboxaba txbxb
It was, or became, lax, flaccid, or flabby: said of a thing in a state of commotion, moving to and fro, quivering, or the like. (K.) [See also xaboxabapN, below; and see R. Q. 1.] ― -b2- He was, or became, empty [in the belly], after repletion. (JK.) And jaA='a yataxaboxabu He came hungry. (JK.) ― -b3- taxaboxaba laHomuhu, (JK,) or badanuhu, (K,) He became lean after having been fat, (JK, K, TA,) so that his shin became lax, flaccid, or flabby, (TA,) and a sound was heard to proceed from him [when he moved], (JK, TA,) by reason of his leanness. (TA.) ― -b4- taxaboxaba AlHar~u The heat became allayed, or assuaged, (K, TA,) somewhat, (TA,) in its vehemence. (K, TA.)

xab~N xb
(JK, S, A, L, Msb, K) [said in the Msb to be originally an inf. n.] and ↓xib~N (S, L, K) [originally an inf. n. accord. to most authorities] and ↓xub~N, (MF,) applied to a man, (S, A, L, Msb,) fem. xab~apN, [which casts doubt upon the assertion that xab~N is originally an inf. n., for were it so the masc. and fem. accord. to a general rule would be the same, as well as the sing. and pl.,] applied to a woman, (JK, A,) A great deceiver, or very deceitful; (JK, * S, A, L, Msb, * K;) wicked and deceitful; a mischief-maker; (S, * A, * L, K, * TA;) deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning; syn. mak~aArN. (Ham p. 537, in explanation of the first and second.) ＝ -A2- Also the first of these words, A long, elevated tract (Habol, in some copies of the K erroneously written jbl, TA) of sand, cleaving to the ground. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A plain, or soft,
tract, between two rugged tracts, in which (i. e. in the former of which) are truffles. (AA, K.)

xub~N xb
: see xab~N. ＝ -A2- See also xib~apN. Hence vawobN A^axobaAbN: see, again, xib~apN. ― -b2- A^axobaAbu AlfaHivi The HawaAyaA [or winding guts, or intestines into which the food passes from the stomach]: (K:) thus used in the pl. form, as though pl. of xub~N. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also The bark (liHaA=') of a tree. (JK, K.) ＝ -A4- And Low, or depressed, land: (JK, K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^axobaAbN and [of mult.] xubuwbN. (TA.)

xib~N xb
Deceit; (JK, Msb, K;) wickedness; dishonesty, or dissimulation; (K, TA;) mischiefmaking; as also ↓xababN: (TA:) guile, art, craft, or cunning. (Ham p. 537.) ＝ -A2- See also xab~N. ＝ -A3- (tropical:) A rising, or state of agitation and commotion, of the sea; (JK, K, TA;) as also ↓xibaAbN. (IAar, K.)

xab~apN xb xbh xbp
: see xib~apN.

xub~apN xb xbh xbp
: see xib~apN and xabiybapN. ― -b2- Also A place where water collects and remains or stagnates, (AA, K, TA,) and around which grow herbs, or leguminous plants: (TA:) a tract of land neither fruitful nor unfruitful, between two other tracts of land; pl. xubabN: (AHn:) a tract of land between that which abounds with herbage and that which is unproductive: (Ru-beh:) a narrow tract of soft land abounding with herbage, not rugged nor plain, but inclining to be plain; (ISh;) but ADk disapproves of this explanation: (TA:) or a tract producing herbage between two long and elevated tracts of sand; as also ↓xabiybapN: (Ibn-Nujeym:) and, accord. to AA, also pasture, or herbage. (TA.) Also, or ↓maxab~apN, (accord. to different copies of the K, or both, TA,) and ↓xabiybapN, The bottom (baTon) of a valley. (K.)

xib~apN xb xbh xbp
and ↓xub~apN and ↓xab~apN A narrow tract, or streak, of sand; [in one copy of the A, I find xib~apN and xabiybapN thus explained; but in another, ↓maxab~apN is written in the place of the former of these two words;] or of clouds; (S, K;) as also ↓xabiybapN: (As:) or, of sand, what resembles a faAliq [or depressed tract between two hills], except in its being wider and more spreading, and not having abrupt sides; so says AHn in explaining xb~p [thus in the TA] and ↓xabiybapN: (TA:) or all three signify a piece of rag like a fillet; as also ↓xabiybapN (S, K) and ↓xub~N: (Lh:) or the last two (xbybp and xb~) signify a piece of rag from a garment, with which one binds his arm or hand. (JK, TA.) [Hence,) ↓vawobN A^axobaAbN, (Lh, K,) [like A^ahobaAbN,] and vwb xibabN, (Lh, JK, K,) like hibabN, (JK,) and ↓vwb xabaAy^ibu, like habaAy^ibu; (S;) [the latter word in the first of these phrases being pl. of xub~N; that in the second, pl. of xib~pN; and that in the third, pl. of xabiybapN;] A garment, or piece of cloth, rent in pieces, ragged, or tattered. (Lh, JK, S, K.) [See also xabiybapN, below.] It is also said that the xib~ap of a garment, or piece of cloth, is [A portion thereof] like the Tur~ap [q. v.]: and accord. to Sh, the xub~ap thereof is its Tur~ap. (TA.) And xb~p [so in the TA] signifies A piece of rag which a woman wears, covering her head with it: erroneously written by Lth Hn~p. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- Also, i. e. xib~apN and its two vars., and ↓xabiybapN, of which the pl. is xabaAy^ibu, A streak of the flesh appearing in the skin, occasioned by the loss of flesh. (TA.)

xababN xbb
: see xib~N. ＝ -A2- Also A kind of run, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) with wide steps, but falling short of that termed EanaqN; (Mgh, Msb;) i. e. a quick pace: (TA:) or a certain pace which is not quick: (Har p. 157:) or i. q. ramalN [q. v.]: or a pace of a horse, (K,) and of a camel, (TA,) in which he remores both his right legs together and both his left legs together; i. e. an amble: (K, TA:) or in which a horse rests on his right and left fore legs alternately, (yuraAwiHu bayona yadayohi, S, K, TA,) and in like manner on his kind legs: (S, TA: [app., as thus explained in the S and TA, meaning the same as the explanation next before it:] and (accord. to some, TA) quickness. (K.)

xibaAbN xbAb
: see xib~N.

xabiybN xbyb
A trench, or furrow, (xad~N,) in the ground. (K.)

xabiybapN xbyb xbybh xbybp
, and its pl. xabaAy^ibu: see xib~apN, in five places. It is also said to signify A fillet, or bandage. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A long strip, or slice, of flesh, or flesh-meat; (JK, S, K;) and so ↓xub~apN; (A, TA;) pl. of the former as above: (JK:) or any compact and long portion of flesh: any such portion is also termed xaSiylapN: either in the arm or elsewhere: (AO, TA:) or a [portion such as is termed] xSylp thereof, intermixed with [sinews, or tendons, such as are termed] Eaqab. (TA.) And xabaAy^ibu Almatonayoni The flesh of the two corresponding portions extending along the two sides of the backbone. (TA.) [Hence,] laHomuhu xabaAy^ibu His flesh is dissundered, or cut in pieces. (TA.) ― -b3- See also xub~apN, in two places. ― -b4- Also The wool of a vaniY~ [or sheep in its third year]; (S, L;) which is better than that termed Eaqiyqap, i. e. the wool of a ja*aE [or sheep in or before its second year], and cleaner, and more abundant: (ISk, S:) so accord. to most of the leading lexicologists; though said in the K to be a mistake of J, for janiybapN. (TA.)

xaboxabapN xbxbh xbxbp
[by rule an inf. n. of R. Q. 1:] Laxness, flaccidity, or flabbiness; and a state of commotion, moving to and fro, quivering, or the like: (S:) or laxness, flaccidity, or flabbiness, of a thing in a state of commotion, moving to and fro, quivering, or the like; (TA;) as also ↓xaboxaAbN. (JK, K, TA.) [See also R. Q. 2.]

xaboxaAbN xbxAb
: see what next precedes.

xaAb~N xAb
, (S, K, TA,) in one copy of the K xaAb~apN, [as in the CK,] but the former is the more correct, (TA,) Relationship; (S, K;) and affinity, syn. SihorN: (S:) pl. xawaAb~u. (S, K.) You say, liY mino fulaAnK xawaAb~u [I have ties of relationship, or affinity, to such a one]. (S.)

maxab~apN mxbh mxbp
: see xub~apN: ＝ -A2- and see also xib~apN.

muxaAb~N mxAb
, as though from ↓xaAb~a, One who acts treacherously towards another, and takes him unawares. (TA.)

1 xabaA^ahu *
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
xabaAa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. xabo'N, (S, Msb,) He hid, or concealed, it; (Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓xb~A^hu, [but app. in an intensive sense, or applying to a number of things,] (K,) inf. n. taxobiy^apN; (TA;) and ↓AxtbA^hu. (K.) ― -b2- He kept it, preserved it, guarded it, or took care of it. and ↓xb~A^hu he did so much; and well, or carefully. (Msb.) [He laid it up; stored it, or reposited it, in a place of safety.]

2 xab~aAa
see 1, in two places. [Hence, xb~A^ jaAriyapF He kept a girl carefully concealed from view: see the pass. part. n., below.]

3 xaAbaA^otuhu maA ka*aA *
, (K,) inf. n. muxaAbaA^apN, (TK,) I proposed to him as an enigma, What is such a thing? syn. HaAjayotuhu. (K. [See also 8.])

8 AxtbA^ *
It was, or became, hidden, or concealed: (Mgh:) he hid, or concealed, himself. (S.) ＝ -A2- It is also trans.: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] ↓AxtbA^ lahu xabiyoy^FA He expressed a thing enigmatically to him, and then asked him respecting it. (IDrd, K. [See also 3.])

xabo'N xb'
(S, Msb, K) and ↓xibo'N (TA) and ↓xuboA^apN, of the measure fuEolapN from AlxbA^ [or rather Alxabo'u], like gurofapN and quboDapN from Algarofu and AlqaboDu, (Har p. 426,) and ↓xabiYo'N (S, K) and ↓xabiyoy^apN, (K,) of which last the pl. is xabaAyaA, (TA,) A thing that is hidden, or concealed, (S, * Msb, K,) and absent, or unseen. (K.) [Hence,] xabo'u Als~amaA='i The rain. (Th, S, K.) And xabo'u AlA^aroDi The plants, or herbage. (S, K.) And AlA^aroDi ↓xabaAyaA The seed which the sower has hidden in the earth: or what God has hidden in the mines of the earth. (TA, from a trad.) Al~a*iY yuxoriju Alxabo'a fiY Als~am`waAti waAlA^aroDi, in the Kur [xxvii. 25], is held by Az to mean Who knoweth what is unseen in the heavens and the earth; agreeably with an explanation of Alxabo'u by Fr. (TA.)

xibo'N xb'
: see the next preceding paragraph.

xaboA^apN *
A daughter; syn. binotN. (K, TA. [In the CK, Aln~abotu is put for Albinotu.]) Hence the prov., xaboA^apN xayorN mino yafaEapi sawo'K [A daughter is better than a grown-up boy of evil deeds]. (TA.) [In Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 438, the first word in this prov. is written xubaA^ap, and followed by SidoqK.] Aboo-Zeyd Sa'eed Ibn-Ows El-Ansáree entitled one of his books ktAb xbA^p because he commenced it by mentioning xbA^p in the sense of bnt, quoting the foregoing prov. in confirmation thereof. (TA.)

xuboA^apN *
: see xabo'N.

AimoraA^apN xubaA^apN *
A woman who shows herself and then hides herself: (S, O, TA:) [like qubaEapN:] or a woman who keeps to her house, or tent. (K.)

xibaA='N xbA='
A well-known kind of structure; (K;) [i. e.] a kind of tent, (Mgh, TA,) made of wool, (Mgh, Msb,) or of camels' fur, or sometimes of [goats'] hair, sometimes upon two poles, or three; what is above this kind being termed bayotN: (Msb:) or a tent having one pole; that which has more than one pole being termed byt: (AZ, TA in art. rbE:) [or] also applied to a byt [or tent] of any kind: (Towsheeh, TA voce bayotN, q. v.:) pl. A^axobiy^apN, (TA,) or A^axobiyapN: (Msb:) it is from xabaA^ahu “ he hid it, ” or “ concealed it: ” (Mgh:) or it belongs to art. xbY: (K:) most of the lexicologists hold that its radical letters are xbY: some, that they are xbw: IDrd asserts that they are xbA^. (TA:) [See also art. xbY.] ＝ -A2- A mark made with a hot iron upon some secret part of an excellent she-camel: pl. A^axobiy^apN. (Lth, K.)

xabiYo'N xbY' xby' xby^
: see xabo'N: and see also 8.

xabiyoy^apN *
, and its pl. xabaAyaA: see xabN'N, in two places.

kayodN xaAbiy^N *
An artifice, or a stratagem, resulting in disappointment; i. q. xaAy^ibN; (AHei, K;) formed [from the latter] by transposition. (AHei.)

xaAbiy^apN *
, as sometimes pronounced, (Msb,) or xaAbiyapN, with the ' suppressed, (S, Msb, K,) because of frequent usage, (Msb,) i. q. Hub~N [q. v.]; (S, K;) i. e. A large jar: pl. xwAbY [i. e. xawaAbiy^u, or xawaAbK]: (TA:) from xabaA^ahu “ he hid it, ” or “ concealed it. ” (S, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] binotu AlxaAbiyapi (assumed tropical:) Wine. (Har p. 365.)

maxobaA^N *
A place, or chamber, for hiding or concealing [anything]; a secret place or chamber: pl. maxaAbiy^u. (MA.)

jaAriyapN muxab~aA^apN *
; so in the [S and] O, and in some of the correct copies of the K; in other copies of the K muxobaA^apN; (TA;) [and thus in the CK;] A girl that is [kept in the house, or tent,] concealed from view; or that conceals herself; (S;) that is kept behind, or within, the curtain; (K, TA;) not going forth: or (TA) that is not yet married. (Lth, K, TA.)

muxotabiy^N *
One who conceals himself in order that he may see without the knowledge of him who is seen. (Mgh.)

1 xabata *ikoruhu *
The mention of him, or it, was, or became, concealed: (L:) [app. meaning he, or it, was, or became, obscure; or of no reputation, or repute.] ＝ -A2- xabuva, accord. to Z, i. q. xabuva [q. v.]: occurring in a trad. (TA.) [See xabiytN.]

4 Axbt A^xAb A^xbt A^xbtt Axbt
He became in what is termed xabotN [q. v.]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And, (S, Msb, K, TA,) [hence, or] from xabotN, (Ksh and Bd in xi. 25, and TA,) or from xabata *ikoruhu, (L,) inf. n. A_ixobaAtN, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) He (a man, Msb, TA) was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, (S, Msb, K, TA,) in heart, (Msb,) and obedient, (TA,) lil~`hi to God. (S, TA.) And in like manner, in the Kur [xi. 25], (TA,) waA^axobatuwA A_ilaY rab~ihimo means (tropical:) And who have become lowly, humble, or submissive, [and obedient,] to their Lord; or have lowered, humbled, or abased, themselves to their Lord; or have trusted to their Lord: (A, * TA:) for the Arabs put A_ilaY in the place of li. (TA.)

xabotN xAb xb xbA xbt
A low, or depressed, tract of ground: (TA:) or a low, or depressed, (S,) or concealed and low, (TA,) tract of ground, in which is sand: (S, TA:) or a wide, or spacious, low tract of ground: (IAar, A, K:) or a plain, or soft, tract of ground in a [stony tract such as is termed] Har~ap: (TA:) and a wide bottom, or bed, or interior, of a valley: (A:) or a deep valley, easy to be walked or ridden through, extended [to a great length], and in which grow varieties of the EiDaAh: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^axobaAtN (K) and [of mult.] xubuwtN: (A, K:) it is a genuine Arabic word. (TA.)

fiyhi xabotapN fyh xbth fyh xbtp
(tropical:) In him is lowliness, humility, or submissiveness. (S, TA.)

xabiytN xbyt
A thing that is contemptible, or despicable; (K, TA;) bad, corrupt, abominable, vile, base, or disapproved; [&c.;] (TA;) and [thus] i. q. xabiyvN. (As, K.) The Jew of Kheyber says,
yanofaEu AlT~ay~ibu Alqaliylu mina Alr~izo
qi walaA yanofaEu Alkaviyru Alxabiytu
[The lawful, but small, supply of the means of subsistence is beneficial, but the large and unlawful is not beneficial]. (TA.) Kh asked As respecting Alxbyt in this verse; and the latter replied that the poet meant Alxabiyv; the former word being of the dial. of Kheyber: but Kh rejoined, “ If so, the poet would have said Alktyr: it behooves you only to say that the people of Kheyber change v into t in some words: ” AM thinks that Alxbyt in this verse is a mistranscription for Alxatiyt, which means the thing that is “ contemptible and bad, ” and is syn. with Alxasiys. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also applied to a man; meaning as above; or Bad, corrupt, vitious, or depraved. (TA.)

muxobitN mxbt
(assumed tropical:) Still; motionless: as also muxobiTN. (TA in art. xmd.)

1 xabuva xbv
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
xabuva
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. xabaAvapN, (S,) or xubovN, the former being a simple subst., (Msb,) or both, (Mgh, K, [the latter word erroneously written in the CK xabov,]) and xabaAviyapN, (K,) said of a thing, (S, Mgh, Msb,) It was, or became, xabiyv [q. v., meaning bad, &c.]; contr. of TaAba. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) [Hence,] xabuvato raAy^iHatuhu (tropical:) [Its, or his, odour was, or became, bad, foul, or abominable]. (A.) And xabuva TaEomuhu (tropical:) [Its taste was, or became, bad, foul, abominable, or nauseous]. (A.) (A.) ― -b2- See also xiborapN. ＝ -A2- And see xabiyrN: ＝ -A3- and xuborapN.

xabarN xbr
[originally] an inf. n. of xabirahu: see xuborN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Information; a piece of information; a notification; intelligence; an announcement; news; tidings; a piece of news; an account; a narration, or narrative; a story; syn. nabaA^N; (T, K;) that comes to one from a person of whom he asks it: (TA:) or xabarN and nabaA^N are not synonymous; for, accord. to Er-Rághib and others, the latter relates to a thing of great importance: and accord. to the leading authorities in lexicology and the science of conventional language, the former signifies properly, and in its common acceptation, what is related from another or others: to which authors on the Arabic language add, that it may be true or false: (MF:) or what is related from another or others, and talked of: (Msb:) pl. A^axobaArN, (S, Msb, K,) and pl. pl. A^axaAbiyru. (K.) ― -b3- By the relaters of traditions, it is used as syn. with HadiyvN [signifying A tradition; or narrative relating, or describing, a saying or an action &c. of Mohammad]: (TA:) or this latter term is applied to what comes from the Prophet; and xabarN, to what comes from another than the Prophet; or from him or another; and A^avarN, to what comes from a Companion of the Prophet; but it may also be applied to a saying of the Prophet. (Kull p. 152.) ― -b4- [In grammar, as correlative of mubotadaA^N, An enunciative: and as correlative of AisomN, the predicate of the non-attributive verb kaAna and the like, and of kaAda &c.] ― -b5- Also A man's state, or case; AlA^amoru Al~a*iY huwa Ealyohi. (Har p. 20.)

xubozN xbz
a word of well-known meaning; (K;) [Bread;] that which is eaten. (S.) It is said in a prov., kul~u A^adaApi Alxubozi EinodiY gayoruhu [All the apparatus of bread is in my possession except it, namely, the bread itself]: the origin of which was this: a company of men demanded hospitality of a certain man; and when they sat down, he threw down a [piece of leather such as is called] niToE, and put upon it a mill-stone, and adjusted its pivot, and covered it [with the upper stone]: and the presence of his apparatus made the company to wonder: then he took the handle of the mill, (haAdiY Alr~aHaY,) and began to turn it: whereupon they said to him, What dost thou? and he answered in the words of this proverb. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Alxul~apu xubozu AlA_ibili (tropical:) [Sweet herbage is the bread of camels: and AlHamoDu faAkihatuhaA, or AaHomuhaA, sour herbage is their fruit, or flesh-meat]. (A, TA.)

1 xabaTa xbT
, aor.
xabiTa
, (Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. xaboTN, (Msb, TA, &c.,) He struck, or beat, (Msb, TA,) anything: (TA:) or he struck, or beat, it, or him, vehemently: (M, K, TA:) or xaboTN signifies a camel's striking, or beating, a thing with his fore foot: (T, TA:) or in the cases of beasts, (dawaAb~, [generally meaning horses and mules and asses,]) the striking, or beating, with the fore feet; not with the hind feet: and in the case of the camel, with the fore foot and the hind foot: or vehement treading; or of the fore feet of beasts (dwAb~): (TA:) or, accord. to the Keshsháf, the act of striking, or beating, in a way
that is not right: or, as some say, the going, or journeying, upon what is not the middle, or main part, of the road, or what is not the main road, or upon a road not open to view: or continuous, or consecutive, striking, or beating, in different ways: and afterwards tropically applied to any (tropical:) beating, or striking, that is not approved: or originally, the striking, or beating, with the fore foot or the hind foot, and the like: (MF, TA:) with the fore feet or legs, it is like ramoHN with the hind feet or legs. (TA.) You say, of a camel, xabaTa AlA^aroDa, (Msb,) or xabaTa AlA^aroDa biyadihi, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He struck, or beat, the ground with his fore foot: (S, Msb:) or he struck, or beat, vehemently the ground with his fore foot; and ↓txb~T and ↓AxtbT signify the same: (K:) it is said in the O that xabaTahu signifies he struck him with his fore foot, or hand, and prostrated him, as also ↓txb~Thu: and ↓AxtbT, said of a camel, is syn. with xabaTa: and in the T, that birijolihi ↓taxab~aTaniY is syn, with xabaTaniY. (TA.) Hence the trad., laA taxobiTuwA xaboTa Aljamali [lit. Ye shall not beat the ground as the camel does with his fore foot in rising]; meant to forbid a man's putting forward his foot in rising from prostration [in prayer]. (TA.) And xabaTahu, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) signifies also He trod him, or it, vehemently, (K, TA,) as the camel does with his fore foot. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) fulaAnN yaxobiTu xaboTa Ea$owaA='a (S, * TA) (tropical:) [Such a one goes at random, in a headstrong and reckless manner,] like the weak-sighted she-camel that beats the ground with her fore feet (taxobiTu) as she goes along, not guarding herself from anything. (S, TA.) It is a prov., applied to him who turns away from a thing as though he were not cognizant of it: or to him who is continually falling into a thing. (Har p. 239.) Zuheyr says,
raA^ayotu AlmanaAyaA xaboTa Ea$owaA='a mano tuSibo
tumitohu wamano tuxoTiy^o yuEam~aro fayahorami
I saw the fates [treading mankind] like the treading of the weak-sighted she-camel; whom they smote, him they killed: and whom they missed, he was made to continue in life so that he lived to extreme old age. (TA, and EM p. 132.) In like manner you say, fulaAnN yaxobiTu fiY EamoyaA='a (tropical:) Such a one undertakes what he undertakes with ignorance. (TA.) And xabaTa A^amorahu EalaY gayori baSyrapK (assumed tropical:) [He prosecuted his affair without mental perception, or without certainty]. (S in art. E$w, q. v.) And yaxobiTu fiY AlZ~alaAmi (tropical:) He goes in the night without a lamp, and so becomes confounded and perplexed, and unable to see his right course, and errs from the way, and perchance may fall into a well. (TA.) And xabaTa All~ayola, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He went, or journeyed, in the night without direction. (K, TA.) And baAta yaxobiTu AlZ~alomaA='a (tropical:) [He passed the night traversing the darkness without direction]. (TA.) xaboTN is said to signify (assumed tropical:) The act of journeying, or going, without direction: or upon what is not the middle, or main part, of the road, or what is not the main road. (TA.) ― -b3- [And hence, perhaps,] xabaTahu (tropical:) He asked of him a benefit, or favour, without any tie of relationship; (K, * TA;) as also ↓AxtbThu: (IB, K:) or this is from xaboTu waraqi Al$~ajari [explained in what follows]: (Har p. 425:) or the latter, [or both,] he came to him seeking his beneficence without any such tie: (S:) or he came to him seeking a gift; because he who does so must beat the ground with his feet: (IF:) and you also say, maEoruwfahu ↓AxtbT. (Aboo-Málik, TA.) [The latter verb is the more common. See also 10.] ― -b4- And (tropical:) He conferred a benefit upon him without there having been any acquaintance between them, (S, K, TA,) and without there being anything to draw them near, and without there being any relationship: (TA:) and xabaTahu bixayori signifies the same: (TA:) or he bestowed on him a benefit, (K, TA,) being asked: (TA:) and you say also, bixayorK ↓AxtbThu: (Aboo-Málik, TA:) and xabaTa fiyhimo bixayorK signifies (assumed tropical:) He benefited them. (TA.) 'Alkameh Ibn-'Abadeh says, (S, TA,) praising El-Hárith Ibn-AbeeShemir, (TA,)
wafiY kul~i HaY~K qado xabaTota biniEomapK
(assumed tropical:) [And upon every tribe thou hast conferred benefit, app. meaning without being related to them]: (S, TA:) but it is said in a marginal note to the S, that xabaT~a would be better; and so it is accord. to one relation: in the L, however, it is said that xabat~a would be more agreeable with analogy. (TA.) Accord. to AZ, xabaTotu Alr~ajula, inf. n. xaboTN, signifies (assumed tropical:) I held loving communion, commerce, or intercourse, with the man. (TA.) ― -b5- [In respect of the places which I have given to the abovementioned significations of asking and conferring a benefit, I have followed the opinion of IF; but it is said in the TA, and, I think, with greater probability, that they are from what here next follows.] ― -b6- xabaTa Alwaraqa mina Al$~ajari, aor.
xabiTa
, (Msb,) inf. n. xaboTN, (Lth, T, Msb,) He made the leaves to fall from the trees: (Msb:) or he beat the leaves of the trees, (Lth, T,) meaning large trees of the kind called TaloH, [acacia, or mimosa, gummifera,] with a staff, or stick, (Lth,) so that they fell off, or became scattered, (Lth, T,) after which he gave them as food to camels; (Lth;) refrainfrom injuring thereby the trunks and branches of the trees: (T:) and lahu xabaTFA ↓AxtbT signifies the same as xabaTa. (TA.) And xabaTa Al$~ajarapa, (S, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (S,) He beat the tree with a staff, or stick, in order that its leaves might fall off: (S:) or he bound the tree, and then made its leaves to fall, (K, TA,) by beating it with a staff, or stick, to give them as food to camels and other beasts. (TA.) The leaves are stored up for the camels; and in wintertime are bruised, or broken up, for them, and moistened with water, and given to them as fodder. (Har p. 218.) Mohammad was asked, Does AlgaboT [i. e. “ the wishing for a blessing on the condition that it shall not become transferred from its possessor ”] injure [its author]? and he answered, laA A_il~aA kamaA yaDur~u AlEiDaAha AlxaboTu [No, save as the beating off the leaves injures the trees called 'idáh]; i. e., it only diminishes, without annulling, its author's recompense, like the beating off the leaves of the 'idáh, without cutting them down and extirpating them; for the leaves will grow again. (TA.) [See also art. gbT.] ― -b7- Hence, (A, TA,) xabaTa Alqawoma bisayofihi (tropical:) He struck the people with his sword. (A, K, TA.) ― -b8- xabaTahu Al$~ayoTaAnu (tropical:) The devil touched him with a hurt, (K, TA,) so as to corrupt him, or disorder him, and render him insane; (TA;) as also ↓txb~Thu: (K, TA:) or the latter, [which is the more common,] the devil corrupted him, or disordered him: (S, Mgh, Msb: *) lit., struck him: (Mgh, Msb:) or prostrated him, and sported with him: or trampled upon him, and prostrated him. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 276], ↓laA yaquwmuwna A_il~aA kamaA yaquwmu A@l~a*iY yataxab~aTuhu Al$~ayoTaAnu mina A@lomas~i (tropical:) [They shall not rise save as he riseth whom the devil prostrateth by reason of possession, or insanity]; i. e., as he who is affected by diabolical possession rises, in his state of possession, when he is prostrated, and falls: or it means, whom the devil corrupts, or disorders, by rendering him insane. (K, * TA.) [You say also, of a drug, AlEaqola ↓xb~T (assumed tropical:) It disordered the intellect: see the act. part. n., below.] ― -b9- xabaTa also signifies (assumed tropical:) He (a man) threw himself down (S, L, K) where he was, (S, L,) to sleep, (S, K,) or and slept. (L.) And (assumed tropical:) He (a man) slept. (A' Obeyd, TA.) In the K, qaAma is erroneously put for naAma. (TA.) ― -b10- xabaTa EalaY AlbaAbi He knocked upon the door, or at the door. (TA.) ― -b11- xabaTa AlEiroqu The vein beat, or pulsated. (TA.)

(Msb.) Accord. to Er-Rághib, xatomN and TaboEN signify The impressing a thing with the engraving of the signet and stamp: and the former [as is indicated, but not plainly expressed, as distinguished from the latter,] is tropically used, sometimes, as meaning the securing oneself from a thing, and protecting [oneself] from it; in consideration of protection by means of sealing upon writings and doors: and sometimes as meaning the producing an impression, or effect, upon a thing from another thing; in consideration of the impress produced [by the signet]: and sometimes it is used as relating to (assumed tropical:) the reaching the end [of a thing]: (TA:) or the primary signification of xatomN is the act of covering over [a thing]: (Az, TA:) accord. to Zj, the proper meaning of xatomN and TaboEN is the covering over a thing, and securing oneself from a thing's entering it: some say that the former signifies the concealing a notification of a thing, [as] by putting one's fingers over it, by way of guarding oneself thereby. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, xatomu Al$~ahaAdapi [The sealing of the testimony]; which is thus described by El-Hulwánee: the witness, when he wrote his name upon a Sak~ [q. v.], caused his written name to be beneath a piece of lead, [i. e. covered it with a piece of lead,] and put upon it the impress of his signet, in order that there might be no falsification of it or substitution for it. (Mgh.) ― -b3- As to xatomu AlA^aEonaAqi [The sealing of the necks], the case is related, in the “Risáleh Yoosufeeyeh,” to have been this: 'Omar sent Ibn-Honeyf to seal the Euluwj [or unbelievers] of the Sawád; and he sealed five hundred thousand of them, in classes; that is, he marked them twelve dirhems, and twenty-four, and forty-eight; tying a thong upon the neck of each, and putting upon the knot a seal of lead. (Mgh.) ― -b4- xatomN also signifies The protecting what is in a writing by marking [or stamping] a piece of clay [upon it, or by means of a seal of any kind]. (TA.) ― -b5- And you say, of a man, xatama Ealayoka baAbahu [He sealed his door against thee]; meaning (tropical:) he turned away from thee, avoided thee, or shunned thee. (TA.) ― -b6- And xatama laka baAbahu [He sealed for thee his door]; meaning (tropical:) he preferred thee to others. (TA.) ― -b7- xatama EalaY qalobihi [which may be rendered He sealed his heart] means (tropical:) he made him to be such that he understood not, and such that nothing proceeded from him; or he made his heart, or mind, to be such that it understood not, &c. (K, TA.) xatama A@ll~`hu EalaY quluwbihimo, in the Kur [ii. 6], is like the phrase in the same [xvi. 110 and xlvii. 18] TabaEa A@ll~`hu EalaY quluwbihimo: (TA:) it points to what God has made to be usually the case when a man has ended in believing what is false and in committing that which is forbidden, so that he turns not his face to the truth; this occasioning, as its result, his becoming inured to the approval of acts of disobedience, so that he is as though this habit were impressed upon his heart: the assertion of ElJubbáee, that it means God hath put a seal upon their hearts, as a sign, to the angels, of their infidelity, is nought: (Er-Rághib, TA:) Alxatomu is explained by IAar as meaning the preventing of the heart from believing. (L in art. xdE.) [See also TabaEa.] ― -b8- xatama Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. xatomN, also signifies [as indicated above] (assumed tropical:) He reached the end of the thing. (K.) You say, xatama AlquroA=na (assumed tropical:) He reached the end of the Kur-án [in reciting it]; (S, Er-Rághib;) [he recited the whole of the Kur-án;] he completed [the recital of] the Kur- án: (Mgh:) [and] he retained in his memory the last portion of the Kur-án; meaning he retained the whole of it in his memory. syn. xatalahu; (S, Mgh, K;) and desired to do to him a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, without his knowing whence it proceeded: (S, K:) or he dissembled [or acted deceitfully] with him; pretended to him the contrary of what he concealed: (TA:) or he made him to resign, or relinquish, the object that he had in view, by pretending to him something the contrary of what he concealed: (Er-Rághib, B:) and ↓xAdEhu, (S, TA,) inf. n. muxaAdaEapN (S) [and xidaAEN], signifies the same; (S, * TA;) as also ↓AxtdEhu; and ↓txd~Ehu; and ↓xd~Ehu, inf. n. taxodiyEN: (TA:) or this last signifies he deceived him, deluded him, beguiled him, circumvented him, or outwitted him, much: (KL:) [and of another of these verbs we find the following various explanations:] ↓xAdEhu is syn. with kaAyadahu [which has the first of the meanings assigned in this sentence to xadaEahu; or signifies he practised with him mutual deceit, delusion, guile, or circumvention; he deceived him, &c., being deceived, &c., by him; and this latter meaning, if not each meaning, may be intended here by kAydh; for Bd says, (in ii. 8,) that muxaAdaEap is between two]: (TA:) or it signifies he strove, endeavoured, or desired, to deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, or outwit, him; (AAF, L;) [agreeably with what is said by Kemál Páshá Zádeh, (as I find in a marginal note in a copy of the MS, and also in the Kull p. 178,) that one says of a man xAdE when he has not attained his desire, and xadaEa when he has attained his desire;] for many a verb of the measure faAEala relates to one only; as in the instances of EaAqabotu All~iS~a and TaAraqotu Aln~aEola: (L:) or it signifies, [like xadaEahu,] he pretended to him something different from that which was in his mind. (K.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 8], A@ll~`ha waA@l~a*iyna A=manuwA ↓yuxaAdiEuwna, (TA,) meaning They pretend, to God and to those who have believed, something different from that which is in their minds, by concealing unbelief and pretending belief; for when they do thus to the believers, they do thus to God: (K:) and again, [in iv. 141], A@ll~`ha wahuwa xaAdiEuhumo ↓yuxaAdiEuwna [They strive, endeavour, or desire, to deceive God, or] they think that they deceive God, but He is [their deceiver, i. e.,] the requiter, to them, of their xidaAE [or deceit, &c.]: (TA:) or the meaning is [they deceive] the friends of God: (S:) and [agreeably with this last rendering, and that given in the K,] Aboo-Hayáh reads, in the former passage, yaxodaEuwna A@ll~`ha: (TA:) [which passage continues thus:] A_il~aA A^anofusahumo ↓wamaA yuxaAdiEuwna [but they do not deceive any save themselves]; i. e., the re- sult of their xidaAE [or deceit] does not befall any save themselves: (K:) here, again, Aboo-Hayáh reads yaxodaEuwna: (TA:) Muärrik reads wamaA ↓yaxad~iEuwna, meaning yaxotadiEuwna. (K.) Accord. to IAar, AlxadoEu signifies manoEu AlHaq~i [meaning The preventing from discovering, or accepting, the truth]. (L.) [“ He deceived him, ” or the like, seems to be generally regarded as the primary signification of xadaEahu, for it occupies the first place in all the lexicons to which I have access: but Bd says (in ii. 8) that this meaning is from xadaEa said of the Dab~i, and that the primary signification of xadoEN is the act of “ concealing: ” the action of the Db~, however, as will appear in what follows, implies, and originates from, a desire of deceit; and so, often, does the act of concealing.] ― -b4- [Hence, app.,] xadaEotuhu I gained the mastery over him. (TA.) ― -b5- xadaEa, (Lth, TA, &c.,) aor.

[Hence,] A^axodaEu mino Dab~K [More deceitful, or guileful, than a dabb]; a prov.; (S, K;) applied to a person over whom one has not power, by reason of deceit, or guile. (IAar.) They said also, A_in~aka laA^axodiEu mino Dab~K Hara$otuhu [Verily thou art more deceitful, or guileful, than a dabb that I have hunted]. (AZ, AAF, O.) [See xidaAEN.] ＝ -A2- AlA^axodaEu [app. Each of the two branches of the occipital artery which are distributed upon the occiput;] a certain vein, (S, K,) one of a pair of veins, called the A^axodaEaAni, (S, Mgh, Msb,) in the cupping-place (Mgh, Msb) of the neck, (Mgh,) or in the place [of the application] of the two cupping-instruments; being a branch from the wariyd [or carotid artery]; (S, K;) sometimes the scarification [for cupping] happens to be upon one of them, and the patient consequently is exhausted by loss of blood: (S:) the AxdEAn are two concealed veins in the place of the cupping of the neck: Lh says, they are two veins in the neck: some say that they are the wadajaAni, q. v.: (TA:) the pl. is A^axaAdiEu. (K.) ― -b2- fulaAnN $adiydu AlA^axodaEi means Such a one is strong in the place of the AxdE. (As, S, O.) ― -b3- It also means (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is] a person who resists; unyielding; uncomplying. (TA.) And lay~inu AlA^axodaEu (assumed tropical:) One who does not resist; yielding; complying. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, lawaY fulaAnN A^axodaEahu (tropical:) Such a one turned away, or
aside, and behaved proudly, or haughtily. (TA.) And saw~aY A^axodaEahu (tropical:) He relinquished pride, or haughtiness. (TA.) And to him who is proud, one says, laA^uqiyman~a A^axodaEayoka, meaning (assumed tropical:) I will assuredly dispel thy pride. (Ham p. 432.)

(K, TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (Msb,) the same verb, (S, Msb, K,) with the same aor., (Msb, K,) and the same inf. n., (S, Msb, K,) said of a man, (Msb,) He became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or he became bereft of his reason or intellect, because of fear, or of shame: (S, Msb, K:) or he was confounded, perplexed, or amazed, [for yatahay~aba in the CK, I read yabohata, as in other copies of the K and in the TA,] opening his eyes, and looking: (K, TA:) and he remained confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of anxiety, or of hardship, or distress. (TA.) waqaEa faxariqa [He fell down and clave to the ground], occurring in a trad, means he fell down dead. (TA.) ＝ -A4- xariqa, aor.
xaraqa
, (JK, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. xaraqN; (S, Msb, K; *) and xaruqa, aor.

, (JK, K,) [of which xuroqN, said in the S and Msb to be a simple subst., may be the inf. n., like as HusonN is of Hasona;] He was rough, ungentle, clumsy, or awkward, (S, Msb, K,) in doing, or making, a thing: (Msb:) and he was unskilful in work, and in the management of affairs: and he was foolish; stupid; or unsound, or deficient, in intellect or understanding: (K:) or he was ignorant: (JK:) or the latter verb signifies he knew not his work with his hand, or his handicraft. (Msb.) And xaruqa biAl$~aYo'i He was ignorant of the thing, (K, TA,) and did it not well. (TA.)

xaroqN A^xrq xrq xrqp
, originally an inf. n., of 1: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) A hole, or perforation, (Mgh, Msb, KL,) in a garment, (S, TA,) and in a wall, (Msb, TA,) &c.: (Msb:) and a round hole, or perforation, in the ear of a sheep: (S, Msb:) pl. xuruwqN. (S, Mgh, Msb.) Hence the saying, Ait~asaEa Alxaroqu EalaY Alr~aAqiEi [The hole was, or became, wide to the patcher]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A part that has a hole made in it, or that is rent, or torn, of, or from, a thing. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A desert; and so ↓maxoraqN: (K:) or the former, a desert far extending, (JK, TA,) whether level or not level: and ↓ the latter, a wide desert in which the winds [blow, or] blow irregularly: (TA:) and the former, (El-Muärrij, K,) as also ↓xaroqaA='N, (K,) signifies likewise a wide land, (K,) or a wide country, (El-Muärrij,) in which the winds [blow, or] blow irregularly: (El-Muärrij, K: [see 7:]) ISh says, the space between El-Basrah and Hafr Abee-Moosà is a xaroq, and that between En-Nibáj and Dareeyeh is a xaroq: (TA:) pl. xuruwqN. a subst. from xariqa, (S, Msb,) [or perhaps inf. n. of xaruqa as syn. with xariqa, (see 1, last two sentences,)] and ↓xuruqN, (TA,) Roughness, ungentleness, clumsiness, or awkwardness; contr. of rifoqN; (JK, S, * Mgh, Msb, * K, TA;) in doing, or making, a thing: (Msb:) unskilfulness in work, and in the management of affairs: foolishness; stupidity; or unsoundness, or deficiency, in intellect or understanding; as also ↓xuroqapN: (K:) and ignorance. and ↓xir~iyqN (tropical:) Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (S, K;) as also ↓mixoraAqN: (IAar, K:) or ↓ the second signifies very liberal or bountiful &c.: (K: [so in a later part of the art.:]) or this and the first signify one who takes a wide, or an ample, range, or is profuse, in liberality or bounty &c.: (TA:) or a youth, or young man, (JK,) excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, address, speech, person, and the like; or clever, or ingenious; with liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity, (Lth, JK, K,) and courage: (Lth, JK:) and a goodly youth or young man, [for AlfatiY~u in the CK, I read AlfataY, as in other copies of the K,] of generous disposition: (K:) the pl. (of xiroqN, TA) is A^axoraAqN [a pl. of pauc.] (K) and xuraAqN, or xur~aAqN, (accord. to different copies of the K, [both anomalous, and perhaps it is xiraAqN, agreeably with analogy,]) and xuruwqN; (K;) and the pl. of ↓xir~iyqN is xir~iyquwna; no broken pl. of it having been heard. A womb rent by the fœtus, and that consequently does not conceive (K, TA) afterwards; (TA;) [of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN;] as also ↓mutaxar~iqapN. El.) ― -b5- xaroqaA='u applied to a desert, and to a land: see xaroqN, in three places. ― -b6- And applied to a wind: see xariyqN. ― -b7- Hence, riHolapN xaroqA='u (assumed tropical:) A hard journey. mixoraAqN mxrAq
A kerchief twisted for the purpose of beating therewith: (JK, S:) a genuine Arabic word: (S:) or a thing made of twisted rags, with which boys play: (TA:) or a twisted kerchief, or an inflated [skin such as is termed] ziq~, or the like, with which boys play, beating one another therewith: so called because it rends (yaxoriqu) the air when they make use of it: (Ham p. 702:) pl. maxaAriyqu. (S, TA.) 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom says,
kaA^an~a suyuwfanaA min~aA waminohumo
maxaAriyqN biA^ayodiY laA EibiynaA
[As though our swords, ours and theirs, were kerchiefs twisted for beating therewith, in the hands of players]: (S:) or mxAryq in this verse [written with tenween by poetic license] is the pl. of mixoraAqN signifying a wooden sword with which boys play: the poet means, we cared not for the smiting with the swords, like as the players care not for the smiting with the mxAryq. [See also another ex., in a verse cited voce xariyjN.] 'Alee is related, in a trad., to have said that the lightning is the maxaAriyq of the angels; (S, TA;) meaning thereby the instruments with which the angels chide and drive the clouds. (JK, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) One who falls not into a case without escaping, or extricating himself, therefrom. , inf.n. xaromN, He perforated, or pierced, it; namely, a thing. (Msb.) [And so xazamahu. (Mgh in art. xzm.)] ― -b2- And He cut it, or cut it off. (Msb.) A^avoA^ayotuhu [meaning I spoiled the sewing of the skin, or hide; as when one uses a thick instrument for sewing or perforating, and a thin thong; or as when one rends two stitch-holes into one]. , (K,) inf. n. xaramN, (S,) said of a man, (S, K,) He had the partition between his nostrils cut, or mutilated: or the extremity of his nose, but not to the extent denoted by the term jadoEN: the epithet applied to the man in this case is ↓A^axoramu: (S:) or he had the partition between his nostrils slit; i. e. wataratuhu ↓taxar~amato. yabosa AlHaSaAdi januwbu ↓kamaA xa$oxa$atu
[The short coats of mail of iron rustled upon them, like as when a south wind has caused to rustle the dry reaped corn]. (S.)

xa$~N *
: see maxo$uw$N.

xa$aA$N *
: see xi$aA$N; for the former, in three places.

xu$aA$N *
: see xi$aA$N; for the former, in three places.

xi$aA$N *
The wooden thing that is inserted in the bone of the nose of the camel, (S, A, K,) to which the nose-rein is tied, in order that he may be quickly submissive: (TA:) the burap is of brass, (S, TA,) or of silver; (TA;) and the xizaAmap is of hair: (S:) or the thing that is put in the nose; and the brp is the thing that is put in the flesh: (Lh:) or what is in the bone, when it is wood, or a stick; and the EiraAn is what is in the flesh, above the nose: (As:) a wooden thing, or stick, that is put in the bone of the nose of the camel: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb:) pl. A^axi$~apN. (A, Msb.) [Hence the saying,] jaEala Alxi$aA$a fiY A^anofihi waqaAdahu A_ilaY AlT~aAEapi biEunofihi (tropical:) [He put the x$A$ in his nose, and drew him to obedience by his violence]. (A, TA.) [And hence, also,] it signifies gaDabN, (IAar, K,) as used in the saying, Har~aka xi$aA$ahu, [lit., He put in motion his xi$aA$: meaning, (assumed tropical:) he roused, or excited, his anger; or] he made him angry. (IAar.) ＝ -A2- Alxi$aA$u, and ↓Alxa$aA$u, (S, K,) the latter form being sometimes used, (S,) which indicates that the former is the more chaste, but, accord. to MF, several authorities say the contrary, (TA,) and ↓Alxu$aA$u, (K,) or AlA^aroDi ↓xa$aA$u, (A 'Obeyd, Msb,) and xi$aA$u AlA^aroDi, (Msb,) The creeping things of the earth: n. un. with p, which is syn. with AlHa$arapu and AlhaAm~apu: (Msb:) the Ha$araAt (A' Obeyd, S, K) of the earth, (A' Obeyd, K,) and its hawaAm~, and [other] creeping things, (A 'Obeyd,) such as sparrows and the like: (A 'Obeyd, K: *) or xi$aA$u AlA^aroDi, and AlT~ayori, signify the small ones of beasts or creeping things [of the earth], and of birds: (A:) IAar is related to have said that it is ↓xi$oxaA$N, contr. to what is said by the lexicologists in general: and these things are said to have their appellation from their entering into the earth and concealing themselves; but this assertion is not valid: (ISd:) in a trad., for mn x$A$ AlArD, one relation substitutes ↓mino xa$iy$ihaA, which has the same meaning: and some say that it is ↓xu$ayo$, a contracted dim. of x$A$; or ↓xu$ay~i$, without contraction: (TA:) and ↓Alxa$aA$u signifies the bad [meaning ignoble] kinds of birds; this being with fet-h only: (As:) or birds that do not prey: (IAar, TA voce EuqaAbN:) xi$aA$N, with kesr, also signifies the serpent of the mountain; which does not suffer one to survive; and the A^afoEaY is the serpent of the plain; (El-Fak'asee, K;) which like wise does not suffer one to survive: (K:) or a great and abominable vuEobaAn: or a serpent like the A^aroqam, but smaller: or a small, tawny serpent, smaller than the Arqm: (TA:) or a white serpent, which seldom hurts, between the Huf~aAv and the Arqm: (Aboo-Kheyreh:) or such as is light, or active, and small in the head, of serpents: explained also as signifying the serpent, without restriction: (TA:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) such as has no power of defence, [maA laA difaAEa lahu, as in the CK and a MS copy of the K, for which we find in some copies of the K, and in the TA, mA lA dimaAga lahu such as has no brains, which is doubtless a mistake,] of beasts or creeping things of the earth, and of birds, (K,) such as the ostrich, and the [bustard called] HubaAraY, and the karawaAn [or stonecurlew], and [the bird called] mulaAEibu Zil~ihi, and the [harmless kinds of] serpent: (TA:) or what is small in the head, and slender, of beasts or creeping things: and the kite; and [the bird called] mulaAEibu Zil~ihi: (Aboo-Muslim:) the pl. is x$~A=' [app. xu$~aA='u, originally xu$a$aA='u, unless a mistake for A^axi$~aA='u, originally A^axo$i$aA='u]. (TA.)

xa$iy$N *
, and xu$ayo$N, and xu$ay~i$N: see xi$aA$N.

xu$~aA='N *
The bone which is protuberant behind the ear, (S, Msb, K,) and which is thin, and bare of hair: (TA:) originally xu$a$aA='u, (S, Msb, K,) of the measure fuEalaA='u; (S;) [but masc., and perfectly decl., as being quasi-coordinate to quroTaAsN, whereas the original is fem., and imperfectly decl.; (see quwabaA='u;)] like quwobaA='N, which is originally quwabaA='u; (S, Msb;) and these two words are the only instances of their kind: (ISk, Msb:) dual xu$a$aAwaAn. (S, K.)

xa$oxa$apN *
The [clashing, clattering, chinking, jingling, rattling, or rustling,] sound of arms, or weapons, (S, A, * K,) and the like; (S;) as also $axo$axapN, but this latter is a dial. var. of weak authority: (TA:) and of any dry or hard thing rubbing against another such thing: (K:) accord. to IDrd, such [sound or thing (for his words are ambiguous)] is termed ↓xa$oxaA$N: (TA:) and the [rustling] sound of a new garment or piece of cloth, when it is put in motion; as also na$ona$apN: (IAar:) and [a confused sound] such as is heard to proceed from the inside of an animal on its being hit by an arrow: (JK in art. x$f:) and a motion having a sound like the sound of arms, or weapons; (TA;) or an audible motion. (Mgh in art. x$f.)

xa$oxaA$N *
A company: (ISd, TA:) or a numerous company of men: (Az, TA:) or a company (S, K) in, (K,) or having upon them, (S,) arms, or weapons, and coats of mail. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also xa$oxa$apN. ＝ -A3- Also A certain plant, (S, Msb,) well known; (S, Msb, K;) [namely, the poppy;] which is of several species; (K;) i. e., four; (TA;) yusotaAniY~N [or garden-poppy,] (K,) which is the white, and this is the most fit for eating, and the best thereof is the fresh and heavy; (TA;) and manovuwrN, (K,) which is the wild Egyptian; (TA;) and muqar~anN, [app. the horned poppy,] (K,) the produce of which has an elongated extremity like the horn of the bull; (TA;) and zubodiY~N, [app. the spattling poppy,] (K,) which is known by the name of blbs [a word which I have not been able to find elsewhere]: (TA:) every one of these is soporiferous, and produces torpidness, and cools: (K:) used as a suppository, it produces sleep: and the integument [of the capsule] has a stronger power of producing sleep than the seeds: (TA:) [or rather the seeds have no narcotic power:] from half a drachm of the integument, with cold water, as a draught, taken early in the morning, and the like at sleep, has a wonderful effect in stopping a looseness characterized by a mixture of humours and by blood, when accompanied by heat and inflammation: (K:) it is wonderful also that its solid part confines, and its juice relaxes: and when the root, or lower part, is taken with water, [and boiled] so that the water is reduced to half its quantity, it is beneficial as a remedy for diseases of the liver arising from thick humour: so says the author of the Minháj: (TA:) the n. un. is with
p: (Msb:) and the pl. is xa$aAxi$u [app. a mistake for xa$aAxiy$u]. (TA.) [See also A^afoyuwnN.]

xi$oxaA$N *
: see xi$aA$N.

maxo$uw$N *
A camel having a xi$aA$ put in his nose; as also ↓xa$N. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

1 xa$aba *
, (S, K,) aor.
xa$iba
, (K,) inf. n. xa$obN, (TA,) He mixed a thing (S, K) with (bi) another thing. (S.) ― -b2- And He picked out, chose out, or selected, a thing: the verb thus having two contr. significations. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) He polished a sword, (S, K,) by laying on it a broad and smooth spearhead and rubbing it therewith: so accord. to ElAhmar, who relates that an Arab of the desert said to him, I said to a sword-polisher, “ Hast thou finished my sword? ” and he answered, naEamo A_il~aA A^an~iY lamo A^axo$ibohu [Yes, except that I have not polished it]. (S.) And [or, as in the TA, “ or ”] He sharpened it. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And He forged a sword: (K:) or fashioned it with the file, without polishing it: (TA:) or he made it imperfectly, not thoroughly, or not well: (A:) thus, again, the verb has two contr. significations: (K:) also he thus made an arrow: (A:) or he shaped out a bow, (AHn, K,) and an arrow, (TA,) [in a rough manner, or] by the first operation, (AHn, K, TA,) without perfecting it, or making it smooth, or even. (TA.) You say of a sword, before it has been filed, maA A^aHosana maA xu$iba [How well has it been forged!]: and in like manner one says of an arrow, when it has been filed, before the safan [with which it is smoothed] has been applied to it. (Skr, on a verse of Sakhr, cited below, voce xa$iybapN.) ― -b3- [Hence,] xa$aba Al$~iEora, (ISk, S, A, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (A,) (tropical:) He said, spoke, or uttered, the poetry (ISk, S, A, K) as it came, (ISk, S,) [unpolished, and unstudied,] without affecting nicety, or refinement, therein, (ISk, S, A, K,) and without study, or labour: (A, K:) Jereer did thus, and Farezdak trimmed his verses; but the verses of Jereer thus produced are better than the trimmed verses of Farezdak: (A, TA:) and ↓Axt$bhu signifies the same. (A, K.) You say also, humo yaxo$ibuwna AlkalaAma waAlEamala (tropical:) [They say, speak, or utter, words, and do work, without affecting nicety, or refinement, and without study, or labour]: (A:) or imperfectly, or not thoroughly; inelegantly, or not well. (TA.) And Ait~axa*a Als~ayofa xa$abFA: see 8.

5 tx$~b *
: see 8. ＝ -A2- tx$~bti AlA_ibilu The camels ate thick branches: (K:) or ate dry herbage. (S.) And tataxa$~abu EiydaAna Al$~ajari They take with the mouth, and eat, the branches of the trees. (TA.)

8 Axt$b Als~ayofi *
signifies ↓Ait~axa*ahu xa$obFA; He took the sword without choosing the best by taking it from this place or that; (L, TA;) as also ↓tH$~bhu. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the end.

12 Ax$w$b *
He [a man or a camel (see xa$ibN)] was, or became, tall, and gross, rude, or coarse, with bones uncovered by flesh, and hard, or hardy. (K.) He (an ostrich) was, or became, rough, or coarse. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became hard, or hardy, and rough, or coarse, in his religion, clothing, food, and in all respects. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) He employed himself in work, and in walking barefoot, in order that his body might become thick, gross, or coarse. (S, TA.) And Ax$w$b fiY Eayo$ihi (assumed tropical:) He endured with patience a life of hardship, or difficulty: or he subjected himself to a life of hardship, or difficulty, in order to render himself the more able to bear it. (K, TA.) Aixo$awo$ibuwA is thus used in a trad. of 'Omar: (S, TA:) or, as some relate it, the word is [Aj$w$bwA,] with j; or, accord. to some, Ax$w$nwA, with x and n. (TA.)

rajulN qi$obN xi$obN *
A man in whom is no good: (S, K:) or with whom is no good: (TA:) [in some copies of the K, xi$obN wa qi$obN; but this, as is said in the TA, is incorrect:] xi$obN being an imitative sequent to qi$obN. (S, TA.)

xa$abN *
[Wood, such as is used in carpentry and the like; timber;] thick wood: (A, K:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. xa$abapN [signifying a piece of wood or timber]: (Msb:) the pl. of the latter, (S, Msb, *) or of the former, (K,) is xa$abN, (S, K, [i. e., accord. to the K, the pl. is the same as the sing., but properly speaking, as said above, this is a coll. gen. n.,]) and xu$ubN and xu$obN (S, Msb, K) and xu$obaAnN, (S, K,) [which last is agreeable with analogy as pl. of xa$abN,] or xu$obaAnN is pl. of xu$obN, and xu$obN is pl. of xa$abapN. (JK.) The hypocrites are described in a trad. as xu$ubN biAll~ayoli SuxubN biAln~ahaAri Like timbers, or pieces of wood, in the night; [clamorous in the day;] meaning that they pass the night in sleep, without prayer. (TA.) ― -b2- maAlN xa$abN (assumed tropical:) Cattle that are lean, or emaciated, syn. hazolaY, (K,) in consequence of their feeding upon dry herbage. (TA.) [And it seems that ↓xa$abN signifies the same: for I find in the TA, and in a copy of the A which I believe to have been used by the author of the TA, mentioned as tropical, maAlN xa$abN waHaTibN jazolN, app. meaning that maAlN xa$ibN and HaTibN signify jazolN; but jazolN, I think, is here evidently a mistranscription for hazolaY; as HaTibN is explained in the S and K as signifying “ very lean or meagre. ”]

xa$ibN *
Rough, or coarse; as also ↓A^axo$abuxa$iybN: (K:) the former applied in this sense to a male ostrich: (S:) and both signify anything gross, or big, and rough, or coarse; (A 'Obeyd, S;) as also ↓xa$iybN: (TA:) and the first, (K,) applied to a man and to a camel, (TA,) tall, and gross, rude, or coarse, with bones uncovered by flesh, and hard, or hardy, and strong; (K, * TA;) as also ↓xa$iybN and ↓xa$iybiY~N: (K:) or these three signify, or signify also, dry, or rigid, or tough: (Kr, ISd:) and xa$ibN, a man hard, or hardy, strong, and vigorous, in body: (A, TA:) and the same, (JK,) or ↓xa$iybN, (TA,) a man whose bones are uncovered by flesh, and whose sinews are apparent; (JK, TA;) hard, or hardy, and strong: (JK:) and the last, a gross, big, or coarse, camel: (S, TA:) a camel gross, coarse, or rude, in make, and ugly: (TA:) and a horse thick, or big, in the bones. (Ham p. 207.) See also xa$abN. And see A^axo$abu, in two places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Life in which one is not dainty, nice, or scrupulous. (K.)

xa$obapN *
The first filing of a sword, before the polishing. (TA.)

xu$obaAnN *
: see A^axo$abu.

xa$aAbN *
: see A^axo$abu.

xu$aAbN *
, from the Persian xuw$o A=bo, [The beverage properly called in Arabic] nabiy*. (TA.)

xa$iybN *
and ↓maxo$uwbN Mixed. (TA.) ― -b2- And the former, (K,) or both, (TA,) Picked out, chosen, or selected: (K, TA:) both words thus having two contr. significations. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the former (S, K) and latter, (K,) A sword polished: (S, K: *) this is [said to be] the prevailing signification: (TA:) or both signify a sharpened sword. (JK, TA.) ― -b2- And the former, (As, S, K,) or both, (JK, A,) A sword of which the forging is commenced; thus [again] having two contr. significations: (S:) or forged, (K, * TA,) or fashioned with the file, but not yet polished: (As, TA:) or newly made: (TA:) or imperfectly, not thoroughly, or not well, wrought; (JK, A;) and thus both words applied to an arrow: (A:) or the former, (S, K,) or both, (TA,) applied to an arrow, (S, K,) and to a bow, (K,) shaped out (S, K) [in a rough manner,] by the first operation, (S, TA,) not yet perfected, or made smooth, or even: (TA:) pl. of the former (accord. to the TA as applied to a bow [but I see no reason for this restriction]) xu$ubN and xa$aAy^ibu. (K.) lamo yunaq~aHo ↓maxo$uwbN [Rough hewn, not yet trimmed,] is a prov., mentioned by Meyd and Z. (MF, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] $iEorN xa$iybN and ↓maxo$uwbN (tropical:) Poetry said, spoken, or uttered, as it has come to the speaker, [unpolished, and unstudied,] without his affecting nicety, or refinement, therein, and without study, or labour. (A, * TA.) And jaA='a ↓bilmaxo$uwbi (tropical:) [He said, or uttered, that which came to him, as it came, unpolished, and unstudied]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- See also xa$iybN voce xa$ibN, in three places. ― -b5- It also signifies Bad, corrupt, or vile. (K.)

xa$iybapN *
The natural quality [of the metal] of a sword, (Skr on the verse here following, S, TA,) before the making thereof is completed: (Skr:) or its blade, or iron: (A:) or its edge: or its polish. (JK.) Sakhr says,
waSaArimN A^uxoliSato xa$iybatuhu
A^aboyaDu mahowN fiY matonihi zubadu
And a sharp sword of which the natural quality [of the metal] before the completion of the making thereof has been refined, [white, or a sword,] thin in the two edges or sides, having [in its broad side] diversified marks. (Skr.)

xa$iybiY~N *
: see xa$ibN.

xa$~aAbN *
: see what next follows.

xa$~aAbapN *
[a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is ↓xa$~aAbN,] Sellers of xa$ab [i. e. wood, or timber]. (TA.) ― -b2- Fighters with staves. ＝ -A2- Accord. to ElHejeree, x$Abp [so in the TA, without any syll. sign,] signifies A slender [implement of the kind called] mTrq [i. e. miToraq, q. v.,] which the polisher, when he has finished the polishing of a sword, passes over it, in consequence of which the scabbard does not alter its state. (TA.)

xaA$ibN *
: see muxota$ibN.

A^axo$abu *
: see xa$ibN. Also A great mountain: (A:) or a rugged, or rough, and great mountain; (S, K;) and so ↓jabalN xa$ibN: or such as is not to be ascended: (TA:) an elevated place, rugged, with rough stones: (JK:) a tract of the kind termed quf~, rugged and stony: (TA:) pl. A^axaA$ibu, (A, TA,) because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it: and the fem. xa$obaA='u is also sometimes used in the same sense; or as syn. with gayoDapN [i. e. a thicket, &c.]; but the former meaning is better known: and this [likewise] is thought to be rather a subst. than an epithet, because of the pl., mentioned above: (TA:) and ↓xu$obaAnN [also seems to be a pl. of A^axo$abu, or of xa$ibN; for it is said that it] signifies rugged, or rough, mountains, neither great nor small: (K:) and rugged ground. (TA in art. *nb.) xa$obaA='u also signifies Hard land or ground; (K, * TA;) land, or ground, in which are stones and pebbles and earth or clay. (IAmb, TA.) And A^aroDN ↓xa$aAbN (K, TA) Hard land or ground, like xa$obaA='u, (TA,) that flows with the least rain. (K, TA.) And A^akamapN xa$obaA='u (S, TA) A hill of which the stones are scattered, but near together. (TA.) And jabohapN xa$obaA='u A displeasing forehead; as also ↓xa$ibapN: (TA:) or a displeasing, rigid forehead; (JK, S, K; *) not even. (JK.) And A^axo$abu Aljabohapi A man having a displeasing and rigid forehead. (TA.)

bayotN muxa$~abN *
[so in the present day, but written in the TA without any syll. sign,] A house having xa$ab [i. e. wood, or timber, employed in its construction]. (TA.)

maxo$uwbN *
: see xa$iybN, in four places. ― -b2- It is applied to a horse, by El-Aashà; (S, TA;) meaning Of mixed pedigree: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or not broken; not well trained; from what next follows; and thus used only by El-Aashà. (IKh, TA.) ― -b3- jafonapN maxo$uwbapN A wooden bowl imperfectly made. (IKh, TA.) ― -b4- TaEaAmN maxo$uwbN [Food imperfectly prepared; i. e.], if flesh-meat, not thoroughly cooked; and if not flesh-meat, (but grain, TA,) without any seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (K, * TA.)

muxota$ibN *
One who eats what he can; as also ↓xaA$ibN. (JK.)

1 xa$arahu *
, aor.
xa$ira
, (S, K,) inf. n. xa$orN, (S,) He picked it, (Lh, S, K,) namely, a collection of goods, or commodities, (Lh,) removing from it what was bad. (Lh, S, K.) ― -b2- And xa$ara, aor. (and inf. n., TA) as above, He left upon the table refuse of food: thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also xa$arahu He rendered it (a thing) bad, or vile. (TA.)

xu$aArN *
(K) and ↓xu$aArapN (S, A, K) The bad part or parts [or the refuse] (Lh, S, K) of goods, or commodities, (Lh,) or of anything. (S, K.) And the latter, The worst kind, syn. $iyS, of lates. (A.) ― -b2- What contains no lub~ [or heart], of barley. (A, K.) ― -b3- And the latter, The refuse of food remaining upon a table; that in which is no good. (S, A, K. *) ― -b4- Also the latter, (S, A, K,) and the former, (K,) and ↓xu$~aArN, (IAar,) (tropical:) The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people; (IAar, S, A, K;) as also ↓xaA$irN, accord. to the K, but correctly ↓xaA$irapN, as related by AA from IAar. (TA.) El-Hotei-ah says,
wabaAEa baniyhi baEoDuhumo bixu$aArapF
wabiEota li*uboyaAna AlEalaA='a bimaAliki
[And some of them have sold their sons for the refuse of mankind; but] thou hast purchased eminence for Dhubyán with Málik: in the S we find bimaAlikaA [with thy property]: but it is correctly as above: Málik was a son of 'Oyeyneh Ibn- Hisn: the Benoo-'Ámir slew him: wherefore 'Oyeyneh made war upon them, and obtained his blood-revenge, and spoil: and to this event El- Hotei-ah refers in the verse above. (IB, TA.)

xu$aArapN *
: see the paragraph next preceding.

xu$~aArN *
: see the paragraph next preceding.

xaA$irN *
: see the paragraph next preceding.

xaA$irapN *
: see the paragraph next preceding.

1 xa$aEa *
, aor.
xa$aEa
, inf. n. xu$uwEN, He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓Axt$E (S, K) and ↓tx$~E; (Abu-lFet-h, Ham pp. 24 and 127;) xu$uwEN being syn. with xuDuwEN: (S, Msb, K:) or x$wE is nearly the same as xDwE: (Lth, K:) or the former is mostly used as meaning in the voice; and the latter, in the necks: (Msb:) or the latter is in the body; and the former is in the voice and in the eyes: (K:) or, as we read in the 'Eyn, the former is nearly the same as the latter, except that the latter is in the body, and signifies the acknowledging of humility and submission, and the former is in the voice and in the eyes; and the like is said in the Nh [and in the Msb in art. xDE]. (TA.) You say, xa$aEati AlA^aSowaAtu The voices were [or shall be (as in the Kur xx. 107]) still and low: (Msb:) or low: or, as some say, still. (TA.) And xa$aEa bibaSarihi He lowered his eye. (S.) And ↓Axt$E and ↓tx$~E He cast his eye towards the ground, and lowered his voice. (TA.) Lth says that you say, fulaAnN ↓Axt$E, but not Axt$E bibaSarihi. (TA.) And xa$aEa baSaruhu His eye became contracted. (TA.) And xa$aEato duwnahu AlA^aboSaAru (tropical:) [meaning The eyes were cast down before him, or it]. (TA.) xu$uwEN also signifies The being, or becoming, still: and the abasing oneself; or lowering oneself. (K, TA.) And ↓Axt$E, He lowered, or stooped, or bent down, his breast. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, He feared; for instance, in prayer: (TA:) or xa$aEa fiY SalaAtihi and fiY duEaAy^ihi signifies He applied himself with his heart to [or in] his prayer, and his supplication. (Msb.) ― -b3- xa$aEati AlkawaAkibu, (Aboo-'Adnán,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) The stars approached to the place of setting; (Aboo-'Adnán;) or approached to setting: (K:) or sank, and nearly disappeared in their setting-place. (Aboo- Sálih El-Kilábee.) [The corresponding phrase in Hebrew, occurring in Gen. xxxvii. 9, probably has the same meaning.] ― -b4- xa$aEati Al$~amosu (tropical:) The sun became eclipsed. A^axoDaru *
[Green; verdant;] of the colour termed xuD~aAraY; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓xaDirN (Msb, K) and ↓xaDiyrN and ↓xaDuwrN and ↓yaxoDuwrN and ↓yaxoDiyrN: (K, TA: the last two written in the CK taxoDuwrN and taxoDiyrN:) applied to a horse, [and to a camel, (see xuDorapN,) and to an ass, and sometimes to a bird, and to a garment of the kind called kisaA=', and the like, and to various other things, of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour; or dingy ash-colour; or dark dust-colour;] of a dust-colour intermixed with duhomap [i. e. blackness or deep ash-colour]; which is the same as dayozajN; (S;) in horses being distinguished as A^axoDaru A^adogamu and A^axoDaru A^aToHalu and A^axoDaru A^aworaqu: (TA: [see the latter epithet in each of these cases:]) applied to a man, [and to other things,] tawny, or brownish: (S:) [and blackish: and of a blackish hue inclining to green:] and black; (S, K;) black-complexioned: (TA:) [and intensely black: it is said in the Msb, art. Htm, that AlA^axoDaru is, with the Arabs, A^asowadu; which may mean either that green is, with the Arabs, termed Aswd, or that AlAxDr is, with the Arabs, black: but the truth is, that each of the epithets A^axoDaru and A^asowadu is sometimes used for the other: see what here follows, and see A^asowadu: in Har p. 495, it is erroneously said, on the authority of Er-Rázee, that the Aswd is not termed by the Arabs AxDr, although the AxDr is termed by them Aswd because of its intense xuDorap and riY~:] the fem. is xaDoraA='u: and the pl. is xuDorN. (Msb, TA.) You say $ajarapN xaDoraA='u A green, and fresh, or juicy, tree. (TA.) And maA='N A^axoDaru Water inclining to a green colour, by reason of its clearness. (TA.) And A^axoDaru Aljilodapi [lit. Tawny of skin:] meaning (assumed tropical:) of pure race; because the complexions of the Arabs are tawny; (S;) of genuine Arab race: (IB:) as in the saying of El-Lahabee, (S, TA,) El-Fadl Ibn-'Abbás, (TA,)
waA^anaA AlA^axoDaru mano yaEorifuniY
A^axoDaru Aljilodapi fiY bayoti AlEarabo
[And I am the tawny: who knows me? the tawny of skin (or pure of race), of the family that comprises the nobility of the Arabs]. (S, IB.) And fulaAnN A^axoDaru AlqafaA [lit. Such a one is blackish, or black, in the back of the neck:] meaning (tropical:) such a one is the son of a black woman: (Az, A:) or (tropical:) one who is slapped on the back of his neck: (A:) or (tropical:) a freedman, or an emancipated slave. (TA.) And A^axoDaru AlbaToni (tropical:) A weaver: (A, TA:) because his belly, being stuck close to his loom, becomes blackened by it. (TA.) And A^axoDaru Aln~awaAji*i (tropical:) An eater of onions and leeks: or a tiller, or cultivator, of the ground; because he eats herbs, or leguminous plants. (A.) And humo xuDoru AlmanaAkibi [lit. They are green in the shoulders, from carrying the produce of their land:] meaning (tropical:) they are in a state of great plenty. (K, TA.) And [hence, perhaps,] fulaAnN A^axoDaru (tropical:) Such a one possesses abundant xayor [or wealth, or prosperity]: (A, TA:) [or it may mean goodness: for] AlA^axoDaru, applied to a man, is an epithet of praise, whereby he may be likened to the sea, because it is described as green, or to the [rain or herbage called] rabiyE; in both cases meaning (assumed tropical:) liberal, or bountiful; and it is so applied because xuDorapN is of the colours of the Arabs: and it is also an epithet of dispraise, as meaning (assumed tropical:) black by reason of baseness, ignobleness, or meanness. (Ham p. 282.) And $aAb~N A^axoDaru (tropical:) A young man whose hair has begun to grow upon the sides of his face. (TA.) And katiybapN xaDoraA='u (tropical:) An army, or a troop of horse, overspread with the blackness of iron: (S, TA:) or a great army or troop of horse (K, TA) of which most of the men are clad in iron; like jaA^owaA='u: (TA:) because of the xuDorap of the iron: (A:) [i. e.] because of the blackness thereof. (TA.) And All~ayolu A^axoDaru (tropical:) Night is black. (TA.) And [hence,] jan~a Ealayohi A^axoDaru AljanaAHayoni (tropical:) Night [lit. the black-winged] veiled him, concealed him, or covered him with its darkness. (A.) mudohaAm~ataAni, in the Kur [lv. 64, relating to two gardens of Paradise], is explained by xaDoraAwaAni because it means Inclining to blackness, by reason of abundance of moisture, or irrigation. (S.) ― -b2- AlA^axoDaru used as a subst.: see xuDaArapN. ― -b3- The fem. xaDoraA='u [is also used as a subst., and] signifies Gree herbs or leguminous plants; (Msb, K;) as also ↓xuDaArapN: (K:) pl. xaDoraAwaAtN: by rule it should be xuDorN; but as the quality of a subst. predominates in it, it has a pl. like the pl. of a subst., like SaHoraAwaAtN pl. of SaHoraA='N: (Msb:) this pl. occurs in the saying (in a trad., TA) layosa fiY AlxaDoraAwaAti SadaqapN There is no poor-rate in the case of green herbs or leguminous plants; (Msb;) or fresh fruits and herbs or leguminous plants; (TA;) or fruits, such as the apple and the pear &c.; or herbs or leguminous plants, such as leeks and smallage and rue and the like; and xuDarN, pl. of xuDorapN, is sometimes substituted for it. (Mgh.) [Hence,] A_iy~aAkumo waxaDoraA='u Ald~imani, meaning (tropical:) Avoid ye the beautiful woman that is of bad origin: (S, A, Msb:) because what grows in a dimonap [or place which men have blackened by their cooking, and where their camels or other beasts have staled and dunged], though it may be beautiful and bright, does not bear fruit [because it is neglected, and left unwatered], (S, Msb,) and soon becomes corrupt, or bad. (Msb. [See also dimonapN: and see Eu$obapN Ald~aAri, in art. E$b.]) ― -b4- And AlxaDoraA='u, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, (TA,) (tropical:) The sky, or heaven; (S, A, K;) because of its greenness; like as the earth is called AlgaboraA='u. (TA.) You say, maA taHota AlxaDoraA='i A^akorahu minohu (tropical:) [There is not under the sky one more hateful than he]. (A.) ― -b5- And xaDoraA='u (tropical:) A bucket (A, K) with which water has been drawn long, so that it has become green or blackish &c. (Hat~aY A@xoDar~ato). (K.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The congregated or collective body, and mass, or bulk, of a people. (S, K.) So in the saying, A^abaAda A@ll~`hu xaDoraA='ahumo (assumed tropical:) [May God destroy the congregated or collective body, mass, or bulk, of them]: (S:) or this means, (tropical:) their stock ($ajarap) from which they have branched off; (A;) [for] xaDoraA='u signifies the origin of anything: (TA:) or, their life in this present world: (Fr, TA:) or, as some say, their enjoyment and plenty; (TA;) [for] xaDoraA='u signifies prosperity, and plenty, and enjoyment: (TA in a later part of this art.:) or the right reading is gaDoraA='ahumo, meaning “their prosperity, and their pleasantness of life, or plenty and prosperity.” (S. [See art. gDr.]) ― -b7- Albaqolapu AlxaDoraA='u: see xaDirN. ― -b8- AlxuDoru, (T,) or AlxaDoraA='u, (K,) The domestic pigeons; (T, K;) so called although of various colours, because their predominant colour is wuroqap [or ash-colour], or xuDorap [meaning a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]: the xuDor and the numor [or spotted with white and black, &c.,] are especially characterized by the faculty of rightly directing their course. (T, TA.) ― -b9- AlA^axaASiru [a pl. of AlA^axoDaru used as a subst.] (tropical:) Gold and flesh-meat and wine; as also AlA^aHaAmirapu [as some explain this latter]. (TA.) ― -b10- A^axoDaru also signifies (tropical:) Fresh, or recent: so in the saying, AlA^amoru bayonanaA A^axoDaru (tropical:) [The affair between us is fresh, or recent]: and in like manner you say, Almawad~apu bayonanaA xaDoraA='u (tropical:) Love, or affection, between us is fresh. (A.) And Soft, or tender; applied to herbage, or seed-produce. (TA.) ― -b11- [Hence,] Eiy$apN xaDoraA='u (assumed tropical:) A mode of life soft, or delicate, and plentiful and pleasant. (Har p. 639.) ― -b12- AlA^axoDaru is also the name of [A certain star, or asterism; most probably either a of Piscis Australis or ε of Pegasus, or some star or asterism nearly in a line with those two;] one of the three A^anowaA=' of the rain called Alxariyf; namely, the middle nawo' of those three AnwA='; the first being the nasoraAni; and the last, the foremost of the farogaAni: see nawo'N. (AZ, T and TA in art. nwA^.)

You say, xaT~a Alz~aAjiru fiY AlA^aroDi, aor. and inf. n. as above, The diviner made a line, or a mark, or lines, or marks, upon the ground, and then divined. (TA.) And Alz~aAjiru yaxuT~u biA_iSobaEihi fiY Alr~amoli wayazojuru [The diviner makes lines, or marks, with his finger upon the sand, and divines]. (S.) Th says, on the authority of IAar, that Eilomu AlxaT~i is Eilomu Alr~amoli [or geomancy]: I 'Ab says that it is an ancient science, which men have relinquished: but Lth says that it is practised to the present time; [to which I may add, that it has not even now ceased; being still practised on sand and the like, and also on paper;] and they have conventional terms which they employ in it, and they elicit thereby the secret thoughts &c., and often hit upon the right therein: the diviner comes to a piece of soft ground, and he has a boy, with whom is a style; and the master makes many lines, or marks, in haste, that they may not be counted; then he returns, and obliterates leisurely lines, or marks, two by two; and if there remain two lines, or marks, they are a sign of success, and of the attainment of the thing wanted: while he obliterates, his boy says, for the sake of auguring well, AibonaYo EiyaAno A^asoriEaA AlbayaAno [O two sons of 'Iyán (meaning two lines or marks), hasten ye the manifestation]: I 'Ab says that when he has obliterated the lines, or marks, and one remains, it is the sign of disappointment: and AZ and Lth relate the like of this. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh Ibn-El-Hakam Es-Sulamee, traced up by him to its author, kaAna nabiY~N mina AlA^anobiyaA='i yaxuT~u famano xaT~ahu Ealima mivola Eilomihi [A prophet of the prophets used to practise geomancy; and he who matches his geomancy knows the like of his knowledge]. (TA.) You say also, when a man is meditating upon his affair, and considering what may be its issue, or result, fulaAnN yaxuT~u fiY AlA^aroDi (tropical:) [Such a one makes lines, or marks, upon the ground]. (TA.) [See also nakata: and see St. John's Gospel, ch. viii. verses 6 and 8.] And xaT~a birijolihi AlA^aroDa means (tropical:) He walked, or went along.
