8 AixotilaAfN AxtlAf {xtlAf
signifies The following reciprocally; or alternating. (Mgh.) So in the phrase in the Kur [ii. 159 and iii. 187 and xlv. 4], waA@xotilaAfi All~ayolu waAln~ahaAri And the alternating of the night and the day. (Mgh) [And in a verse of El-'Ajjáj cited voce A^abolaY, in art. blw.] And hence the phrase, AixotalafaA DarobapF Each of them beat, or struck the other in turn. (Mgh.) And the saying, in a trad. of 'Alee, faA@xotalafato bayona Eubayodapa boni AlH`rivi waAlwaliydi boni Euqobapa DarobataAni [And two blows were interchanged between 'Obeydeh Ibn-El-Hárith and El-Weleed Ibn-'Okbeh]. (Mgh.) And the saying, in a trad. of Umm-Sabeeyeh, Aixotalafato yadiY waydu rasuwli A@ll~`hi fiY A_inaA='K waAHidK, meaning My hand and the hand of the Apostle of God were both put [by turns] into one vessel. (Mgh.) And AixotalafuwA signifies They followed, or succeeded, one another; whenever one went, another coming after him. (TA in art. Ewr.) ― -b2- Also The going, or moving, repeatedly, to and fro; so coming and going; or reciprocating; syn. tarad~udN [in this sense, as is shown in this art. in the K and TA, and in the S and K in art. rwd &c.: and also as mean ing the returning, or repairing, time after time, or repeatedly, or frequently, to a person or place; because it implies coming and going: and sometimes it means simply the returning; because this cannot be without a previous going]. (K.) You say, huwa yaxotalifu A_ilaY fulaAnK, i. e. yatarad~adu [He returns, or repairs, time after time, repeatedly, or frequently, to such a one]: and Aixotalafa A_ilayohi A@xotilaAfapF waAHidapF [He returned to him once]. (TA.) And huwa yaxotalifu A_ilaY majaAlisi AlEilomi He repairs frequently to, or frequents, the assemblies of science; syn. yatarad~adu. (A in art. rd.) And Aixotalafa A_ilaY AlmutawaD~aA^i [He returned, or repaired, time after time, &c., to the privy]. (S.) And Aixotalafa A_ilaY AlxalA='i [properly signifies the same: and hence, (assumed tropical:) He had a looseness of the bowels, or a diarrhœa]. (K.) And [perhaps as implying coming and going,] Axtlf also signifies He supplied, or gave, or offered, water. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also The disagreeing, differing, or varying, in state or condition or quality &c.; being dissimilar, different, diverse, various, incongruous, discordant, or dissentient:] Axtlf is the contr. of Ait~afaqa; (K, TA;) and is said of anything that is dissimilar [in the parts or members &c. of which it is composed]; as also ↓txAlf. (TA.) You say, AlA^amoraAni ↓txAlf [and Axtlf AlAmrAn], i. e. lamo yat~afiqaA [The two things, or affairs, or cases, were, or became, dissimilar, &c.]. (TA.) And AxtlfwA and ↓txAlfwA (Mgh, Msb) [They disagreed, &c., fiY A^amorK in a thing or an affair or a case;] every one of them took to, or held, a way, or an opinion, different from, or contrary to, that of another: (Msb:) both signify the same. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., saw~uwA Sufuwfakumo walaA taxotalifuwA fataxotalifa quluwbukumo [Make ye your ranks even when ye place yourselves to pray together, and be not dissimilar in your positions, for in that case your hearts would disagree]; meaning, when one of you advances, or stands, before another in the ranks, your hearts will be affected, and disagreement in respect of friendship and amity will arise among you: or, as some say, it means, your hearts will be made to recoil: or the Suwrap [or specific character] of your hearts will become changed into another Swrp. (TA.) [Hence,] Aixotalafato Eano A^anowaAy^ihaA, said of stars: see 4, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b4- Also The being complicated, intricate, or confused. (KL.) [You say, Axtlf AlA^amoru bayonahumo The affair, or case, was, or became, complicated, intricate, or confused, so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference, between them: a phrase of frequent occurrence.] ＝ -A2- Axtlfhu: see 1, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- See also 2, in two places. ― -b3- Axtlf SaAHibahu: see 3, near the middle of the paragraph.

10 Astxlfhu A^stxlfh Astxlfh Astxlfp {stxlf {stxlfh
: see 2, in two places. ― -b2- Also He took it (a thing) as a substitute, or in exchange, for another thing; or in the place of another thing; syn. AisotaEowaDahu and Aisotabodalahu. (TA.) ― -b3- Astxlfti AlA^aroDu The land produced the herbage of the [season called] Aisotabodalahu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in the middle of the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.

xalofN xlf
[meaning The location, or quarter, that is behind; and the time past;] (K; [so in my MS. copy, and thus it should be written as a simple noun; but in the CK xalofu;]) or Alxalofu; (Lth, K;) contr. of qud~aAmN [or Alqud~aAmu]: (Lth, K:) [and] xalofa [Behind; and after;] contr. of qud~aAma: (S: [thus in my tow copies; and said in the margin of one of them to be thus in the copy of IB, and in that of El-Jawáleekee:]) a simple noun: and an adv. n.: of the fem. gender [as meaning the jihap; but otherwise it seems to be masc.]. (TA.) You say, jaA='a xalofahu [and mino xalofihi, both meaning He came behind him, and after him]. (Mgh.) And jalasotu xalofa fulaAnK I sat after, or behind, such a one; syn. baEodahu (S.) And labiva xalofahu He remained after him. (K.) Some read, in the Kur [xvii. 78], waA_i*FA laAyalobavuwna xalofaka: others read xilaAfaka [which means the same, as mentioned above: see the middle of the first paragraph of this art.]. (TA.) ― -b2- xalofN signifies also The back (K, TA) itself: so says IAar: and particularly, of a house; the side corresponding to, or over against, that in which is the door; and as a house may have two doors, [in two different sides,] it may be said to have two backs, each of which may be thus termed; and the dual of this word seems to be used as meaning two backs in a trad. [respecting the building of the Kaabeh]. (TA.) ― -b3- And One who comes after another; (S, TA;) as also ↓xalafN, or, accord. to some, there is a difference between these two, as will be shown in what follows; (S;) and ↓xaAlifN and ↓xaAlifapN: it is originally an inf. n.: (TA:) and signifies one who remains after another, whether this other be dead or living: and one remaining after another who is dead; his follower, or successor; the follower, or successor, of one who has gone: used in praise and in dispraise: pl. xuluwfN: and the sing. also signifies [like the pl.] persons remaining after others; accord. to some: (IB, TA:) a remnant of people: (Lh, TA:) and a generation after a generation; (Lth, S, K;) as also ↓xalafN: (Lth, TA:) but Lth says that the former is applied to the evil, and ↓ the latter to the good, (K, TA,) whether meaning a generation or a son: (TA:) the latter means a good son (K, TA) remaining after his father: (TA:) and the former, a bad son: (K, TA:) [therefore] one says, huwa xalofu sawo'K mino A^abiyhi [He is a bad son] who has taken the place of his father, and SidoqK mn Abyh ↓xalafu [a good son] &c.: (S:) but sometimes each is used in the place of the other; so that one says, hw xalofu SidoqK mn Abyh: (K:) or both signify the same: (S, K:) so says Akh: some, he says, use the former; and some, the latter: but some say SidoqK ↓xalafu and xalofu sawo'K, meaning thus to distinguish between them: (S:) accord. to IB, ↓xalafN correctly signifies a man's successor who is a substitute for him, good and bad: and is originally an inf. n.: (TA:) and the pl. of this is A^axolaAfN: (AZ, IB, TA:) accord. to IAth, xalafu SidoqK means a good generation: and xalofu sawo'K, an evil generation: (TA:) and xalofN likewise signifies progeny [without restriction]. (K.) One says also, (S, K,) of a people following people more in number than they, (S,) h`w^ulaA='i xalofu sawo'K [These are a bad generation. (S, K.) And baqiynaA fiY xalofi sawo'K We remained among an evil remnant. (Lh, TA.) And faxalafa mino baEodihimo xalofN, in the Kur [vii. 168
and xix. 60], is explained as meaning And there remained after them a remnant. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] (tropical:) One in whom is no good. (IB, K.) [And app. also Persons in whom is no good..] ― -b5- And (tropical:) A thing in which is no good: (IB, TA:) [and particularly] (assumed tropical:) a bad saying; (ISk, S, Msb, K;) a wrong, bad saying, like the xalof of mankind. (A 'Obeyd, Msb.) See also xulofN. It is said in a prov., sakata A^alofFA wanaTaqa xalofFA (assumed tropical:) He held his tongue from a thousand words (sakata Eano A^alofi kalimap), and then uttered what was wrong. (ISk, S, Msb.) An Arab of the desert, who had been guilty of a breach of manners (Habaqa HaboqapF), pointed with his thumb towards his Aisot, and said, A_in~ahaA xalofN naTaqato xalofFA [which may be rendered, Verily it is a thing in which is no good: it uttered a thing in which was no good: but it obviously admits of being rendered otherwise]. (IAar, S.) ― -b6- Also People who have gone away from the tribe (T, K) to draw water, and have left their baggage &c. behind them: (T, TA:) and such as are present, [remaining behind,] of the tribe: thus bearing two contr. significations: pl. xuluwfN. (K.) You say HaY~N xuluwfN A tribe who are absent; none of them remaining behind: (S, TA:) or a tribe of which the men are absent and the women remaining: (TA:) and xuluwfN also signifies the contr., i. e. such as are present, (S, TA,) remaining behind. (S.) It is said of Mohammad, in a trad., lamo yatoruko A^aholahu xuluwfFA, i. e. He did not leave his family neglected, with no pastor nor protector. (TA.) See also a verse of El-Hoteíäh in the latter part of the first paragraph of this article. ＝ -A2- Old and worn out; applied to a waTob [or skin for milk, or for clarified butter and milk: as though it were a remnant thereof]. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.) ＝ -A3- A mirobad; (S, K;) i. e. a place of confinement for camels: (TA:) or such as is behind the tent or house. (JK, S, * K.) ＝ -A4- A large faA^os [i. e. hoe or adze or axe]: or such as has one head: and the edge of a fA^s: or the head thereof: (K:) you say faA^osN *aAtu xaloqayoni a two-headed fA^s: (S, TA:) or *aAtu xaloqayoni and ↓*aAtu xiloqayoni are names of the fA^s (K, TA) when two-headed: (TA:) and the pl. is *awaAtu Alxaloqayoni: (K:) pl. xuluwfN. (JK.) ― -b2- And The head of a razor. (K.) ― -b3- And The [pointed] head of a minoqaAr, [an iron instrument like the faA^os, (A and K in art. nqr,) with which mill-stones &c. are pecked, or wrought into shape, (see minoqaArN,) and] with which wood is cut. (TA.) ＝ -A5- See also xilofN.

xulofN xlf
a subst. from A_ixolaAfN, (S, Msb, K,) relating to a promise, and restricted to future time; (Msb;) i. e. a subst. used in the place of A_ixolaAfN; (Lh, TA;) meaning The breach, or non-fulfilment, of a promise; as also ↓xulufN, which is said to be the original form of the word, and ↓xuluwfN: (TA:) it is, in respect of the future, like ka*ibN in respect of the past: (S, K:) some say that it signifies a false, or wrong, saying; which is a meaning of ↓xalofN, with fet-h, before mentioned: but perhaps these two words may be syn. dial. vars. (MF, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (Msb,) or ↓xulofapN, and ↓xilofapN, (K, TA,) Disagreement, difference, dissension, contrariety, contrariousness, or opposition, (Msb, K, * TA,) in opinions or the like, (Msb,) or in respect of friendship and amity, (TA in explanation of the second of these words,) or in natural disposition; (K;) as also ↓xilafonapN (S, K) and ↓xilafonaApN and ↓xaAlifN and ↓xaAlifapN. (K.) ＝ -A2- It is also pl. of xaliyfN, in its various senses.

xilofN xlf
: see xilofapN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in seven places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, (Sgh,) i. q. lajuwjN [app. as meaning One who perseveres much in opposition or contention or the like]; (Sgh, K;) as also ↓xaAlifapN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also a subst. from A_ixolaAfN meaning The act of drawing water; and so ↓xilofapN: (A 'Obeyd, K: *) [whence the saying,] mino A^ayoni xilofatukumo Whence do ye draw water? (S, K.) ＝ -A3- The teat (Halamap) of the udder of the she-camel: (S, K:) and the two fore ones, and the two hinder ones: (S:) or the part of the udder upon which the milker lays hold: (TA:) or the extremity of the udder of the she-camel: (Msb, K:) or the hinder of the A^aTobaA=' [or teats]: (K:) or the udder itself; (Lth, TA;) [i. e.] it is, to the she-camel, (Msb, * K,) like the vadoY to the human being, (Msb,) or like the DaroE to the ewe or she-goat: (K:) or the xilof is of the camel and of the cloven-hoofed animal; and the TuboY, of the solid-hoofed animal and of the animal that has a claw: (Lh, TA:) the pl. [properly of pauc.] is A^axolaAfN (Msb, TA) and [of mult.] xuluwfN. (TA.) One says, dar~ato lahu A^axolaAfu Ald~unoyaA (tropical:) [The world yielded him abundance of its good things]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- The shortest of the ribs of the side; (S;) [and] so ↓xalofN; (K;) likewise called DilaEN Alxilofi and Alxalofi; it is the furthest and thinnest of the ribs; (TA;) [i. e.] the xilof is that next to the belly, of the small ribs; their quSayoraY: (K: [see AlquSoraY:]) pl. of the former (S) [and] of the latter (K) xuluwfN. (S, K.) ＝ -A5- *aAtu xilofayoni: see xalofN, near the end of the paragraph.

xalafN xlf
A substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in place of, or in exchange for, another thing. (A 'Obeyd, Th, S, Msb, K, TA.) You say, AijoEalo h`*aA xalofFA mino h`*aA Make thou this to be a substitute for this. (Msb.) And h`*aA xalafN mim~aA A^uxi*a laka This is a substitute for what has been taken to thee. (IB.) And fiY h`w^ulaA='i Alqawomi xalafN mim~ano maDaY In these people are such as supply the place of those who have gone. (TA.) And fiY fulaAnK xalafN mino fulaAnK [In such a one is a substitute for such a one]. (TA.) And huwa mino A^abiyhi xalafN He is a substitute for his father. (IB.) See also xalofN, in six places, in the former half of the paragraph.

xalifN xlf
, applied to she-camels, i. q. maxaADN, i. e. Pregnant: n. un. with p: (S, K:) accord. to some, (TA,) the pl. of xalifapN, which signifies a pregnant camel, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) or, as some say, one that has completed a year after bringing forth and has then been covered and has conceived, until she enters upon the term called Alt~aEo$iyr, (TA, [from-the time when her pregnancy has become manifest, (see qaAriHN and laAqiHN,)] is maxaADN, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) like as the pl. of AimoraA^apN is nisaA='N; (Msb, TA;) and sometimes xalifaAtN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and xilaAfN: (TA:) but xalifN occurs in the saying of the rájiz,
maA laka tarogiyna walaA taroguwA Alxalifo
[What aileth thee that thou utterest a grumbling cry, when the pregnant camels utter not that cry?]. (IB.)

xulafN xlf
: see xulofapN.

xulufN xlf
: see xulofN.

xalofapN xlf xlfh xlfp
: see the next paragraph, in two places.

xulofapN xlf xlfh xlfp
: see xulofN. ― -b2- Also A vice, a fault, or an imperfection: (K:) and badness, corruptness, vitiousness, or dishonesty: (TA:) and foolishness, or stupidity; or paucity, or want, of intellect or understanding; as also ↓xalaAfapN [properly an inf. n., of xalufa, and before mentioned as such; (see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph;)] and idiocy. (K.) All of these meanings have been assigned to it in explanations of the saying, A^abiyEuka h`*aA AlEaboda waA^aboraA^u A_ilayoka mino xulofatihi [I sell to thee this slave, but I am irresponsible to thee for his vice, &c.]: or, accord. to IAar, the meaning is, xilaAfihi [his contrariousness]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The last taste of food; (K;) as in the saying, A_in~ahu laTay~ibu Alxulofapi [Verily it is good, or sweet, in respect of the last taste]; (TA;) and so ↓xalofapN: pl. xulafN: and it (xulofapN) signifies also loss of appetite for food, in consequence of disease: (so accord. to the CK:) [or,] accord. to some copies of the K, ↓xalofapN has this latter signification; and so ↓xulafN: accord. to other copies, xulafN is pl of xalofapN in this sense: but both these readings require consideration: what is found in the Lexicons is, xalafato nafosuhu Eani AlT~aEaAmi, aor.
xalufa
, inf. n. xuluwfN; meaning as explained above, in the latter half of the first paragraph. (TA.)

xilofapN xlf xlfh xlfp
a subst. signifying A mode, or manner, of coming after [or behind]; like qiEodapN signifying “ a mode, or manner, of sitting. ” (Msb.) ― -b2- See also xulofN. ― -b3- It signifies also Difference [of any kind]: (K, * TA:) or the coming and going of the night and the day; (S, K, * TA;) and likewise of wild animals. (K.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xxv. 63], wahuwa A@l~a*iY jaEala A@ll~ayola waA@ln~ahaAra xilofapF, (S, K, *) meaning *awaY xilofapK, (Bd,) i. e. [And He it is who hath made the night and the day] so that each replaces the other: or each follows the other: (K, * TA:) or so that he who is unable to accomplish a thing in the night may do it in the day, and the reverse. (Fr, L, K.) Zuheyr says, of wild animals, yamo$iyna xilofapF, meaning They go to and fro. (S, TA. [See Em p. 109.]) And one says, A^axa*atohu xilofapN, meaning He was
taken with [an affection causing] a frequent going to and from the privy. (S, K.) [And hence,] xilofapN signifies also, A discharging of the bowels; or a purging and vomiting together; (K;) or a disordered state of the stomach arising from [unwholesome] food; (TA;) a looseness, or diarrhœa. (JK, TA.) ― -b4- See also xilofN. ― -b5- Also The bringing of camels to the watering-place in the evening, after the people have gone away. (L, K.) ― -b6- And A man's watching to see another, (A^ano yunaAZira in some copies of the K, and An yunaASira in other copies, being put for An yubaASiru, which is the right reading, agreeably with an explanation of Aixotalafa SaAHibahu, [for which see 3, near the middle of the paragraph,] TA,) and when he is absent from his family, going in to them, (K, TA,) or [rather], when he is absent from his wife, going in to her. (TA, after the explanation of the phrase above mentioned.) ＝ -A2- A thing that is suspended behind the rider; (JK, K;) such as is suspended behind the [kind of vehicle called] maHomil. (TA.) ― -b2- Remains of water in a trough or tank. (TA.) ― -b3- What remains, of food, between the teeth. (Lh, K.) ― -b4- A plant, or herbage, that comes forth after another plant, or other herbage, (S, Msb, K,) which has become dry, and broken in pieces: (S, TA:) or that comes forth not from rain, but by reason of the cold of the latter part of the night. (Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee, K. [See also rabolN.]) ― -b5- What the trees disclose in the beginning of the cold, (K, TA,) by reason of the [rain called] Safariy~ap [q. v.]: (TA:) or fruit that comes forth after other fruit: (K:) or fruit that comes forth after abundant fruit; (S, Mgh, TA;) this being termed the xilofap of trees: (S, Mgh:) or a growth of leaves after the falling away of other leaves: (K, * TA: duwna in the K is a mistake for baEoda: TA:) or leaves that come forth after the first leaves, in the [season called] Sayof. (Nh, TA.) ― -b6- What grows in the Sayof [or summer]; so says A 'Obeyd: (S, K:) or, (JK, Mgh, K,) as also ↓xilofN, (K,) the herbage produced by the Syf, (JK, K,) or in the Syf, (Mgh,) after the springherbage has dried up. (JK, Mgh.) ― -b7- A produce of grape-vines after the grapes have turned black; the grapes being gathered while it is fresh and green, it then ripens: and so other fruits: or a new produce, by the vine, of fresh sour grapes. (K.) ― -b8- Grain that is sown (JK, * Mgh, K *) after the former has come to maturity: (Mgh, TA:) because taken as a substitute for wheat and barley: (K:) pl. xilafN. (Mgh.) ― -b9- A piece with which a garment is patched (K) when it is old and worn out. (TA.) ― -b10- A time after a time. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A3- Differing [one from another or others]; as also ↓xilofN: (K:) it is applied in this sense to a people, or company of men: (AZ, S, K:) and to beasts, or horses or the like, as meaning differing (K, TA) in their colours and appearances: (TA:) and xilofataAni is applied to any two things that are different; (Ks, TA;) as also ↓xilofaAni: (Ks, Msb, TA:) and xilofapN, (K,) or xilofataAni, (Ks, TA,) to any two colours that are combined [because different]. (Ks, K, TA.) AZ cites, as an ex., the saying [of a rájiz],
saAqiyaAhumaA ↓dalowaAYo xilofaAni
[My two buckets are different, and their two suppliers with water]; (S, TA;) meaning that one of them [i. e. of the buckets] is ascending and full, and the other is descending and empty; or that one of them is new, and the other is old and worn out. (TA, in two places.) And one says of two children, or two male slaves; or two female slaves, that they are xilofataAni, (Ks, K,) and ↓xilofaAni, (K,) applying to the male and the female, (TA,) meaning One tall and the other short: or one white and the other black. (Ks, K.) One says also, banuw fulaAnK xilofapN, meaning The children of such a one are half males and half females. (S.) And nitaAju fulaAnK xilofapN The offspring of the beasts of such a one are one year male and another year female. (JK, TA.) And ↓waladato xilofayoni, said of ewe or goat, (K,) or of a camel, (L,) She brought forth one year a male and another year a female. (L, K.) The pl. [of ↓xilofN] (K, TA) in all its senses (TA) is A^axolaAfN and xilafapN; (K, * TA;) the latter, [in the CK xilofapN,] like qiradapN as pl. of qirodN. (TA.)

xulofufN xlff
and xulofafN and xulofufapN and xulofafapN: see xaAlifN, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- A^um~u xulofufK (Sgh, K) and xulofafN Calamity, or misfortune: or the greatest calamity or misfortune. (K.)

xilafonapN xlf xlfnh xlfnp
and xilafonaApN: see xulofN: ― -b2- and see also xaAlifN, in the middle of the paragraph.

xilaAfN xlAf
an inf. n. of 3 [q. v. passim]. (S, &c.) ― -b2- Also The contrary, or opposite, of a thing; syn. Did~N. (Msb in art. Dd. [Very often used in this sense.]) You say, AlAixotilaAfu xilaAfu AlAit~ifaAqi [i. e. AlAxtlAf is the contrary of AlAt~fAq] (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, Msb, K,) by the vulgar (O, Msb, TA) incorrectly pronounced with teshdeed (O, Msb, K, TA) and fet-h [to the x, i. e. xal~aAfN], (TA,) A well-known kind of tree; (S;) the [kind of tree called] SafoSaAf: (Msb:) or a species of the SfSAf, but not the SfSAf itself: (K:) [the salix Aegyptia of Linnæus; called by this name in the present day; and by some, improperly, baAnN, q. v.:] it abounds in the land of the Arabs; and is [also] called sawojarN [or sawoHarN]; and there are many varieties thereof; all of them soft and weak; (TA;) but it is seldom, or never, found in the desert: (Msb:) they assert that it is thus called because the torrent brings it from one locality to another, so that it grows in a place different from that of its origin; (AHn, Msb, K, * TA;) but this is not a valid assertion: (TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (Msb, TA.) suw~iyna mino xilaAfi, in the saying of the rájiz cited voce xuf~N, means Made of different trees: it does not mean of the tree called xilaAf; because this is seldom, or never, found in the desert. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also The sleeve of a shirt. (IAar, K.)

xuluwfN xlwf
: see xulofN. ＝ -A2- It is also, as stated above, pl. of xalofN: (IB, K, TA:) ― -b2- and a pl. of xilofN. (TA.)

xaliyfN xlyf
: see xaliyfapN, in three places. ― -b2- Also One who holds back from the place, or time, of promise: and one who breaks a promise. (TA.) ― -b3- And A woman that has let down her hair behind her. (JK, O, K.) ― -b4- And A woman that has attained to the period of one day, or two days, after her having brought forth. (IAar.) [Perhaps from the signification next following.] ― -b5- A she-camel in the second day after her having brought forth: pl. xulufN and xulofN: (K, TA:) these two pls. are mentioned in the K in different places in this art., but both are correct, like rusulN and rusolN. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) one says, rakibahaA yawoma xaliyfihaA [He rode her on the second day after she had brought forth]. (K.) ― -b6- And The milk that is after the biestings: (AA, K:) pl. as above. (K.) One says also, HalabahaA xaliyfa libay^ihaA He drew from her the milk that came after the biestings had passed away. (JK.) And AiytinaA bilabani naAqatika yawoma xaliyfihaA, i. e. [Bring thou to us the milk of thy she-camel of the day] after the cessation of her biestings; i. e., of the milking that is after her bringing forth by a day or two days. (AA, TA.) ＝ -A2- Applied to a garment, (S, K,) or a shirt, (Msb,) Having the middle, wornout part taken out, and the [cut] edges then sewed together: (S, Msb, K *:) and ↓maxoluwfN signifies the same; (JK;) or a garment composed of two pieces sewed together: or, as some say, this signifies a garment pledged. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also, accord. to A 'Obeyd, The part beneath the armpit: and the xaliyfaAni of the camel are like the A_iboTaAni of man: accord. to the S and the O, xaliyfaA Aln~aAqapi signifies the two armpits of the she-camel (A_iboTaAhaA): but the author of the K, following the [first] explanation given by A 'Obeyd, says that this is wrong, and that the meaning is the parts beneath the two armpits of the she-camel. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And A gap between two mountains, (JK,) or between two mountain-tops, (TA,) of little breadth and length: (JK, TA:) or a road between two mountains: (S, K:) or a valley between two mountains: (K:) or a place where water pours forth (K, TA) between two mountains, or between two valleys, passing thence into a wide tract: (TA:) and any road in a mountain, (Skr, K,) or behind a mountain, or behind a valley: (TA:) or simply a road; as also ↓maxolafapN; (JK, K;) this being either in a plain or in a mountain: (TA:) pl. of the former as above. (K.) One says *iyxu Alxaliyfi i. e. [The hairy male hyena] of the road between two mountains, (S, K,) or of the valley between two mountains; (K) like as one says *iy^obu gaDFA. (S.) ＝ -A5- And A sharp arrow: (AHn, K:) or, accord. to Skr, the word in this sense is HaliyfN, with the unpointed H; and this is more probably correct. (TA.)

xalaAfapN xlAf xlAfh xlAfp
: see xulofapN.

xilaAfapN xlAf xlAfh xlAfp
inf. n. of xalafahu as meaning “ he was, or became, his xaliyfap ” [q. v.]. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [And hence, as a simple subst., The office of xaliyfap.]

xaliyfapN xlyfh xlyfp
A successor: and a vice-agent, vice-
gerent, lieutenant, substitute, proxy, or deputy: (KL:) one who has been made, or appointed, to take the place of him who has been before him: (JK:) an act. part. n. of xalafahu, inf. n. xalafN and xilaAfapN; as also ↓xaliyfN: (TA:) or it may have the meaning of an act. part. n. or that of a pass. part. n.: and so in the sense next following: (Msb:) the supreme, or greatest, ruler or sovereign, (S, Msb, K, TA,) who supplies the place of him who has been before him; (TA;) [particularly the successor of the Prophet; whence “ Caliph, ” commonly used by English writers for “ Khaleefeh; ”] as also ↓xaliyfN, (K,) which is the original form, (Msb,) without p; (Msb, TA;) disapproved by some, but mentioned by AHát and Ibn-' Abbád and IB, and occurring in a verse of Ows Ibn-Hajar cited by IB: (TA:) the p in the former is to denote intensiveness of signification, (Nh, Msb, TA,) as in Eal~aAmapN and nas~aAbapN: (Msb:) or, as some say, liln~aqoli [i. e. for the transference of the word from the category of epithets to that of substs.]: (TA:) it is also said that the word may be an epithet of which the subst. qualified thereby is suppressed, for nafosN xaliyfapN; but this requires consideration: (MF, TA:) it is an epithet applied to a man peculiarly: (Msb:) some make it fem.; (Fr, S, Msb, K;) saying h`*aA xaliyfapN A^uxoraY [This is another Khaleefeh]; though the proper way is to make it masc.: (Msb:) a poet says,
A^abuwka xaliyfapN waladatohu A^uxoraY
waA^anota xaliyfapN *aAka AlkamaAlu
[Thy father was a Khaleefeh, whom another Khaleefeh begat; and thou art a Khaleefeh: that is perfection]: (Fr, S:) the pl. is xalaAy^ifu [generally applied to any people that have succeeded others, and supplied their places, as in the Kur x. 15], (S, K,) like as karaAy^imu is pl. of kariymapN; (S;) and xulafaA='u [generally applied to successors of the Prophet], (S, K,) because, as it applies only to the male, and has p added, the p is dropped in forming the pl., which is thus like ZurafaA='u as pl. of ZariyfN: (S:) thus says ISk, and the like is said in the O: but what AHát and Ibn-'Abbád say requires not this straining: (TA:) [i. e.] xalaAy^ifu is pl. of xaliyfapN; and xulafaA='u, of ↓xaliyfN: (JK:) or some, having regard to the original, make the pl. to be xulafaA='u, like as $urafaA='u is pl. of $ariyfN; (Msb;) and this pl. is masc. only, so that you say valaAvapN xulafaA='a: (ISk, Msb, TA:) and some, having regard to the word itself [in its altered and used state], make the pl. to be xalaAy^ifu; (Msb;) and this pl. may have prefixed to it either a masc. or a fem. n. of number, so that you say valaAvapN xalaAy^ifa and valaAvu xalaAy^ifa; (ISk, Msb, TA;) both of which are chaste. (Msb.) You say, kaAna A@ll~`hu xaliyfapa waAlidika Ealayoka [May God be to thee a supplier of the place of thy father]: (S, Msb: *) and in like manner you say, to a person, of any one whom he has lost by death, (S, Msb,) and who cannot be replaced; as the paternal uncle; (Msb;) or the mother. (K.) Some say that the application of the title xaliyfapu A@ll~`hi [The Vicegerent of God] is not allowable, except to Adam and David because there is express authority in these instances [in the Kur ii. 28 and xxxviii. 25]; but others allow it in other cases, like suloTaAnu A@ll~`hi and junuwdu A@ll~`hi and Hizobu A@ll~`hi and xayolu A@ll~`hi; all of which have been heard: (Msb:) and Zj says that it is allowable to say of the Imáms that they are xulafaA='u A@ll~`hi fiY A^aroDihi [The Vicegerents of God in his earth]. (TA.)

xil~iyfapN xlyfh xlyfp
: see the middle of the next paragraph.

xaAlifN xAlf
: see xalofN, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also One who remains behind, or after, another, (Yz, K, TA,) or others, in the case of a war, or a warring and plundering expedition, and in other cases: (TA:) pl. xaAlifuwna (Yz, K, TA) and xawaAlifu, which latter is extr. [in this case], but is also said to be a [reg.] pl. of ↓xaAlifapN, and as such to signify persons who do not go forth on a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition: and AlgaAziY ↓xaAlifapu signifies he who remains behind, or after, him who goes forth on such an expedition, being of his family. (TA.) faA@qoEuduwA maEa AlxaAlifiyna, in the Kur [ix. 84], means Then stay ye with those who remain behind. (Yz, K. *) xawaAlifu is also pl. of ↓xaAlifapN [as fem. of xaAlifN], (TA,) and signifies Women (K, TA) remaining behind in the houses or tents: but some assign to it the first of the meanings explained above: and some say that it means the children remaining behind. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 88 and 94], ↓raDuwA biA^ano yakuwnuwA maEa AlxawaAlifi, i. e. [They chose to be] with the women: (S, K: *) thus it is explained by Ibn-'Arafeh: but some say that the meaning is, with the bad, or corrupt, persons; and that xwAlf is here a pl. [of xaAlifN,] like fawaArisu. (TA.) For ― -b3- xaAlifN is applied to a man [as meaning Bad, or corrupt]; and ↓xaAlifapN to a woman as meaning bad, or corrupt, and remaining behind in her abode: and the former to a slave as meaning bad, or corrupt: and also contrarious: and in this last sense it is likewise applied to a companion: and some of the grammarians say that there is no word of the measure faAEilN having its pl. of the measure fawaAEilu, except xaAlifN and haAlikN and faArisN: but see this last: (TA:) and ↓xil~iyfapN, also, has this last signification; (JK, TA;) or [rather] signifies very contrarious; (K;) as also ↓xaAlifapN; (JK;) and so ↓xilafonapN, and ↓xilafonaApN, (Lh, JK, K,) in each of which the n is augmentative, and each of which is applied to a man and to a woman and to a pl. number; (Lh, K;) but xilafonayaAtN has been mentioned as pl. [of xlfnAp], and as applied to males and females: (TA:) and xaAlifuwna is likewise used in this sense applied to a number of men. (JK.) ― -b4- Also, applied to a slave, [and app. to any man, but in this latter case I find it written xlf, which I believe to be a mistranscription,] One who has withdrawn from the people of his house: so says Lh. (TA.) ― -b5- Also Stupid; foolish; or having little, or no, intellect or understanding; as also ↓xaAlifapN, (K, TA,) but in an intensive sense, and also applied to a woman; (TA;) and ↓A^axolafu, (JK, K,) of which the fem. is xalofaA='u; (JK, TA;) and ↓xulofufN, (K,) or ↓xulofafN, (L,) or both, (JK,) likewise applied to a woman, as also ↓xulofufapN, (K,) or ↓xulofafapN: (JK:) or, as some say, xaAlifN signifies one in whom is no good: and, as also ↓xaAlifapN, one who has not what suffices: or who often breaks his promises: (TA:) or both of these mean one who has not what suffices, and in whom is no good: or very contrarious. (JM.) One says that a man is A^aholi bayotihi ↓xaAlifapu and xaAlifu, Ahl byth, meaning The one in whom is no good, of the people of his house: (S, K:) and the ungenerous: (K:) or the stupid, or foolish: or the bad, or corrupt, and the evil: and it is [said to be] tropical. (TA.) And ↓qawomN xawaAlifN Persons in whom is no good. (JK.) ― -b6- And, [app. because he leaves his family behind him,] A drawer of water; (S, TA;) as also ↓musotaxolifN [q. v.]: both mentioned in the K; but Als~aq~aA='u is there erroneously put for AlmusotaqiY. 1 xaloqN xlq xlqp
signifies The act of measuring; or determining the measure, proportion, or the like, of a thing; and the making a thing by measure, or according to the measure of another thing; or proportioning a thing to another thing; syn. taqodiyrN: (S, Msb, K, TA, and Bd in ii. 19:) this is the primary meaning. (Msb, TA, and Bd ubi suprà.) You say, xalaqa AlA^adiymi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
xaluqa
, (S, TA,) inf. n. xaloqN (JK, S, Msb, K) and xaloqapN, (K,) He measured, or proportioned, (qad~ara,) the hide, and sewed it: (K:) or he measured, or proportioned, (qd~r,) the hide, (JK, S, Msb, K,) limaA yuriydu [for, or to, that which he desired to make of it], (JK, * TA,) or lils~iqaA='i [for, or to, the skin for water or milk that he desired to make], (Msb,) before cutting it; (S, K, TA;) he measured it (qaAsahu) to cut from it a water-bag, or a water-skin, or a boot: (TA:) and in like manner, xalaqa Aln~iTaEa he measured, &c., the nTE [q. v.]: when one cuts it, one says, faraAhu. (K.) And xalaqa Aln~aEola He determined the measure of the sandal, or proportioned it; (qad~arahaA;) and made it by measure. (Ksh and Bd in ii. 19.) Hence the saying of Zuheyr, (S,) praising Herim Ibn-Sinán, (TA,)
walaA^anota taforiY maA xalaqota wabaEo
Du Alqawomi yaxoluqu vum~a laA yaforiY
In the preceding quotation, the final character of the first line and initial character of the second are missing in the original text. [(assumed tropical:) And thou indeed cuttest what thou hast measured; but some of the people measure, then will not cut]: (S, TA:) i. e., when thou determinest upon a thing thou executest it; but others determine upon that which they do not execute. (TA.) And El-Hajjáj said, maA xalaqotu A_il~aA qarayotu waEadotu A_il~aA wafayotu [(assumed tropical:) I have not measured unless I have afterwards cut, and I have not promised unless I have afterwards performed]. (S.) A^axoluqu lakumo mina AlT~iyni kahayoy^api AlT~ayori, in the Kur iii. 43, means I will form for you, (Jel,) or I will make according to its proper measure (A^uqad~iru) for you, (Ksh, Bd,) and will form, (Bd,) of clay, a thing like the form of the bird, or of birds. (Ksh, Bd, Jel.) ― -b2- [Hence,] it signifies also The bringing a thing into existence according to a certain measure, or proportion, and so as to make it equal [to another thing], or uniform [therewith]: (Ksh and Bd in ii. 19:) or the originating, or producing, [a thing] after a pattern, or model, which one has devised, not after the similitude of anything preexisting: this is another meaning which it has in the [classical] language of the Arabs. (TA.) As the act of God, it signifies The originating, or bringing into being or existence, anything, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing: (TA:) [and the creating a thing; and thus it is generally best rendered; as meaning the bringing into existence from a state of non-existence: for] xalaqa A@ll~`hu Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. xaloqN, means God brought the thing into existence (Mgh, * TA) after it had not been: (TA:) [or xaloqN, as the act of God, signifies the creating out of nothing: for it is said that] A^uEobuduwA rab~akumu A@l~a*iY xalaqakumo, in the Kur ii. 19, means [Serve ye your Lord] who brought you into existence when ye were nothing. (Jel. [But in other passages of the Kur (vi. 2 &c.) it is said that God created (xalaqa) mankind of clay.]) Accord. to the A, xalaqa A@ll~`hu Alxaloqa is a tropical phrase, meaning (tropical:) God brought into existence the creation, or created beings, or mankind, according to a predetermination (taqodiyr) required by wisdom. (TA.) You say, h`*ihi xaliyqatuhu Al~atiY xuliqa EalayohaA and xuliqahaA and Al~atiY xuliqa: see xuluqN. (Lh.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] xalaqa, (S, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. xaloqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He fabricated speech, or a saying or sentence, &c.: (K, * TA:) (tropical:) he forged (S, Msb, K, TA) a saying, (Msb,) or a lie, or a falsehood; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓Axtlq (S, Msb, K) and ↓txl~q. (S, K.) The Arabs say, Had~avanaA fulaAnN biA^aHaAdiyvi Alxaloqi (tropical:) Such a one related to us fictitious tales or stories, such as are deemed pretty, or such as are told by night [for entertainment]. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xxvi. 137], accord. to one reading, A_ino h`*aA A_il~aA xaloqu AlA^aw~aliyna, meaning (tropical:) This is nought but the lying, and forging, of the ancients. (TA.) And in the same [xxxviii. 6], ↓A_ino h`*aA A_il~aA A@xotilaAqN (tropical:) This is nought but forging, and lying. (TA.) ― -b4- xalaqahu, (K,) inf. n. xaloqN, (TA,) also signifies He made it smooth; (K;) and so ↓xl~qhu; namely, an arrow, (S,) [and any other thing; for] of anything that has been made smooth one says, xul~iqa: (TA:) he made it equable, or even; namely, wood, or a stick; and so ↓xl~qhu, (K,) inf. n. taxoliyqN. inf. n. of xalaqa. (JK, S, Msb, K, &c.) You say rajulN taAm~u Alxaloqi [A man complete, or perfect, in respect of make, or proportion, &c.].
