(TA.) ― -b2- Alxaloqu is also used in the sense of ↓Almaxoluwqu [meaning What is created; the creature]: (TA, and Bd in xxiii. 17, &c.:) [and, collectively, the creation; as meaning the beings, or things, that are created;] all created things: (Bd ubi suprà, &c.:) and [particularly] mankind; as also ↓Alxliyqapu: (S, * K:) and mankind and the jinn, or genii, and others: (Jel in lv. 9, &c.:) and ↓Alxliyqapu and [its pl.] xalaAy^iqu signify the same: you say, humo xaliyqapu A@ll~`hi and also humo xalqu A@ll~`hi [They are the creatures of God]: Alxaloqu being originally an inf. n.: (S, TA:) and Lh mentions [an instance of its having a pl., in] the saying, laA waA@l~a*iY xalaqa Alxuluwqa maA faEalotu ka*aA, meaning [No, by Him who created] all creatures, [I did not such a thing.] (TA.) In the saying, falayugay~irun~a xaloqa A@ll~`hi, in the Kur [iv. 118, lit. And they shall alter the creature of God], some say that castration is meant: (TA: [and Bd includes, with this, other unnatural actions:]) or the meaning is, the religion of God; (Bd, Jel, TA;) accord. to El-Hasan and Mujáhid. (TA.) And laA tabodiyla lixaloqi A@ll~`hi, in the Kur [xxx. 29], means, accord. to Katádeh, [There shall be no changing, or altering,] of the religion of God. (TA.) ― -b3- xaloqN also signifies Anything made smooth. (TA.) [See also muxal~aqN.]

xuloqN xlq xlqp
: see xuluqN, in four places.

xalaqu xlq xlqp
inf. n. of xaliqa: as such, signifying The being smooth [&c.]. (JK, S. *) [As such also,] in a rock, Freedom from crack or fracture. (S, K.) ― -b2- [And, as such,] The being old, and worn out. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence, used as an epithet,] Old, and worn out: (S, Msb, K:) [and as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; meaning an old and worn-out garment or piece of cloth:] pl. xuloqaAnN (S, K) and A^axolaAqN. (S, * K, * TA.) And [as an epithet] it is masc. and fem.; (S, K;) because it is originally an inf. n., the inf. n. of A^axolaqu meaning “ smooth, ” (S,) [or rather of xaliqa meaning “ it was, or became, old, and worn out; ” although it has pls.; and] IB mentions an instance of its dual, xalaqaAni: (TA:) Ks says, We have not heard them say, xalaqapN in any instance: (Lh, TA:) Fr says that it is without p [as a fem. epithet] because it was originally used as a prefixed noun; for one said, A^aEoTiniY xalaqa jub~atika and xalaqa EimaAmatika [lit. meaning Give thou to me what is old, and worn out, of thy jb~p and of thy turban]; but Ez-Zejjájee says that this is nought. (TA.) You say vawobN xalaqN [An old and worn-out garment or piece of cloth], and miloHafapN xalaqN [an old and worn-out outer wrapping garment]: (S:) also rum~apN xalaqN [an old and worn-out piece of rope]: and daArN xalaqN [an old and decayed house]: and jisomN xalaqN [an old and wasted body]. (TA.) One says also vawobN A^axolaAqN, meaning A garment, or piece of cloth, altogether, or wholly, old and worn out; (Fr, S, K;) every portion of it being xalaq; (Fr;) like as they said buromapN A^aEo$aArN &c.: (S:) and in like manner, mulaA='apN A^axolaAqN. (IAar.) And Ks mentions the saying, A^aSobaHato viyaAbuhumo xuloqaAnFA wa xalaquhumo jududFA [Their garments became old, and worn out; and their old and worn-out garments became replaced by new]; with the sing. [in the latter clause] in the place of the pl. xuloqaAn: (TA:) or jududFA may be here put for jadiydFA. (L in art. jd.) In the phrase ↓miloHafapN xulayoqN [An outer wrapping garment that is a little, or somewhat, old, and worn out], the dim. is without p because it is [the dim. of] an epithet [applied without p to a fem. n.], and p is not affixed to the dims. of epithets [of this kind]: it is like nuSayufN dim. of naSafN an epithet applied to a woman. (S, K. * [See Lumsden's Arab. Gram. p. 623: but some of the grammarians consider these instances as anomalous.]) ― -b4- baAEahu biyEapa Alxalaqi, and bayoEa *iY Alxalaqi, the latter as used by a poet, [lit. He bought it, or sold it, (app. the former,) as one buys, or sells, the old and worn-out garment, like as we say “ dogcheap, ” and “ cheap as dirt ”], are phrases mentioned, but not explained, by IAar, who cites the following saying:
A^aboligo fazaArapa A^an~iY qado $arayotu lahaA
majoda AlHayaApi bisayofiY bayoEa *iY Alxalaqi
[app. meaning Tell thou Fezárah that I have purchased for them life-long glory (lit. the glory of life), with my sword, as cheaply, i. e as easily, as one purchases the old and worn-out garment]. (TA.) ― -b5- saHaAbapN xalaqapN: see the next paragraph.

xaliqN xlq xlqp
[part. n. of xaliqa]. ― -b2- [Hence,] sHaAbapN xaliqapN A cloud in which is a sign, or trace, of rain; as also ↓xaliyqapN: (S, K:) or a cloud giving hope of rain; as also ↓xaloqaA='u; (JK;) both are said by IAar to signify the same: (TA:) and ↓xalaqapN [alone, as a subst., or probably saHaAbapN xalaqapN,] a cloud that is equable, or uniform, giving hope of rain. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K.)

xuluqN xlq xlqp
(S, Msb, K) and ↓xuloqN (S, K) A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; syn. sajiy~apN, (S, Msb, K, TA,) and TaboEN; (K, TA;) of which one is created: (TA:) and ↓xiloqapN signifies [the same; i. e.] the fiTorapN [or nature, &c.,] (S, Msb, K, TA) of which a man is created; (TA;) like [xuluqN and] ↓xuloqN: (K, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, xaloq:]) and ↓xaliyqapN [also] signifies [the same; i. e.] the TabiyEap [or nature, &c.,] (S, K, TA) with which a man is created: (TA:) the proper signification of xuluqN is [the moral character; or] the fashion of the inner man; i. e. his mind, or soul, and its peculiar qualities and attributes; like as xaloqN signifies the “ fashion of the outer man, and its [peculiar] qualities and attributes: ” it signifies also custom or habit [as being a second nature]: (TA:) and, as also ↓xuloqN, [which is merely a contraction thereof, and therefore identical with it in all its senses,] manliness; syn. muruwo'apN: and religion: (IAar, K:) the pl. is A^axolaAqN only: (TA:) [this is often used as signifying morals: and ethics:] and the pl. of ↓xaliyqapN in the sense explained above [said in Har p. 193 to be that of xuluqN] is xalaAy^iqN. (S.) It is said in a trad., layosa $aYo'N fiY AlmiyzaAni A^avoqala mino Husoni Alxuluqi [Nothing is heavier in the balance in which good and evil will be weighed than goodness of the moral character, &c.] (TA.) And one says, EalayohaA ↓Al~atiY xuliqa ↓h`*ihi xaliyqatuhu and ↓xuliqahaA and ↓Al~atiY xuliqa This is his nature, &c., of which he was created. (Lh.) And ↓A_in~ahu lakariymu Alxaliyqapi Verily he is generous in respect of nature, &c. (AZ.) And SaAra *`lika lahu xuluqFA That became to him [a second nature, a habit, or] a thing to which he was habituated. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxvi. 137], A_ino h`*aA A_il~aA xuluqu AlA^aw~aliyna This is nought but a custom of the ancients. (TA.) And in the same [lxviii. 4], wa A_in~aka laEalaY xuluqK EaZiymK And verily thou art of a great religion. (Jel, TA.) And in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, kaAna xuluquhu AlqaroA=na, meaning That whereto he clung was the Kur-án, with its rules of discipline and its command and its prohibitions, and the excellences and beauties and gracious things comprised in it. (TA.) ― -b2- nawomapu Alxulqi [i. e. Alxuluqi or ↓Alxuloqi] The sleep of midday, which was prescribed by the Prophet. (Har p. 223. [See also HumoqN and xuroqN.])

xuloqapN xlq xlqh xlqp
Smoothness; (K, TA;) as also ↓xuluwqapN and ↓xalaAqapN: (K:) but the second of these three, correctly speaking, [as also the third, accord. to analogy, and perhaps the first also,] is an inf. n. of xaluqa. (TA.)

xiloqapN xlq xlqh xlqp
[primarily signifies A mode, or manner, of xaloq, generally as meaning creation; a particular make: and hence,] constitution; syn. tarokiybN: (Mgh:) [and particularly the natural constitution of an animated being, as created in the womb of the mother; also termed fiTorapN:] see also xuluqN. You say rajulN Hasanu Alxiloqapi [A man goodly, or beautiful, in respect of make]. (A, TA.) fiY masolakK huwa xiloqapN means fiY TariyqK A^aSoliY~K ↓xiloqiY~K [In a way, or road, that is natural, and original]. (Mgh.)

xalaqapN xlq xlqh xlqp
: see xaliqN.

xiloqiY~N xlq xlqY xlqp xlqy xlqyy
Natural; not accidental: [constitutional: of, or relating to, or belonging to, the natural constitution of an animated being, as created in the womb of the mother:] rel. n. of xiloqapN. (Msb.) You say EayobN xiloqiY~N A natural fault or imperfection &c. (Msb.) And SifapN xiloqiy~apN [A natural quality]; opposed to A@xotiyaAriy~apN. (Msb in art. mdH.) See also xiloqapN.

xalaqiY~N xlq xlqY xlqp xlqy xlqyy
One who wears old and worn-out clothes. (TA.)

xuloqaAniY~N xlq xlqAn xlqAnY xlqAny
A seller of old and worn-out clothes. (TA.)

xalaAqN xlAq
A share, or portion: (JK, S, Msb:) and a good, just, or righteous, share or portion: (JK:) or a full, a complete, or an abundant, share or portion of good, (K, TA,) and of goodness, or righteousness: (TA:) and religion: or a share, or portion, thereof. (TA.) One says, laA xalaAqa lahu fiY AlA=xirapi There is no share, or portion, [of good] for him in the final state of existence. (S. [See the Kur iii. 71, &c.]) And laA xalaAqa lahu He has no desire for good, nor righteousness in religion. (TA.)

xilaAqN xlAq
: see the next paragraph.

xaluwqN xlwq
A certain species of perfume; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) also termed ↓xilaAqN; (Lh, Msb, K;) accord. to some of the lawyers, (Msb,) fluid, (Mgh, Msb,) but of thick consistence; (L, voce naDoxN;) and in which is a yellowness: (Mgh, Msb:) it is composed of saffron and other things; and redness and yellowness are predominant in it: it is forbidden [to men], because it is of the perfumes of women, who use it more than do men. (TA.)

xaliyqN xlyq
, applied to a man, (S, TA,) Perfect, or complete, in make; (TA;) as also ↓muxotalaqN: (Ham p. 561:) or perfect, or complete, in make, and just in proportion; (S, TA;) and so ↓ the latter; (S, K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, muxotaliq; in the TA expressly said to be of the pass. form;]) fem. of the former with p: (TA:) or ↓ both signify goodly, or beautiful, in make: or the former is not applied to a man; but ↓ each, with p, signifies a woman having [a goodly] body and make: (TA, in which this signification is said to be tropical:) and xaliyqN and xaliyqapN are alike, (JK, TA,) accord. to Lh, (TA,) in this last sense: (JK:) or the former of these two may be pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of the latter, like as $aEiyrN is of $aEiyrapN: (TA:) and ↓muxotalaqN signifies anything just in proportion: (IF, TA:) ↓muxal~aqN, also, signifies perfect, or complete, in make; applied to a camel (jml): (TA:) [or jml, here may be a mistranscription for Hamol; for] ↓muDogapN muxal~aqapN signifies [a fœtus when it has become like a lump of flesh] perfect, or complete, in make; (Fr, S, K;) so in the Kur xxii. 5; (Fr, TA;) or of which the make has become apparent. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- Also Adapted or disposed [by nature], apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, competent, or worthy; (KL, PS;) syn. jadiyrN (S, K) and HariY~N (TA) [and HaqiyqN &c.: pl. xulaqaA='u, and Freytag adds xuluqN]. You say, fulaAnN xaliyqN lika*aA, i. e. jadiyrN bihi [Such a one is adapted or disposed by nature, &c., for such a thing]; as though he were one of those in whom that was reckoned to be, and in whom the symptoms, signs, or tokens, thereof were seen. (S.) [And huwa xaliyqN liloxayori He is adapted or disposed by nature to good; i. e., to be, or to do, or to effect, or to produce, what is good.] And A_in~ahu laxaliyqN A^ano yafoEala *`lika and biA^ano yfEl *lk and liA^ano yfEl *lk and mno A^ano yfEl *lk [Verily he is adapted or disposed &c. for doing that; or worthy to do it]: so says Lh: and he adds that the Arabs say, yaA xaliyqu bi*`lika, using the nom. case; and yaA xaliyqFA bi*`lika, using the accus. case; [the latter being the usual form; both meaning O thou who art adapted or disposed &c. for that;] but ISd says, I know not the reason of this. (TA.) And li*aAka ↓h`*aA maxolaqapN, i. e. majodarapN lahu [This is one that is adapted or disposed &c. for that]: (S, K: *) and laka ↓h`*aA AlA^amoru maxolaqapN [This affair, or thing, is one that is adapted &c. for thee]: and mino *`lika ↓A_in~ahu maxolaqapN [Verily it is adapted &c. for that]: like majodarapN and maHoraApN and maqomanapN: and in like manner one says of two, and of more than two, and of a feminine: so says Lh. (TA.) [ ↓maxolaqapN properly signifies A place, and hence a thing, an affair, and a person, adapted or disposed &c.: it is of the same class as maEosaApN and maZin~apN and may^in~apN.] xaliyqN also signifies Habituated, or accustomed. (PS, TA. *) And one says, A_in~ahu laxaliyqN, i. e. laHariY~N, meaning Verily it is probable; or likely to happen or be, or to have happened or been. (TA.) And huwa xaliyqN lahu He, or it, is like to him, or it. (JK, TA.) ― -b3- saHaAbapN xaliyqapN: see xaliqN. ― -b4- [See also xaliyqapN, which, in several senses, is a fem. epithet used as a subst.]

xulayoqN xlyq
: see xalaqN (of which it is the dim.), in the latter half of the paragraph.

xalaAqapN xlAq xlAqh xlAqp
: see xuloqapN.

xuluwqapN xlwq xlwqh xlwqp
: see xuloqapN.

xaliyqapN xlyq xlyqh xlyqp
: see xaloqN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The beasts, or brutes. (En-Nadr, K.) The saying, respecting the xawaArij [a sect of heretics, or schismatics], humo $ar~u Alxaloqi wa AlxaliyqapN is explained by En-Nadr as meaning [They are the worst of mankind and] of the beasts, or brutes. (TA.) ― -b3- And A well (biy^orN) just dug: (AA, K:) or a well in which is no water: or a hollow, cavity, pit, or hole, formed by nature in the ground: or a small hollow or cavity, in a mountain, in which water remains and stagnates: accord. to IAar, xlq [app. xuluqN, pl. of xaliyqapN, like as mudunN and SuHufN are pls. of madiynapN and SaHiyfapN,] signifies wells recently dug. (TA.) ― -b4- And Land (A^aroDN) that is dug. (TA.) ― -b5- See also xuluqN, in four places.

xulayoqaA='u xlyqA='
[dim. of xaloqaA='u fem. of A^axolaqu]: see A^axolaqu, in three places.

xalaAy^iqu *
[pl. of xaliyqapN]. ＝ -A2- AlxalaAy^iqu i. q. HamaAy^iru AlmaA='i, i. e. Four large and smooth masses of stone at the head of the well, upon which the drawer of the water stands. (TA.) Accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, HawoDN baAdiY AlxalaAy^iqi means [A watering-trough of which] the [stones termed] naSaAy^ib [appear]. (JK, TA. [See naSiybapN.])

xul~aqN xlq xlqp
: see A^axolaqu.

xal~aAqN xlAq
: see the next paragraph.

xaAliqN xAlq
[act. part. n. of xalaqa:] A worker in leather and the like; (K, TA;) because he measures first, and then cuts. (TA.) To xaAliqaAt, meaning Women working in leather, as engaged in dividing a hide (A^adiym), El-Kumeyt likens genealogists. (TA.) ― -b2- AlxaAliqu, as an epithet applied to God, (K, Msb, TA,) properly, He who brings into existence according to the proper measure, or proportion, or adaptation; (TA;) [and hence, the Creator; or] the Originator, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing: (K:) or He who hath brought into existence all things after they had not been in existence: (Az, TA:) and ↓Alxal~aAqu signifies the same; (Msb, * TA;) [i. e. the Creator of all things; or, as an intensive epithet, the Great Creator;] or the Creator of many creatures: (Ksh and Bd and Jel, in xxxvi. 81:) Az says that this epithet, with the article Al, may not be applied to any but God. (Msb.) Accord. to IAmb, tabaAraka A@ll~`hu A^aHosanu AlxaAliqiyna means AHsn Almuqad~ariyna [i. e. Blessed be God, the Best of those who make things according to their proper measures, or proportions, or adaptations]. (TA.)

xawaAliqu xwAlq
[a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Smooth mountains: so in the saying of Lebeed,
wa AlA^aroDu taHotahumo mihaAdFA raAsiyFA
vabatato xawaAliquhaA biSum~i Aljanodala
[And the earth beneath them a firm expanse; its smooth mountains being rendered fast by hard and solid stones]. (K, TA. [In the CK, bDam~i is erroneously put for biSum~i.])

A^axolaqu *
Smooth: (JK, K:) smooth and solid; (S, K, TA;) applied in this sense to anything: (TA:) smooth and firm: (JK:) fem. xaloqaA='u. (JK, S, K.) You say HajarN A^axolaqu Stone that is smooth (K, TA) and solid, upon which nothing makes an impression. (TA.) And SaxorapN xaloqaA='u A rock, or great mass of stone, smooth (K, TA) and solid: (TA:) or free from crack and fracture. (S, K, TA.) And firosinN xaloqaA='u A camel's foot in which is no crack. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) And haDobapN xaloqaA='u [A hill, or the like,] destitute of herbage or vegetation. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Poor; syn. faqiyrN. (K.) You say rajulN A^axolaqu mina AlmaAli (assumed tropical:) A man destitute of property. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., layosa Alfaqiyra faqiyru AlmaAli A_in~amaA Alfaqiyru AlA^axolaqu Alkasobi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The poor in respect of property is not the poor the poor is only]
he who has no good deeds for which he will be rewarded in the world to come. (TA, in two places.) ― -b3- AlA^axolaqu also signifies The exterior of a horse's hoof. (JK.) ― -b4- And xaloqaA='u, (JK, S, K,) applied to a woman, (JK, S,) Impervia coëunti; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓xul~aqN. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b5- See also xaliqN. ― -b6- And AlxaloqaA='u [used as a subst.] The sky; because of its smoothness and evenness. (TA.) ― -b7- And The side of a camel &c. (K.) One says also, Darabotu xaloqaA='a janobihi (K, TA [in the CK ElY xaloqaA'a janobihi]) I struck the outer part of his side. (TA.) ― -b8- And The interior (Lth, K, TA) and smooth part (Lth, TA,) of the gaAr, (K,) i. e., of [the upper part of the interior of the mouth, or] what is termed AlgaAru AlA^aEolaY; (Lth, TA;) as also ↓AlxulayoqaA='u [the dim. of AlxaloqaA='u]: (Lth, K, TA:) or both signify what appears of the gAr: and the dim. form is that which is predominant in this case. (TA.) ― -b9- And The part of the forehead that is even (JK, K, TA) and smooth; (TA;) as also ↓AlxulayoqaA='u. (JK, K, TA.) One says, suHibuwA EalaY xaloqaAwaAti jibaAhihimo [They were dragged along upon the even and smooth parts of their foreheads]. (TA [in which this is said to be tropical]) ― -b10- Alfarasi ↓xulayoqaA='u That [part] of the horse which is like the Eironiyn [or upper part of the nose] of man; (S, K;) the part where the forehead of the horse meets the narrow portion of the bone of the nose: AO says that the xulayoqaAwaAni in the face of the horse are [the two parts] where his forehead meets the bone of his nose, on the right and left of the xulayoqaA=', sloping towards the eye; and the xulayoqaA=' is [the part] between the eyes; and some call it the xaloqaA='. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A_in~a A^axolaqa bika A^ano tafoEala ka*aA is a phrase mentioned by Ks, as meaning Verily the most apt, meet, suitable, fit, or proper, thing for thee to do is such a thing. (TA.)

maxolaqapN mxlqh mxlqp
: see xaliyqN, in four places, in the latter half of the paragraph.

muxal~aqN mxlq
: see xaliyqN, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also, applied to an arrow, Made smooth (S, K, TA) and even. (TA.) [See also xaloqN, last signification; and muxotalaqN.]

maxoluwqN mxlwq
[pass. part. n. of xalaqa. When used as a subst., signifying A creature, or created thing, its pl. is maxoluwqaAtN]. See xaloqN. ― -b2- qaSiydapN maxoluwqapN (tropical:) [An ode that is forged; or] ascribed to a person not its author. (S, K, * TA.)

muxotalaqN mxtlq
: see xaliyqN, first sentence, in five places. ― -b2- Also Made smooth. (TA.) [See also muxal~aqN.] ― -b3- And Generous in [nature, or] natural dispositions. (Ham p. 561.) ― -b4- muxotalaqN lilomuloki, in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, means Created of a nature fitting for dominion: (S, TA:) and so liloA^aSoHaAbi [for companions]; as in a verse of Ibn-Ahmar. (TA.)

muxolawoliqN mxlwlq
Very smooth; its measure being one of those that denote intensiveness. (Ham p. 358.)

xalanojN xlnj
a Persian word, arabicized, (S,) A kind of tree, (S, K,) of the wood of which vessels are made: (TA:) or any [bowl of the kinds called] jafonap and SaHofap, or other vessel, made of wood having variegated streaks: (L:) pl. xalaAniju. (S, K.) The word is mentioned [in the S and K in art. xlj; but] in the L and some other lexicons in a separate art., because all the letters of a word which is not Arabic are regarded as radical. (MF.)

1 xalaA xl xlA
, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaxoluw, (S, Msb,) inf. n. xuluw~N, (S, Msb, K,) or xalaA='N, (Msb,) or both, (K,) said of a place, (K,) of a place of alighting or abode, (Msb,) and of a thing, (S, TA,) It was, or became, empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; (K, TA;) had none, and nothing, in it; (TA;) as also ↓AxlY, (Msb, K,) and ↓AstxlY, (K.) [xalaA AlmakaAnu mina Aln~aAsu wa AlmaA='i waAlkalaA^ means The place was, or became, devoid, or destitute, of human beings and water and herbage or pasturage; without human beings &c.] Of a place of alighting or abode, you say, xalaA mino A^aholihi and ↓AxlY [It was, or became, devoid, or destitute, of its occupants]. (Msb.) And of a vessel, xalaA mim~aA fiyhi It was, or became, empty of what was in it. (Mgh.) And xalawotu Eani AlT~aEaAmi (S) I became empty, in the belly, of food; (PS;) and Eanohu ↓A^axolayotu signifies the same. (S.) And xalaA min AlEayobi, (Msb,) or Eani AlA^amori, and minohu, (Kudot;,) inf. n. xuluw~N, He was, or became, free (Msb, K) from fault, (Msb,) or from the thing, or affair: (K:) and, accord. to IAar, xlA alone signifies he was, or became, free from a fault, or the like, of which he was accused, or suspected. (TA.) And xalato Eano maAniEi Aln~ikaAHi, inf. n. xuluw~N, is said of a woman [as meaning She was, or became, free from any obstacle to marriage]. (Msb.) Accord. to the K, xalaA makaAnuhu [lit. His place became vacant] means (tropical:) he died: but accord. to IAar, xalaA alone has this signification [from the same verb signifying maDaY. explained below]: and if you add mkAnh, you say xal~aY, with teshdeed; which see below. (TA.) You say also, xalaA laka Al$~aYo'u and ↓AxlY, both signifying the same, (AA, S, TA,) i. q. faraga [i. e. The thing was, or became, vacant, or unoccupied, for thee: (see an ex. of the former verb in a saying of Tarafeh cited voce jaw~N:) and hence, the thing was, or became, exclusively for thee]. (TA.) AA cites as an ex. the saying of Maan Ibn-Ows,
A^aEaA*ilu halo yaA^otiY AlqabaAy^ila HaZ~uhaA
lanA Almawotu waHodanaA ↓mina Almawoti A^amo A^axolaY
[O censurer, does their share of death come to the tribes in common, or is death exclusively for us alone?]. (S, TA.) See also the paragraph, below, commencing with xalaA as a word denoting exception. ― -b2- [Hence,] xalaA and ↓AxlY, (S, K,) said of a man, (TA,) or the same two verbs followed by binafosihi, said of a man, (Msb,) both signify the same; (S;) He was, or became, [without any companion, i. e.] alone, by himself; (Msb;) or he became (waqaEa [q. v.]) in a vacant place, in which he was not pressed against, or straitened. (K.) And xalaA bihi, (S, Msb, K,) and A_ilayohi, (S, K,) and maEahu, (K,) inf. n. xalowapN (S, Msb, K) and xalaA='N (S, K) and xalowN, (K, TA,) or xuluw~N, (CK,) or the first of these, i. e. xalowapN, is a simple subst., and the second and third are the inf. ns.; (TA;) and bh ↓AxlY, (Lh, K,) and ↓AxlAhu, (S, K,) and bihi ↓AstxlY; (K; [the last omitted in the CK;]) He was, or became, alone with him; (Msb;) he was, or became, in company with him, or he met him, or had a meeting or an interview with him, in a vacant place, or a place unoccupied [by others, i. e., in a private place]. (S, K.) In the saying in the Kur [ii. 13], waA_i*aA xalawoA A_ilaY $ayaATiynihimo, it is said that A_ilaY is used in the sense of maEa, [so that the meaning is And when they are alone with their devils,] as in that other saying in the Kur [iii. 45 and lxi. 14], mano A^anoSaAriY A_ilaY A@ll~`hu. (S.) A man says to another man, Auxolu maEiY Hat~aY A^ukal~imaka, i. e. Be [or come] thou alone with me [that I may speak to thee in private]. (TA.) And one says, xalaA bizawojatihi, inf. n. xalowapN, [but see what is said of this noun above,] He was, or became, alone with his wife: but [properly speaking, according to the law,] the term xalowapN [or xalowapN SaHiyHapN, in this case,] is not used unless it be with the enjoyment of AlmufaAxa*ap, [see 3 in art. fx*,] and then it has an effect upon the circumstances of the marriage [by its rendering obligatory the payment of the dowry, though consummation has not taken place]: if with consummation, the act is termed duxuwlN. (Msb.) You say also, ↓A^axoli A^amoraka and biA^amorika Be thou alone in thine affair, with none to take part with thee in it; confine thyself to it exclusively of other things. (TA. [See also 5.]) And A_ilayoka ↓A^axoli Keep thou to thine affair, and be alone in it, with none to take part with thee therein. (JK.) And AlbukaA='u ↓AstxlY [app. for biAlbukaA='i] He was, or became, alone in weeping, with none to participate with him in it. (TA.) [And xalaA liloA^amori: see 5.] And xalaAEalaY baEoDi AlT~aEaAmi He restricted himself to a portion of the food. (K.) Temeem say, xalaA fulaAnN EalaY All~abani wa All~aHomi (JK, * TA) i. e. Such a one fed upon milk and flesh-meat alone; (JK;) or such a one ate not, nor mixed, anything with milk and flesh-meat: and Kináneh and Keys say ↓A^axolaY. (Lh, JK, * TA.) [And it seems to be indicated in the T that xalawoA signifies They selected a she-camel for a xaliy~ap, q. v.: or i. q. taxal~awoA bixalay~ipK: see 5.] ― -b3- xalaA also ssignifies He devoted himself to religious services or exercises [app. in solitude, or seclusion, or in a xalowap; or because one generally does so in solitude; or because the doing so involves abstraction from other affairs]. (TA. [See also 5; and see musotaxolK.]) ― -b4- And xalaA bihi
[sometimes] signifies (tropical:) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him: (Lh, S, Z, K, TA:) said by Az to be strange, and not known by him or any other authority than that of Lh: (TA:) from the saying, xalaA fulaAnN biEiroDi fulaAnK yaEobavu bihi [Such a one occupied himself alone with the honour, or reputation, of such a one, making sport with it]. (Ksh in ii. 13.) And i. q. xaAdaEahu (tropical:) [He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; &c.: or he strove to do so]: (TA:) as also ↓xAlAhu, (JK, and K in art. xlY,) inf. n. muxaAlaApN. (JK.) ― -b5- And xalaA Ealayohi He relied upon him; [as though he betook himself to him alone;] syn. AiEotamada. (TA.) ― -b6- And xalaA, (JK, K,) inf. n. xuluw~N, (TA,) or xalaA='N, (JK,) said of a man (JK) and of a thing, (JK, TA,) He, or it, went, went away, or passed away. (JK, K.) Hence, (TA,) wa A_ino mino A^um~apKA_il~aA xalaA fiyhaA na*iyrN, in the Kur [xxxv. 22], means [And there is not any people but a warner] hath gone, and hath been sent, among them. (S, TA.) [Hence also xalaA explained above as meaning He died.] And xalaA minohaA [an elliptical phrase] She became old; the greater part of her life passed. (TA from a trad.) And xalaAka *am~N [for xalaA Eanoka *am~N] Blame passed away from thee; or may blame pass away from thee. (Ksh and Bd in ii. 13.) You say, AifoEalo ka*aA wa xalaAka *am~N Do thou such a thing, and thou wilt have an excuse; [i. e.] blame will fall from thee. (S. [See art. *m.]) And xalaAhu AlHuzonu Grief passed away from him, and quitted him. (Har p. 590, from the Tekmileh.) ― -b7- xalaA Eani Al$~aYo'i: see 2. ＝ -A2- xalaA [or xalaY, probably belonging to art. xlY, though mentioned in the present art.,] He ate what was good, sweet, or pleasant. (TA.)

2 xal~aY xl xlY xly
, inf. n. taxoliyapN, [He left a place, &c., empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied.] Hence, xl~Y makaAnahu [He left his place vacant;] meaning (tropical:) he died: (TA, and so in Ham p. 478:) a meaning assigned in the K to ↓xalaA makaAnuhu, and by IAar to xalaA alone, without tesh-deed; but when mkAnh is added, it is with teshdeed. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He went his way. (Ham p. 379.) And xl~Y sabiylahu [He left his way free, or open, to him]. (S, TA.) And xl~Y bayonahumaA [He left the way, or space, free between them two; meaning he left them two free, each to do to the other as he pleased]. (TA.) [And xl~Y bayonahu wabayona ka*aA He left him free access to such a thing.] And xl~Y bayonahu wa bayona nafosihi He left him, or it, alone; syn. A^ahomalahu. (S and O and K in art. hml.) [And xl~Ahu wafulaAnFA He left him to do as he pleased with such a one.] And xl~Y AlA^amora He left, left alone, or let alone, the thing, or affair; as also ↓txl~Y minohu and Eanohu; and ↓xAlAhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. xilaA='N. (TA.) For taxoliyapN signifies The leaving, and making a thing to be alone. (Har p. 123.) [xl~Ahu and xl~Y Eanohu both signify He left, or left alone, it, or him.] It is said in a trad., xl~Y Eanohumo A^arobaEiyna EaAmFA He (God) left them, or left them alone, and turned from them, forty years. (TA.) [And xl~Ahu lika*aA He made him, or left him, vacant, unoccupied, unemployed, or at leisure, for such a thing.] ― -b2- taxoliyapN also signifies The act of loosing; contr. of $ad~N. (IAar, K in art. AbD.) [Hence,] xl~Y Eani Al$~aYo'i, (JK, S, * TA,) in the K ↓xalaA, without teshdeed, but this requires consideration, (TA,) He dismissed, loosed, let loose, or let go, the thing. (JK, K, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence xl~Ahu meaning He left it, permitted it, or allowed it: see the pass. part. n., below.] ＝ -A2- xul~iyato, said of a she-camel such as is termed xaliy~ap; and hence, of a cooking-pot: see 1 in art. xlY.

3 xAlAhu xAl xAlAh xAlAp
He left, forsook, relinquished, abandoned, deserted, or quitted, him, being left, &c., by him; namely, another man; syn. taArakahu; (S;) inf. n. muxaAlaApN, syn. with muwaAdaEapN, (JK,) [and xilaA='N also: and he was, or became, distant, remote, far off, aloof, or apart, from him; for] xilaA='N is syn. with mubaAEadapN and mujaAnabapN (TA in art. xlA^) and furoqapN. (TA in the present art.) And xAlY AlA^amora, inf. n. xilaA='N: see 2. ― -b2- [Also He went, or came, out, or forth, to him, in the field; for] muxaAlaApN is also syn. with mubaArazapN. (Sh, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (Lth, JK, K,) inf. n. muxaAlaApN, (Lth, JK,) He wrestled with him, each endeavouring to throw down the other; contended with him in wrestling: (Lth, JK, K: mentioned in the K in art. xlY:) because, when one does so, he is alone with the other, so that neither of them seeks aid from any other. (Az, TA.) And in like manner the word muxaAlaApN is used [app. as meaning The act of contending with another, by oneself,] in relation to any affair, or case. (Lth, JK, TA. [See its act. part. n., below.]) ― -b4- See also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.

4 A^axolawa
see 1, in eleven places. ＝ -A2- AxlY AlmakaAna, (S, K,) or Almanozila, (Msb,) He made the place, (K,) or the place of alighting or abode, (Msb,) empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied: (Msb, K:) or it signifies, (S, K,) or signifies also, (Msb,) he found it empty, &c. (S, Msb, K.) One says in praying for another that he may have a long life, laA A^axolaY A@ll~`hu makaAnaka [May God not make thy place vacant]. (TA.) ― -b2- AxlAhu maEahu [He made him, or found him, to be alone with him]. (K.)

5 txl~Y A^xl A^xlY txlY txly xl xlA xlY
He went forth into the field, or open country, to satisfy a want of nature. (TA.) And txl~Y fiY AlxalaA='i He went forth into the vacant tract, or into the privy, to satisfy a want of nature: or he satisfied a want of nature therein. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He was, or became, or made himself, vacant from occupation, or business; [unoccupied; unemployed; or at leisure;] syn. tafar~aga: (S:) or so txl~Y mina Al$~ugoli. (K in art. frg.) You say, txl~Y liloEibaAdapi He was, or became, or made himself, vacant for, or he confined himself exclusively to, the service of God. (TA.) [See also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph. In like manner, one says also, liloA^amori ↓xalaA He was, or became, or made himself, vacant for, or he confined himself exclusively to, the affair.] And taxal~awoA bixaliy~apK (S, K, TA) They confined themselves exclusively to a she-camel, or to she-camels, such as they termed xlyp, (K, TA,) yaHolubuwnahaA [milking only her, or them]. (S, TA.) And txl~Y xaliy~apF He took for himself a xly~p. (TA.) ― -b3- And txl~Y mina AlA^amori and Eanohu: see 2. ― -b4- And taxal~ati AlA_ibilu bilaA raAEK [The camels were left to themselves without a pastor]. (K in art. swE.)

10 A_isotaxolawa
see 1, in three places. [And see also musotaxolK.] ＝ -A2- AstxlAhu majolisahu He asked him to leave his sitting-place vacant, or unoccupied, for him. (S. [But found by me in only one copy of that work.]) ― -b2- AstxlY Almalika He asked the king to have a meeting, or an interview, with him in a vacant place, or a place unoccupied [by others, i. e., in a private place; he asked the king to grant him a private meeting or interview]. (K.)

xalaA xl xlA
as a word denoting exception, (S, Mughnee, K,) when it governs a gen. case, (S, Mughnee,) as when you say, jaAw^uwniY xalaA zayodK [They came to me, except Zeyd], is a particle, (S, Mughnee, K,) accord. to some of the grammarians, like HaA$aY; but accord. to some, a prefixed inf. n. (S.) ↓ It. also governs an accus. case, as a verb: (S, Mughnee:) so that you say, jaAw^uwniY xalaA zayodFA [meaning as above]; the agent of xlA being implied, (S, Mughnee, *) like that of HaA$aY [used as a verb]: it is as though you said, xalaA mano jaA='aniY mino zayodK [i. e. those who came to me were without Zeyd]: (S:) or correctly, accord. to IB, xalaA baEoDuhumo zayodFA [for mino zayodK, like as you say, xalaAka *am~N, for xalaA Eanoka *am~N]. (TA.) When you say maA xalaA, it is followed only by an accus., because mA xlA is equivalent to an inf. n.; (S, Mughnee;) so that when you say, jaAw^uwniY maA xalaA zayodFA [meaning as above], it is as if you said, jaAw^uwniY xuluw~a zayodK [or xuluw~FA zayodFA], i. e. xuluw~ahumo mino zayodK, (S,) which two phrases mean jaAw^uwniY xaAliyna mino zayodK [They came to me, they being without Zeyd]: (S, K:) [for] accord. to Seer, mAxlA occupies the place of a noun in the accus. as a denotative of state: but some say, as an adv. n. of time; so that, accord. to these, maA xalaA zayodFA means waqota xuluw~ihimo Eano zayodK [in the time of their being without Zeyd]. (Mughnee.) You say also, maA A^aradotu masaA='ataka xalaA A^an~iY waEaZotuka, meaning [I desired not to displease thee,] but I admonished thee (A_il~aA A^an~iY waEaZotuka). (JK, TA.)

xilowN xlw
, and its fem. (with p), and dual: see xaAlK, in seven places.

xalowapN xl xlY xlw xlwh xlwp
said by some to be an inf. n.: [see xalaA bihi &c. in the first paragraph of this art.:] by others said to be a simple subst.; (TA;) meaning Loneliness; solitude; lonesomeness; solitariness; desolateness; syn. waHo$apN. (S and K in art. wH$.) [Hence, app.,] rajulN saholu Alxalowapi [A man easy in private conference]. (Msb in art. sls. [See also a phrase in
the latter part of the next paragraph.]) ― -b2- Also An empty, a vacant, a void, or an unoccupied, place. (KL. [See also xalaA='N.]) [In the present day, it is often applied to A closet to which one retires for privacy; and particularly to a cell for religious retirement: and is vulgarly pronounced xilowap.] You say, AijotamaEa maEahu fiY xalowapK (S) or AjtmE bihi fY xlwp (K) [He had a meeting, or an interview, with him in a vacant place, or a place unoccupied by others, i. e., in a private place]. ＝ -A2- Also Each of the two sharp sides or edges of an arrow-head (AHn, JK, TA) or of a spear-head: (AHn, TA:) both together are called the xalowataAni: (AHn, JK, TA.)

xalaA='N xlA='
is primarily an inf. n. (MF, TA. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b2- [Then it is used as an epithet, syn. with xaAlK:] see xaAlK, in five places. ― -b3- Then it is used [as a subst.] in the sense of A vacant place [in a general sense]: (MF, TA:) or a place in which is nothing: (S, K:) [often applied in the present day to any open tract of country or desert:] and then, particularly, such as one takes for the purpose of satisfying a want of nature; (MF, TA;) i. q. mutawaD~aA^N, (S, Msb, K,) but not as meaning only a place for the performance of AlwuDuw', as might be imagined from this explanation: pl. A^axoliyapN. (MF, TA.) It is said in a prov., (S, Meyd,) xalaAw^uka A^aqonaY liHayaAy^ika, (S, Meyd, K,) [in Freytag's Arab. Prov., (i. 436,) biHayaA=yika,] i. e. [Thy place of retirement is] most preservative (A^alozamu) [of thy sense of shame, or modesty]; meaning it is most fit for thee to be alone in thine abode; (S, * Meyd;) for he who is so needs not to be careful for his shame, or modesty: it is used in blaming the mixing with others. (Meyd.) HuSira Ealayohi xalaAw^uhu [His place of retirement for satisfying a want of nature was straitened to him] is used as meaning he suffered suppression of the feces, or constipation of the bowels. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. HSr.) ＝ -A2- A_in~ahu laHoluw AlxalaA='i, (TA,) or [as written in a verse in which it occurs in the TA in the present art., and in art. xlY,] AlxalaA, (JK, TA,) [without ', but whether this be the right reading, or only required by poetic license, seems to be doubtful,] is a phrase mentioned by Th, (TA,) meaning Verily he is good in speech. (JK, TA. [If the former reading be right, the meaning may be similar to that of saholu Alxalowapi, mentioned above: if the latter only, or rather An~h lHlw AlxalaY, be right, it probably belongs to art. xlYK, and is tropical, from the herbage termed xalY; and this may also be the case if the former reading be right.])

xaliY~N xl xlY xly
; and its fem. xaliy~apN: see xaAlK, in twelve places. ― -b2- The fem. also signifies, applied to a she-camel, (S, Msb,) Loosed from the cord, or rope, with which her fore shank and her arm have been bound together, (S, Msb, K,) and left alone, or free, (S,) so that she pastures where she will. (Msb.) Hence, (Msb,) it is used by way of metonymy as meaning Divorced: (Lh, S, Msb, K:) one says to a woman, A^anoti xaliy~apN Thou art divorced; (Lh, S;) and thus a man used to say in the Time of Ignorance: (TA:) and one says, hiYa xaliy~apN She is divorced: (Msb:) and a woman is divorced thereby when divorce is meant. (Lh, TA.) Applied to a woman, it signifies also Free from any obstacle to marriage: pl. xaliy~aAtN. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also A she-camel that is made to affect, with another she-camel, one young one, so that both yield their milk to it, and to which the people of a tent, or house, confine themselves exclusively of the other for the purpose of milking her: (S:) or a she-camel that is chosen as the one more abundant in milk, when one has brought forth and her young one is drawn away (yujar~u) as soon as born, before she smells it, and the young one of another, that has brought forth before her, is brought near to her, and she affects it; the other is left to suckle the young one, and is termed basuwTN, pl. bsT [app. busoTN or busuTN]: (Az, TA:) or a she-camel that is left, or left alone, to be milked: (K:) or that affects a young one [not her own], or is destitute of her young one, (JK, M, K,) whether she incline to another's young one or do not, or that is destitute of her young one by death or slaughter, (M, TA,) and whose milk one causes to flow by means of the young one of another; but only by her affecting a young one, and not suckling it: (M, K: *) or that brings forth, when abundant in milk, and has her young one drawn (yujar~u) from beneath her, and another put beneath her, and is then left, or left alone, to be milked; (Lh, K;) this being done because of her generous quality: (Lh:) or a she-camel, or two she-camels, to which the people of a tent, or house, confine themselves exclusively, for milking, when two or three she-camels are made to affect one young one, and to yield their milk to it; the young one [afterwards] sucking from one of them only: (K, * TA:) or a she-camel that brings forth, and whose young one is drawn away (yujar~u) in order that her milk may continue for their use, she being made to yield her milk by means of the young one of another, which is then withdrawn from her, and she is milked: sometimes, also, they bring together three and four xalaAyaA [pl. of xaliy~apN] to one young camel: and the doing so is termed talas~unN: (IAar, TA:) in this case they take as a xly~p whichever of them they will. (ISh, TA.) [Applied to a she-camel in any of these senses, it seems to be an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; i. e., used without its having naAqapN prefixed to it.] ＝ -A2- See also the paragraph next following, in two places.

xaliy~apN xly xlyh xlyp
[as fem. of the epithet xaliY~N: see the next preceding paragraph, and the places there referred to in its first sentence. ＝ -A2- As a subst. it signifies] A great ship: (T, S, K:) or a ship that goes of itself, without its being made to do so by the sailor: (JK, K:) or one that is followed by a small boat: (K:) the first held by Az to be the right meaning: (TA:) pl. xalaAyaA. (JK, S.) ― -b2- Also, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and ↓xaliY~N, (JK, Msb, K,) The habitation (bayot) of bees, [whether it be a manufactured hive or a hollow in the trunk of a tree or in a rock,] in which they deposit their honey; (S;) the place in which bees deposit their honey: (Mgh:) or the thing in which bees deposit their honey, (K, TA,) not manufactured for them: (TA:) or a thing like the [kind of jar called] raAquwd, of clay, (K, TA,) made for bees: (TA:) or a certain thing for bees, well known, of clay or of wood: (Msb:) or, accord. to Lth, if made of clay, it is called kwArp, (Msb, TA,) i. e. [kuwaArapN and kuw~aArapN and kiwaArapN] with kesr: (Msb:) or a piece of wood hollowed out for honey to be deposited therein [by bees]: or the lower part of a tree that is called xazamapN, [n. un. of xazamN, q. v., hollowed out for that purpose,] resembling the [kind of jar called] raAquwd: (K:) or ↓xaliY~N signifies the part of the kuw~aArap which is the place of the honey: (JK:) pl. as above. (Msb, TA.)

xalaAwapu xlAwh xlAwp
: see the next paragraph.

xaAlK xAl xAly
Empty, vacant, void, devoid, destitute, or unoccupied; (Mgh, TA;) having none, and nothing, in it: (TA:) applied to a place, (Msb, TA,) as also ↓xaliY~N (TA) and ↓muxolK; (Msb;) and to a thing, as also ↓xaliY~N; (TA;) or a vessel. (Mgh.) You say also ↓makaAnN xalaA='N, [as well as xalaA='N alone,] meaning A place in which is none (K, TA) and nothing. (TA.) And wajadotu ↓Ald~aAra muxoliyapF, meaning xaAliyapF [i. e. I found the house empty, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Vacant, or free; from a thing or an affair; or devoid, or destitute, of a thing; (TA;) and so ↓xaliY~N and ↓xilowN; which last is the same as masc. and fem., though it has xilowapN also for fem., and A^axolaA='N for pl.; (K;) but properly, accord. to Lh, it has no dual form, nor pl., nor fem., though some give it such forms: (TA:) or ↓xaliY~N, which has a dual, [i. e. xaliy~aAni,] and pl., (S, Msb,) i. e. xaliy~uwna and A^axoliyaA='u, (K,) signifies free [from a thing]; or clear or quit [of a thing or person]; as also ↓xalaA='u, (S, Msb,) which, being [originally] an inf. n., has no dual nor pl. [nor fem.]; (S;) and ↓xilowN. (Msb.) You say, mino h`*aA ↓A^anota xaliY~N AlA^amori and xaAlK, i. e. Thou art free from this thing, or affair. (TA.) And mina Alham~i ↓A^anaA xaliY~N, meaning xaAlK [i. e. I am free from anxiety]. (Mgh.) And mino ka*aA ↓A^anaA xilowN, meaning xaAlK [i. e. I am free from such a thing]: (S:) and humaA xilowN, and humo xilowN; and some say, humaA xilowaAni, and humo A^axolaA='N, which is not proper. (T, TA.) And mino muSiybatiY ↓A^anota xilowN Thou art free in mind from my affliction, or misfortune. (TA from a trad.) And minoka ↓A^anaA xaliY~N I am clear, or quit, of thee. (S.) And ↓A^anaA minoka xalaA='N signifies the same. (S.) And ↓naHonu minoka AlxalaA='u and AlbaraA='u [q. v.] We are clear, or quit, of you. (Fr, T in art. brA^.) And mino h`*aA AlA^amori ↓A^anota xalaA='N Thou art clear, or quit, of this affair. (TA.) And ↓A^anaA mino h`*aA AlA^amori kafaAliji boni xalaAwapa [lit. I am, with respect to this affair, like Fálij Ibn-Kha-
láweh], (S,) or faAliju bonu xalaAwapa, (so in the JK and K in this art., and in the S and K in art. flj,) meaning bariYo'N [i. e. And ↓xaliY~N [alone] signifies xaAlK mina Alham~i [Free from anxiety]; contr. of $ajiY~N. (S.) It is said in a prov., wayolN ↓lil$~ajiY~i mina AlxaliY~i, i. e. Woe to him who is occupied by anxiety from him who is free therefrom: (TA:) and in another, maA yaloqaY Al$~ajiY~u ↓mina AlxaliY~i, i. e. What will he who is occupied by anxiety experience from him who is free therefrom? meaning, accord. to AO, that the latter will not aid the former against his anxieties, but will censure him: it is said in the Tekmileh that AlxaliY~ [in these provs.] is from xalaAhu AlHuzonu meaning “ Grief passed away from him, ” and “ quitted him. ” (Har p. 590.) And ↓A^anoti xaliy~apN means xaAliyapN mina Alxayori [i. e. Thou, O woman, art devoid, or destitute, of good]. as an intrans. v.: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- xAmrhu, inf. n. muxaAmarapN, It mixed, mingled, commingled, intermixed, or intermingled, with it; became incorporated, or blended, with it; infected, or pervaded, it; syn. xaAlaTahu. (S, A, Mgh, * K.) You say, xAmr AlmaA='a All~abana The water mixed with the milk. (A.) And xaAmarotu fulaAnFA (tropical:) I mixed with such a one in familiar, or social, intercourse; conversed with him; or became intimate with him; syn. xaAlaTotuhu. (A.) And Alxamoru tuxaAmiru AlEaqola: see 1. And xAmrhu Ald~aA='u (assumed tropical:) The disease infected, or pervaded, him; syn. xaAlaTahu: (Sh:) or infected, or pervaded, (xAlT,) his inside. (Lth.) ― -b2- Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He approached it; or was, or became, near to it; (K, * TA;) namely, a thing. (TA.) ― -b3- And xAmr AlmakaAna, (S, A,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) He kept, or clave, to the place; (S, A, K;) did not quit it; (A;) remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in it; (K;) and in like manner, bayotahu his house, or tent; and so ↓xm~rhu. (TA.) ＝ -A3- xAmr, (TK,) inf. n. as above, (IAar, K,) [app. in the dial. of El-Yemen, (see 10,)] also signifies He sold a free person as being a slave. (IAar, K, TK.)

4 Axmr A^xmr Axmr xmr
: see 1 in the former half of the paragraph, in six places. ― -b2- A^axomarati AlA^aroDu The land abounded with xamar, (S, K,) meaning tangled trees. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, latter part, in two places. ＝ -A3- Axmrhu Al$~aYo'a He gave him the thing, or put him in possession of it, (K,) is a phrase common in El-Yemen: (Mohammad Ibn-Ketheer, TA:) a man says, A^axomirniY ka*aA, meaning Give thou me such a thing as a free gift: put me in possession of it: and the like. (Mohammad Ibn-Ketheer, S.)

5 taxam~arato txmr txmrt
: see 8. ＝ -A2- Also She (a woman) applied xumorap as a liniment to her face, to beautify her complexion. (TA.) ＝ -A3- txm~r He was affected with languor by wine. (TA.) [See xumira.] ― -b2- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.

8 Aixotamarato Axtmrt {xtmr {xtmrt
She wore, or put on [her head], a ximaAr; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓txm~rt. (A, Mgh, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- Axtmr, said of dough, [It became fermented;] it had xumorap put into it: and in like manner one says of the beverage called nabiy* [it became fermented]: (A:) or, said of dough, and of clay, or mud, (Tiyn, as in the K, but accord. to other lexicons perfume, Tiyb, TA,) and the like, it was left until it became good [or mature]: (K:) and Axtmrt Alxamoru the wine became mature [and fermented]; (Mgh, Msb, K;) as it does when it becomes changed in odour: (TA:) or became changed in odour. (S.)

10 Astxmrhu Astxmrh Astxmrp
He made him, or took him as, a slave: (S, Mgh, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Mgh, TA.) [See 3.] So in the trad. of Mo'ádh, mano A@sotaxomara qawomFA A^aw~aluhumo A^aHoraArN wajiyraAnN musotaDoEafuwna falahu maA qaSara fiY bayotihi [Whosoever hath made slaves, or taken as slaves, persons the first state of whomhath been that of freemen and neighbours, regarded as weak, to him shall belong what he hath held in possession in his house or tent]: (S, * L:) i. e., hath taken them by force, and obtained possession of them: (S:) meaning, whosoever hath made slaves, or taken as slaves, persons in the Time of Ignorance, and then El-Islám hath come, to him shall belong those whom he hath held in possession in his house or tent: they shall not go from his hand. (Az, TA.) Mohammad Ibn-Ketheer says, This is a phrase known to us in ElYemen, where any other is scarcely ever used [in its stead]. (S.)

xamorN xmAr xmr
[Wine: or grape-wine:] what intoxicates, of the expressed juice of grapes: (ISd, K:) or the juice of grapes when it has effervesced, and thrown up froth, and become freed therefrom, and still: (Mgh:) or it has a common application to intoxicating expressed juice of anything: (K, TA:) or any intoxicating thing, that clouds, or obscures, (lit. covers,) the intellect; as some say: (Mgh, * Msb: [but see what follows:]) and the general application is the more correct, because xamor was forbidden when there was not in El-Medeeneh any xamor of grapes; the beverage of its inhabitants being prepared only from dates in their green and small state, or full-grown but unripe, or fresh and ripe, or dried: (K, * TA:) or the arguing thus, from this fact alone, requires consideration: (MF:) AHn says, it is (assumed tropical:) sometimes prepared from grains: but ISd holds this to be an improper signification: (TA:) it is also sometimes applied to the (assumed tropical:) beverage called nabiy*, like as nby* is sometimes applied to wine expressed from grapes: (L in art. nb*:) applied to (tropical:) expressed juice from which xamor [properly so called] is made, [i. e., to must, or unfermented nabiy*,] it is tropical: it is so used in a trad. in which xamor is said to have been sold by [a companion of Mohammad named] Samurah: xamor [in its proper acceptation] is so called because it veils (taxomuru, i. e. tasoturu,) the intellect: (K:) or because it infects (tuxaAmiru, i. e. tuxaAliTu,) the intellect: (S, K:) [as though acting like leaven: (see 1:)] so said 'Omar: (TA:) or because it is left until it has become mature [and fermented]; (K;) or until its odour has changed: (IAar, S:) [see 8:] the proper application of the root is to denote “ covering, ” and “ commingling in a hidden manner: ” (Sgh, Er-Rághib, TA:) it is of the fem. gender, and sometimes masc.: (Msb, K:) you say huwa Alxamoru as well as hiYa Alxamoru:
but As does not allow it to be masc.: (Msb:) and ↓xamorapN signifies the same: (K:) [or a kind of wine:] or xamorN and xamorapN are like tamorN and tamorapN; [the former a coll. gen. n., and the latter its n. un.;] (S;) and xamorapN [thus] signifies some wine; lit., a portion of xamor: (Msb:) the pl. of xamorN is xumuwrN. (S, Msb.) You say [also] SirofN ↓xamorapN [Some pure, or unmixed, wine; using a masc. epithet, contr. to rule]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] maA Einoda fulaAnK xal~N walaA xamorN, (S,) or maA huwa bixal~K walaA xamorK, (K,) (tropical:) Such a one, (S,) or he, (K,) possesses neither good nor evil: (S, K:) [or neither evil nor good: for] AA says that some of the Arabs make Alxamoru to be good, and Alxal~u to be evil; and some of them make Alxmr to be evil, and Alxl~ to be good. (Har p. 153.) ― -b3- xamorN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Grapes; (AHn, M, K;) in the dial. of ElYemen:) (M:) like as EinabN signifies “ wine ” in that dial. (AHn, TA in art. Enb.) It is said in the Kur [xii. 36], A_in~iY A^araAniY A^aEoSiru xamorFA Verily I thought myself pressing grapes: (ISd:) or the meaning is, pressing out wine from grapes. (Ibn- 'Arafeh.)

xamarN xmAr xmr
A covert of trees &c.: (ISk, S, Mgh, K:) or a place where the ground is eaten away by a torrent, or an oblong tract of sand collected together and elevated, forming a place for concealment: (ISk, S:) and a hollow, or cavity, in which a wolf conceals himself: and tangled trees. (TA.) You say, tawaAraY AlS~ayodu min~iY fiY xamari AlwaAdiY [The game, or wild animal or animals, concealed itself, or themselves, from me in the covert, &c., of the valley]. (S.) And huwa yadib~u lahu AlD~araA='a wa yamo$iY lahu Alxamara (assumed tropical:) [He creeps to him in the thicket, or place overgrown with trees; and he walks to him in the covert of trees, &c.: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. 913]: speaking of a man when he deceives, or circumvents, his companion. (S.) And jaA='anaA EalaY xamorK and ↓ElY ximorapK (assumed tropical:) He came to us secretly; unexpectedly; clandestinely. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) xamarN and ↓xumaArN and ↓xamaArN (S, K) and ↓xamorapN (K) (assumed tropical:) A crowding, (S,) or congregation, (K,) and multitude, of men or people. (S, K.) You say, Aln~aAsi ↓daxala fiY xamaAri and ↓xamaArihimo, dial. vars. of gumaAr and gamaAr, i. e. (tropical:) He entered among the crowding and multitude of the men or people; (S;) and in like manner, fY ↓xamarotihimo and gamarotihimo; (TA;) as also fY xamarihimo and gamarihimo: (TA in art. gmr:) or among such [a crowd] of the people as hid him. (ISk, S.)

xamirN xmAr xmr
A place abounding with coverts of the description termed xamar; (IAar, S, K;) a place concealing by dense trees. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) A man infected, syn. muxaAmarN, (Sh, IAar, S,) by a disease: (TA:) thought by ISd to be a possessive epithet: (TA:) or in the last stage of the remains of intoxication. (S.) [See also maxomuwrN.])

xamorapN xmAr xmr xmrh xmrp
: see xamorN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, (S, A, K,) and ↓ximorapN (Kr, K) and ↓xumorapN, (K,) The odour of perfume: (S, A:) or a sweet odour: (K:) and the last signifies also an odour which has infected (xaAmara, i. e. xaAlaTa,) a person; (K;) as also ↓xamarapN. (AZ, K.) You say, wajadotu xamorapa AlT~iybi I experienced, or smelt, the odour of the perfume. (S, A.) ＝ -A2- See also xamarN, in two places.

xumorapN xmAr xmr xmrh xmrp
: see xamiyrN, in two places. ― -b2- Also a dial. var. of gumorapN [q. v.], A thing [or composition] which is used as a liniment for beautifying the complexion; (S;) [the plant called] waros and certain perfumes which a woman uses as a liniment (so in the K, or applies as a liniment to her face, as in other lexicons, TA) to beautify her face. (K.) ＝ -A2- Pain, and headache, and annoyance, occasioned by wine (xamor, for which in some copies of the K we find Hum~aY erroneously put, TA); as also ↓xumaArN: or the intoxication thereof, which has infected (xaAlaTa) [a person]; (K;) and so ↓xumaArN: (TA:) or this latter signifies the remains of intoxication: (S:) pl. of the former xumarN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also xamorapN. ＝ -A3- A small pot or jar: and a vessel for leaven. (KL.) ＝ -A4- A small mat, (S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K,) [of an oblong shape,] large enough for a man to prostrate himself upon it, (Mgh, Msb,) used for that purpose [in prayer], (S, A,) made of palm-leaves (S, K) woven (turomalu) with threads or strings: (S:) so called because it veils the ground from the face of the person praying [upon it]: (Zj, * Mgh:) or because its threads or strings are hidden by its palm-leaves. (TA.)

ximorapN xmAr xmr xmrh xmrp
A hiding, or concealing, oneself: (IAar, TA:) [or, accord. to analogy, a mode, or manner, of doing so.] ― -b2- See also xamarN. ― -b3- A mode, manner, or way, of wearing the ximaAr. (K, * TA.) You say, A_in~ahaA laHasanapu Alximorapi [Verily she has a beautiful mode of wearing the xmAr]. (S.) And hence the saying of 'Omar to Mo'áwiyeh, maA A^a$obaha Eayonaka biximorapi hinodK [How like is thine eye to Hind's (when she practises her) mode of wearing the xmAr!]. (TA.) Hence also, (TA,) A_in~a AlEawaAna laA tuEal~amu Alximorapa [Verily she who has had a husband will not require to be taught the mode of wearing the xmAr]: (S, K, * TA:) a prov., (S, TA,) applied to him who is experienced and knowing: (K:) i. e. the experienced woman is not to be taught how she should act. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also xamorapN.

xamarapN xmAr xmr xmrh xmrp
: see xamorapN.

xamoriY~N xmAr xmr xmrY xmry
Grapes (EinabN) fit for wine. (TA.) ― -b2- A colour resembling the colour of wine. (TA.)

ximir~N xmAr xmr
: see ximaArN.

xamaArN xmAr
: see xamarN, in two places.

xumaArN xmAr
: see xamarN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also xumorapN, in two places.

ximaArN xmAr
[A woman's muffler, or veil, with which she covers her head and the lower part of her face, leaving exposed only the eyes and part or the whole of the nose: such is the xmAr worn in the present day: a kind of veil which is called in Turkish ya$omaqo; as in the TK:) a woman's headcovering; (Mgh, TA;) a piece of cloth with which a woman covers her head; (Msb;) i. q. naSiyfN, (K,) pertaining to a woman; (S) as also ↓ximir~N: (Th, K:) and any covering of a thing; anything by which a thing is veiled, or covered: (K:) pl. [of pauc.] A^axomirapN (K) and [of mult.] xumurN (Msb, K) and xumorN. (K.) ― -b2- Also A man's turban; because a man covers his head with it in like manner as a woman covers her head with her xmAr: when he disposes it in the Arab manner, he turns [a part of] it under the jaws [nearly in the same manner in which a woman disposes her xmAr]. (TA.) [Hence,] maA $am~a ximaAraka, a prov., (TA,) [meaning] (assumed tropical:) What hath changed thee from the state in which thou wast? What hath befallen thee? (K.)

xamiyrN xmyr
(K) and ↓maxomuwrN and ↓muxam~arN, (TA,) applied to dough, [Leavened;] having had xamiyr [as meaning leaven] put into it: (TA:) or, applied to dough, and to clay or mud (Tiyn, as in the K, but accord. to other lexicons perfume, Tiyb, TA), and the like, left until it has become good [or mature]: (K:) pl. [of the first] xamoraY. (TA.) You say also xubozN xamiyrN Bread [leavened, or] into which leaven (xamiyr) has been put: (Lh, TA:) or yesterday's bread; bread that has been kept over a night: (S:) and xubozapN xamiyrN, without p [in the epithet]. (Lh, TA.) And xamiyrN is also applied to Bread itself: or leavened bread. (Sh, TA.) ― -b2- xamiyrN [used as a subst.] (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓xamiyrapN and ↓xumorapN (S, A, K) signify Leaven, or ferment, expl. by maA xum~ira bihi, (K,) of dough, and of perfume; (TA;) what is put into dough, (S, A, Msb,) and into the beverage called nabiy*; (A;) and ↓xumorapN also signifies what is put into perfume, as well as what is put into dough and into nby*: (Ks:) the xumorap of nby* is its dregs, (K,) and its [ferment which is called] durodiY~; (TA;) or what is put into it, of wine (xamor) and of durodiY~; and so too of perfume; (S;) and the xumorap of milk is its ferment (ruwbap) which is poured upon it in order that it may quickly curdle, or coagulate, or thicken, or become thick and fit for churning. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AijoEalohu fiY sir~i xamiyrika (tropical:) Conceal thou it (i. e. a secret, A) in thy mind. (A, TA.) And A^axoraja mino sir~i xamiyrihi sir~FA (tropical:) He revealed, or disclosed, a secret. (TA.) ― -b4- See also maxomuwrN.

xamiyrapN xmyr xmyrh xmyrp
: see the next preceding paragraph.

xam~aArN xmAr
A vintner; a seller of xamor [or wine]. (K.)

xim~iyrN xmyr
(S) and ↓musotaxomirN (K) One who constantly drinks wine; (S, K;) a great drinker; devoted to drink. (K.)

muxam~irN mxmr
A maker of xamor [or wine]. (K.)

maxomuwrN mxmwr
: see xamiyrN. ― -b2- Also, (S,) and ↓muxam~arN and ↓xamiyrN, (TA,) A man affected with xumaAr, (S, TA,) i. e. the remains of intoxication. (S. [Like maboxuwrN. See also xamirN.])

muxotamirN mxtmr
, and with p: see muxam~arN.

musotaxomirN mstxmr
: see xim~iyrN.

1 xamasa Alqawoma xms Alqwm
, (S, A, Mgh, K,) aor.
xamusa
, (S, Mgh, K,) [inf. n. xamosN,] He took the fifth part of the possessions of the people. (S, A, Mgh, K.) And xamasa AlmaAla, (A, Msb,) aor.
xamusa
, inf. n. xamosN, (Msb,) He took the fifth part of the property. (A, Msb.) xamosN signifies The taking one from five: and hence the saying of 'Adee Ibn-Hátim, rabaEotu fiY AljaAhiliy~ap waxamasotu fiY AlA_isolaAmi [I took the fourth part of the spoil in the Time of Ignorance, and I took the fifth part thereof in the time of El-Islám]; meaning, I headed the army in both those states; for the commander, in the Time of Ignorance, used to take the fourth part of the spoil; and in El-Islám, the fifth part was assigned to him. (TA.) ― -b2- xamasa Alqawoma, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
xamisa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. xamosN, (Msb,) He was, or became, the fifth of the people: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he made them five by [adding to their number] himself. (S, K.) ― -b3- xamasa also signifies He made fourteen to be fifteen. (T in art. vlv.) ― -b4- And He made forty-nine to be fifty with himself. (A'Obeyd, S in that art.) ― -b5- xamasa AlHabola, aor.
xamisa
, inf. n. xamosN, He made the rope of five strands twisted together. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xamasati AlA_ibilu The camels drank on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first. (TA.) [See xamosN.] ― -b2- xamasa, said of a horse, He came fifth in the race. (T, M, L; all in art. vlv.)

2 xm~shu xms xmsh xmsp
, inf. n. taxomiysN, He made it five. (EshSheybánee and K, voce waH~adahu.) ― -b2- He made it to be five-cornered; five-angled; pentagonal. (K.) ― -b3- xam~asato She brought forth her fifth offspring. (TA in art. bkr.) ― -b4- And xm~shu He made it five-fifths. (Msb.) ― -b5- xm~s liA@moraA^atihi, or EinodahaA, He remained five nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sab~aEa.) ― -b6- taxomiysN also signifies [The watering of land or seedproduce on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first;] the watering of land that is [next] after the tarobiyE. (TA.)

4 Axms Alqawomu Axms Alqwm
The party of men became five: (S, K:) ― -b2- also, The party of men became fifty. (M and L in art. vlv.) ― -b3- Axms Alr~ajulu The man was, or became, one whose camels came to water on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first. (S, * K, * TA.) [See ximosN.]

xamosN xms
fem. of xamosapN [q. v.].

xumosN xms
: see xumusN.

ximosN xms
The drinking of camels on the fifth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first; their drinking one day, then pasturing three days, then coming to the water on the fifth day, the first and last days, on which they drink, being thus reckoned: this is the correct explanation, accord. to Aboo-Sahl El-Khowlee; and Aboo-Zekereeyà says the like; (TA;) or their pasturing three days, and coming to the water on the fourth day [not counting the day of the next preceding watering; for it is evident that this explanation is virtually the same as that preceding]: (S, K:) accord. to Lth, the drinking of camels on the fourth day, counting the day on which they returned from [the next preceding] watering; but Az says, that this is a mistake; the day of returning from watering not being counted [when it is explained as meaning the drinking on the fourth day]: (TA:) pl. A^axomaAsN, the only pl. form. (Sb, TA.) [See Zimo'N.] Hence, falaApN ximosN [as in copies of the K, or it may be falaApu ximosK,] A desert in which the water is far distant, so that the camels come to the water on the fourth day, exclusive of the [next preceding] day on which they drank. (Az, K, TA.) Hence also the saying, fulaAnN yaDoribu A^axomaAsFA liA^asodaAsK (S, K *) (tropical:) Such a one makes a pretence of AxmAs [or fifth-day waterings] for the purpose of AsdAs [or sixth-day waterings]: i. e., he advances his camels from the ximos to the sidos: (K:) a prov.: (TA:) meaning, such a one strives to deceive, or circumvent: (S, K:) applied to him who acts towards another with artifice, pretending that he obeys him, or complies with his desire: (TA:) or to him who pretends one thing while he means another: (K:) and taken from the saying, related by AO and IAar, Daraba A^axomaAsFA liA^asodaAsK [He made a pretence of AxmAs for the purpose of AsdAs]; said of him who proposes a thing whereby he means another thing, which he commences and by slow degrees accomplishes: (TA:) for a man, when he desires to make a long journey, accustoms his camels to drink ximosFA sidosFA [i. e. on the fifth day and then on the sixth, in each case counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first]: (K, TA:) the origin of the saying, accord. to IAar, being this: an old man was among his camels, accompanied by his sons, men, who pastured them, and who had been long far distant from their families; and he told them one day to pasture their camels riboEFA [i. e. watering on the fourth day, counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first], which they did, proceeding in the way towards their families: then they proposed to do so ximosFA; and then, sidosFA: whereupon the old man, understanding what they meant, said, ye are doing nothing but making a pretence of AxmAs for the purpose of AsdAs: the object of your desire is not the pasturing of them, but it is only your families. (TA.) [See below, voce xumusN, a saying similar in words but different in meaning.] ― -b2- It is also used for sayoru ximosK [A journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fifth days; a journey in which the second and third and fourth days are without water]. (L in art. jl*.) You say ximsN baSobaASN, [and SaboSaAbN,] and qaEoqaAEN, and HavoHaAvN, [and HaSoHaASN, &c.,] i. e. A journey [in which the camels are watered only on the first and fifth days,] in the course of which, to the water, there is no flagging, by reason of its remoteness. (TA.) El-'Ajjáj uses the expression
ximosN kaHaboli Al$~aEari AlmunoHat~i
meaning, A [journey of the kind termed] xms without any deviation, like a rope made of hair that has fallen off and that is free from any unevenness. (L, TA.) ― -b3- ximosN also signifies The fifth young one, or offspring. (A in art. vlv.) ＝ -A2- A [garment of the kind called] burod, (S, K,) of the fabric of El-Yemen; (S;) so called because first made for a king of El-Yemen named ximosN, (AA, S,) or Alximosu; (K, TA;) as also ↓xamiysN. (TA.) For the latter word, we find in the work of Bkh, xamiyS, with S; which, if correct, is masc. of xamiySapN, which is a small kind of kisaA='. (IAth, and L.) [The pl. of ximosN applied to a burodap is A^axomaAsN.] See also maxomuwsN, in four places.

xumusN xms
and ↓xumosN A fifth part; (Msb, K;) as also ↓xamiysN, (S, in art. vlv, and IAmb and Msb,) agreeably with a rule applicable in the case of every one of the units, except valiyvN: (TA:) some allow this last; but AZ disallows it, and xmys also: (S in art. vlv:) pl. A^axomaAsN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] Daraba A^axomaAsahu fiY A^asodaAsihi He turned his five senses towards his six relative points; [namely, above, below, before, behind, right, and left:] an allusion to the collecting all the thoughts to examine a thing, and turning the attention in all directions. (MF.)

xamosapN xms xmsh xmsp
, (S, K,) masc.; and xamosN, fem.; (S;) [Five;] a certain number. (S, K.) You say xamosapu rijaAlK [Five men], and xamosu nisowapK [Five women]. (S.) You say also, EinodiY xamosapu daraAhimo [I have five dirhems], with refa: and if you please, you incorporate the p into the d [and say, xamosap d~araAhima]: but when you prefix Al to drAhm, you say, EinodiY xamosapu Ald~araAhimi [I have the five dirhems], with damm; and may not incorporate, because you have incorporated the l into the d: and in the case of a fem. n. you say, EinodiY xamosu Alquduwri [I have the five cooking-pots]: also, h`*ihi Alxamosapu Ald~araAhimi [These five dirhems]; and, if you please, Ald~araAhimu, using it in the manner of an epithet: and in like manner [you use the other nouns of number] to Ea$arapN [inclusive]. (S.) You say also, SumonaA xamosFA mina Al$~ahori [We fasted during a period of five nights of the month with their
days]; making layaAlK to predominate over A^ay~aAm, when you do not mention the word Ay~Am, though the fasting is in the day; because the night of each day precedes the day: but when you mention the word Ay~Am, you say, SumonaA xamosapa A^ay~aAmK [We fasted five days].
