: see xamolN, in four places. ― -b2- Also A dense collection of trees; (JK, S;) so says Aboo- Sá'id: (S:) or numerous tangled, or luxuriant, or dense, trees, (K, TA,) among which one sees not a thing when it falls in the midst thereof: (TA:) and a place abounding in trees, wherever it be, (K,) or, accord. to Az, only in plain, level, or soft, ground: (TA:) and a low, or depressed, tract of ground, (K, * TA,) or of sand, (M, TA,) or an intervening tract between low, or depressed, and hard, ground, (T, TA,) or an intervening tract amid sands, in low, or depressed, and hard, ground, (JK,) and producing good herbage or plants: (JK, T, K, TA:) or plain, or soft, land, producing herbage or plants, which are likened to the xamol [or nap] of the qaTiyfap: or a place where water remains and stagnates, and which produces trees; but only in plain, level, or soft, ground: (TA:) or a meadow (rawoDapN) in which are trees; that in which are no trees being termed jaloHaA='u: (Har p. 118:) or a tract of sand producing trees: (As, S, K:) or a place where a tract of sand becomes thin, or shallow; where the main portion of it passes away, and somewhat of the soft part of it remains: pl. xamaAy^ilu: which is also explained as signifying meadows (riyaAD). (TA.)

xaAmilN xAml
A man obscure, unnoted, reputeless, or of no reputation; (S, Msb, K;) unknown, (JK, T,) and unmentioned; (T;) destitute of good fortune: (Msb:) and one says also xaAminN, by substitution [of n for l]: (TA:) pl. xamalN (K) and xamalapN, explained as signifying the lower or lowest, or meaner or meanest, sort of mankind. (TA.) You say also qawolN xaAmilN A low, soft, or gentle, saying or speech. (Az, TA.) And it is said in a trad., Au*okuruwA A@ll~`hi *ikorFA xaAmilFA Celebrate ye God with a low, soft, or gentle, voice, in reverence of his greatness, or majesty. (TA.)

muxomalN mxml
A garment, (JK, TA,) or a kisaA=', (Mgh, Msb,) having xamol [or nap], (JK, * Mgh, Msb, TA,) i. e. what resembles hudob on its surface. (Mgh.)

maxomuwlN mxmwl
(JK, TA) and maxomuwlapN, (JK,) applied to a young camel, (JK,) or to a camel, and a horse, (TA,) and a sheep or goat, ($Ap, JK, TA,) Having, or affected with, the disease termed xumaAl: (JK, TA:) and so ↓xamiylN, applied to a young camel; pl. xamolaY. (JK.)

1 xamana xmn xmnn
, [aor.
xamuna
, ] inf. n. xumuwnN, said of [a man's] reputation (Al*~ikoru), It was, or became, obscure; i. q. xamala, inf. n. xumuwlN: and, said of a thing, it was, or became, obscure, unapparent, hidden, or concealed: whence xamanahu as syn. with xam~anahu, q. v. (Msb.)

2 xm~nhu xmn xmnh xmnnh xmnp
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. taxomiynN; (S, Msb;) and ↓xamanahu, (Msb, K,) aor.
xamina
inf. n. xamonN; (Msb;) He spoke of it conjecturally, (S, Msb, K,) and opining; (TA;) or surmising: (K:) or he formed a surmise respecting it; or an opinion. (Msb.) IDrd says, I think it to be post-classical: (TA:) AHát says that it is of Persian origin, (Msb, TA,) arabicized, (TA,) from xmAnA, [app. a mistranscription for GumaAnaA, or GumaAnaho, or GumaAno,] applied to “ an opinion, ” and “ a conjecture, ” or “ conjectural saying. ” (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- taxomiynN is also syn. with taHoriyrN. (So in the TA. [But this, I doubt not, is a mistranscription for taHoziyzN, which, though perhaps post-classical, signifies The act of conjecturing.])

xamanN xmn xmnn
Stink. (K.)

[
xamaAnN x*mAn
The elder-tree: and xamaAnN SagiyrN Dwarf elder-tree: so in the present day.]

xam~aAnN xmAn
A weak spear: and qanaApN xam~aAnapN [a weak spear or spear-shaft]. (A 'Obeyd, S, K.) ― -b2- What is bad of household-goods, or furniture, or utensils: (TA:) and The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, or mankind; (S, K;) the bad thereof. (K.) [Mentioned also in art. xm.]

xaAminu Al*~ikori *
A man (TA) obscure, unnoted, reputeless, of no reputation; i. q. xaAmilu Al*~ikori. (K, TA.)

div2.head: Quasi xmY
div2.entryFree:
xaAmK xAm
(accus. xaAmiyFA) for xaAmisN: see the latter word.

1 xan~a xAn xn xnn
, (Sh, S, K,) aor. yaxin~N, (S, K,) inf. n. xaniynN, (Sh, S, *, K * TA,) He made a sound from the nose, like Haniyn from the mouth: (TA:) he made a sound like weeping, (S, *, K * TA,) and (so in the S, but in the K “ or ”) like laughing, in the nose: (S, * K, * TA:) he reiterated a sound of weeping in the air-passages of the nose; and sometimes xaniynN is [the reiterating a sound in the nose] from faint laughing: (Sh, TA:) or he laughed faintly. (JK.) [See also xaniynN below.] ＝ -A2- xun~a He (a camel) was affected with the disease termed xunaAn: (JK, TA:) [and in like manner, a bird: see maxonuwnN.]

4 Axn~hu A@ll~`hu *
i. q. A^ajan~ahu [God caused him to be bereft of reason; or mad, insane, &c.]. (Lh, K.)

R. Q. 1 xanoxana xnxn xnxnn
, (TA,) inf. n. xanoxanapN, (JK, S, K, TA,) [like xamoxama,] He snuffled; i. e., spoke through his nose: (TA:) he spoke indistinctly, making a sort of twang (yuxanoxinu) in his xayaA$iym [or air-passages of the nose]. (JK, S, K.) A poet says,
xanoxana liY fiY qawolihi saAEapF
faqaAla liY $ayoy^FA walamo A^asomaEi
[He snuffled to me in his speech awhile, and said to me something, but I heard not]. (TA.) ― -b2- xanoxanapN also signifies The crying of the ape. (IAar, TA.)

xun~apN xAn xn xnh xnnh xnp
i. q. gun~apN [i. e. A nasal sound or twang; or a snuffling sound]; (JK, K;) the latter word explained by Mbr as meaning a mixture of the sound of the xayo$uwm [or air-passage of the nose] in the pronunciation of a letter or word; (TA;) as also ↓maxan~apN: (K:) or the first is like gun~apN; (S, K;) as also ↓xananN: (ISd, TA:) or, (Mbr, K,) as also ↓maxan~apN, (TA,) louder than gun~apN: (Mbr, K, TA:) or more open than gun~apN: (K, TA. [In the CK, A^aqobaHu is put in the place of A^afotaHu.])

xananN xn xnn xnnn
: see what next precedes.

xunaAnN xnAn
A certain disease that attacks in the nose: (S, TA:) a disease that attack camels in their nostrils, and from which they die; (As, TA;) a rheum that affects camels; (K;) in camels, like the zukaAm in human beings. (JK.) zamanu AlxunaAni [The time of the xnAn] was in the age of ElMundhir Ibn-Má-es-Semà; in consequence thereof the camels died: (K:) it is well known with the Arabs, is mentioned in their verses, (TA,) and became an era to them. (As, TA.) ― -b2- Also A certain disease that attacks birds in their throats. (S, M, K.) ― -b3- And A certain disease in the eye. (M, K.)

xaniynN xnp xny xnyn
The issuing of a sound from the nose, like HaniynN from the mouth: [see HaniynN, in two places:] this is the primary signification: (TA:) and it is [the making a sound] like weeping, and (so in the S, but in the K “ or ”) like laughing, in the nose: (S, K:) IB says that there is a kind of xnyn like weeping in the nose: (TA:) or a weeping of women, (JK,) or a kind of weeping, (IAth, TA,) less than what is termed AinotiHaAbN: (JK, IAth, TA:) and a faint laughing. (JK.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- And Stoppages in the xayaA$iym [or air-passages of the nose]. (TA.)

A^axan~N *
i. q. A^agan~N [as meaning Having a nasal twang]; (S, K, TA;) who snuffles; i. e., speaks from [i. e. through] his nose: (TA voce A^adogamu:) [or] as meaning having the xayaA$iym [or airpassages of the nose] stopped up: or, as some say, having the xyA$ym [here app. meaning certain cartilages in the upper, or inmost, part of the nose] delapsed: [see 1 in art. x$m:] fem. xan~aA='u: (TA:) and pl. xun~N. (S, K.)

maxan~apN mxnh mxnp
: see xun~apN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also The nose: (S, K:) written by J [accord. to some of the copies of the S, but not accord. to all,] with kesr to the m: (TA:) or the extremity thereof. (K.) ＝ -A3- And i. q. maA^okalapN: so in the phrase, fulaAnN maxan~apN lifulaAnK [Such a one is to such a one a person from whom to obtain what to eat]. (S, K.) ― -b2- You say also, AlbiT~iyxu liY maxan~apN i. e. [The melon, or water-melon, is to me] a usual food. (JM.)

maxonuwnN mxnwn
A camel, and a bird, affected with the disease termed xunaAn. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. majonuwnN [Bereft of reason; or mad, insane, &c.]. (Lh, K.) [See R. Q. 1 in art. xm.]

1 xanava xnv
, (Lth, L,) aor.
xaniva
, inf. n. xanovN, (L,) He folded, or doubled, a skin for water or milk, and a sack. (Lth, L.) And xanava Als~iqaA='a, (S, A, Mgh, K, TA,) and fama Als~iqaA='i, (A, TA,) and AlsqA='i ↓Axtnv, (S, A, * Mgh, K,) He doubled the skin, (S, K,) or the mouth of the skin, (A, Mgh, TA,) outwards, (S, A, Mgh, K,) or inside-out, (TA,) and drank from it; (S, Mgh, K;) the doing of which is forbidden (Mgh, TA) by Mo- hammad: (TA:) when you double it inwards, you say, qabaEotuhu: (S, A, Mgh:) or xanava fama Als~iqaA='i signifies he turned the mouth of the skin outsidein or inside-out: and xanovN signifies any kind of inverting, or turning upside-down or inside-out or the like. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] xanava lahu biA^anofihi [He contracted his nose at him]; as though he mocked at, scoffed at, derided, or ridiculed, him: so in the A: but in the K, xanavahu, aor.
xaniva
, he mocked at, scoffed at, derided, or ridiculed, him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xanavN, aor.
xanava
, (L, Msb, K,) inf. n. xanavN; (A, Msb, TA;) and ↓Anxv, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) and ↓txn~v; (A, L, K;) He (a man, L) affected a bending, or an inclining of his body, from side to side, and languor, or languidness; or he became bent and languid; syn. tavan~aY watakas~ara: (S, A, L, K:) [or he was, or became, flaccid, or flabby, and affected a bending, or an inclining of his body, from side to side: (see xanivN:) or he was, or became, effeminate: (see xunovN:)] or he was, or became, soft, delicate, tender, flabby, lax, or limber, and affected languor, or languidness; expl. by kaAna fiyhi liynN watakas~urN. (Msb.) 'Áïsheh, describing the death of Mohammad, says, ↓Ainoxanava fiY HajoriY, meaning He became bent and languid (AinovanaY watakas~ara), by reason of the flaccidness of his limbs, in my bosom. (TA.)

2 xn~vhu xnv xnvh xnvp
, (S, K,) inf. n. taxoniyvN, (K,) He bent it; (S, K;) namely, a thing. (S.) Hence the epithet muxan~avN. (S, K.) ― -b2- He made him to be, or become, such as is termed xanivN. (Msb.) ― -b3- xn~v kalaAmahu He made his speech like that of women, in softness and gentleness: so some say. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- taxoniyvN also signifies The doing what is excessively foul, or obscene; [i. e. the acting the part of a catamite;] but this meaning was unknown to the Arabs [of the classical ages]. (MF.)

5 txn~v txnv xnv
It (a thing, S) bent, or became bent. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also i. q. xaniva, q. v. (A, * L, K.) And He (a man) acted in the manner of the muxin~av [or effeminate, &c.]. (TA.) [He became a muxan~av: used in this sense in the S and K in art. Tws.] And txn~v fiY kalaAmihi [He was soft, or effeminate, in his speech]. (S, Mgh.) ― -b3- He (a man &c.) fell down by reason of weakness. (TA.)

7 Anxnvt Alqirobapu Anxnvt Alqrbh Anxnvt Alqrbp
The water-skin became folded, or doubled. (L.) ― -b2- Anxnvt Eunuquhu His neck inclined, or bent. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, in two places.

8 A_ixotanava
see 1, second sentence.

xunovN xnv
a subst. from Ainoxanava [An affectation of a bending, or of an inclining of the body, from side to side, and of languor, or languidness; or a bending and languidness: or flaccidity or flabbiness, and an affectation of a bending, or of an inclining of the body, from side to side: or effeminacy: or softness, delicacy, tenderness, flabbiness, laxness, or limberness, and an affectation of languor, or languidness]: (S, L:) as also ↓xinaAvapN. (Msb.) Jereer says,
A^atuwEiduniY wa A^anota mujaA$iEiY~N
A^araY fiY xunovi liHoyatika A@DoTiraAbaA
[Dost thou threaten me, thou being a Mujáshi'ee? I see, in the softness and weakness of thy beard, or in the bending and languidness, or the effeminacy, of thy person, (for the beard is sometimes, by a synecdoche, put for the whole person,) an evidence of unsoundness, uncompactness, or weakness]. (S.)

xinovN xnv
, with kesr, sing. of A^axonaAvN and xinaAvN, (TA,) which signify The creases, or places of folding, of a garment, or piece of cloth. (K, TA.) You say, TawaY Alv~awoba EalaY A^axonaAvihi and xinaAvihi He folded the garment, or piece of cloth, at its creases. (TA.) And [hence,] A^aloqaY All~ayolu A^axonaAvapu EalaY AlA^aroDi (assumed tropical:) The night cast the folds of its darkness upon the earth. (TA.) ― -b2- Also the former pl., (TA,) and the latter also, (K,) The parts of the dalow [or bucket] whence the water pours forth, between the EaraAqiY. (K, TA.) ― -b3- The sing. also signifies The interior of the part of the cheek by the side of the mouth, next the molar teeth, (K, TA,) above and below. (TA.) ― -b4- And A company in a state of dispersion. (K.)

xanivN xnv
One in whom is an affectation of a bending, or of an inclining of the body, from side to side, and of languor, or languidness; or in whom is a bending and languidness; expl. by mano fiyhi tavan~K watakas~urN: (A, L, K:) or flaccid, or flabby, and affecting a bending, or an inclining of the body, from side to side: (S:) [or effeminate; like muxan~avN]: or one in whom is softness, delicacy, tenderness, flabbiness, laxness, or limberness, and an affectation of languor, or languidness: (Msb:) fem. with p. (TA.) And ↓xunuvN (TA) and ↓mixonaAvN, (K,) applied to a woman, (K, TA,) Soft, delicate, tender, flabby, lax, or limber, (TA,) and affecting languor, or languid-
ness: (K, TA:) pl. of the latter maxaAniyvu. (TA.) One says to such a woman, ↓yaAxanaAvi, (K,) [indecl.,] like qaTaAmi; (TA;) and to a man [of the same description], ↓yaA xunavu. (K.)

yaA xunavu yA xnv
: see the next preceding paragraph.

xunuvN xnv
: see the next preceding paragraph.

xunovaY xnv xnvY xnvy xnvyy
[A hermaphrodite;] one who has what is proper to the male and what is proper to the female: Kr makes it an epithet, and says rajulN xunovaY; (TA;) one who has what is proper to men and what is proper to women, (S, Mgh, K,) together; (S, K;) one who has, by creation, the anterior pudendum of a man and that of a woman: (Msb:) in the language of the lawyers, one who has what are proper to both sexes; or who has neither that of a man nor that of a woman: but some of them say that the former meaning is the proper one; and that he who has no external organ of generation is adjoined to the class of the xnvY as being subject to the same special laws: (MF, TA:) the pl. is xanaAvaY (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and xinaAvN. (Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- Also The plant called barowaAqN [i. e. the asphodel]. (K in art. brq.)

yaA xanaAvi yA xnAv
: see xanitN.

xaniyvN xnyv
A skin of the kind called qirobap folded, or doubled. (L.)

xunaAvapu xnAvh xnAvp xnvY
: see muxan~avN.

xinaAvapN xnAvh xnAvp xnvY
: see xunovN.

Hunayovapu Hnyvh Hnyvp
: see muxan~atu.

A^axonavu mino dalaAli *
[More effeminate, or more incapable of venery, than Delál]: a prov. (S, TA.) Delál was a certain man of El-Medeeneh, (TA,) who was made a eunuch, together with several other muxan~avuwn. (TA in art. dl. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 451; where the name is erroneously written dal~aAl.])

muxan~avN mxnv
, from xan~ava “he bent,” (S, K,) because of his softness, delicacy, tenderness, flabbiness, laxness, or limberness, and affectation of languor, or languidness; (TA;) or from xunovaY; (Kh, JK, MS;) An effeminate man; (T in art. Anv, and TA;) one who resembles a woman in gentleness, and in softness of speech, and in an affectation of languor of the limbs: (TA voce muw^an~avN, q. v.: [see also xanivN:]) it is written thus and ↓muxan~ivN: (TA:) this latter is explained by some as meaning one who makes his speech like that of women, in softness and gentleness: (Msb, TA:) it is also said that both these epithets are used to signify one who affects languor, or languidness, of the limbs; one who makes himself like women in the bending of himself, and in affecting languor, or languidness, and in speech: but that one uses the latter epithet only when he means one who does what is excessively foul, or obscene; [i. e. a catamite; though this is a meaning often borne by the former also;] notwithstanding that taxoniyvN, as signifying the “committing such an action,” was unknown to the Arabs [of the classical ages], and is not found in their language: (MF, TA:) [often, also,] the former epithet signifies a man incapable of venery: (MA:) it is said in a trad. that they used to reckon the mxn~v as one of those having no need of nikaAH. (TA in art. Arb.) The muxan~av is also called ↓xunaAvapu and ↓xunayovapu [each imperfectly decl.]. (K, TA.)

muxan~ivN mxnv
: see what next precedes.

mixonaAvN mxnAv
: see xanivN.

xanojarN xnjr
(S, Mgh, Msb, K) and xinojirN (Msb) and xinojarN, (K,) the last of a rare form, like dirohamN, (TA,) A knife: or a great knife: (K:) or a kind of large knife [or dagger, generally curved, and double-edged], (S, Mgh, Msb,) called in Persian da$onaho: (Mgh:) pl. xanaAjiru. (Msb.) Some say, [as, for instance, the author of the Msb,] that the n is augmentative, the measure being fnEl. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the first, (K,) and ↓xunojuwrN, (As, S, TA,) or ↓xunojuwrapN, and ↓xanojarapN, (K,) A she-camel abounding with milk: (As, S, K:) pl. xanaAjiru. (S.) And ↓xunojuwrapN A bulky she-camel. (K.)

xanojarapN xnjr xnjrh xnjrp
: see above.

xunojuwrN xnjwr
and xunojuwrapN: see xanojarN, in three places.

xanodariysN xndrys
Wine; (S, K;) so called because of its oldness: (S:) or old wine: (TA:) [accord. to some,] derived from xadorasapN, a word not explained: (K:) by some said to be of the measure fanoEaliysN, so that its radical letters are xdr; because wine is muxad~ir [i. e. a cause of torpor or languor]: by some said to be from xarosN; but to this it is objected that d is not augmentative: the truth is, that it is of the measure faEolaliylN, as Sb says: (MF:) by the author of the L and others, it is mentioned after art. xns: (TA:) or it is a Greek word, arabicized: (K:) [but I know not how this is, unless, as an epithet applied to wheat, (see what follows,) it be supposed to be from χόνδρος:] IDrd thought it to be an arabicized word: it may be an arabicized word from the Persian xanodaho riy$o, meaning “ having a laughing beard,” [or rather “one whose beard is laughed at,” i. e., “a laughing-stock,”] because he who makes use of it [namely of wine] has his beard laughed at. (TA.) ― -b2- You also say, HinoTap xanodariysN Old wheat: (IDrd, S, K:) and tamorN xanodariysN old dates. (TA.)

Q. 1 xanodaqahu xndq xndqh xndqp
(K) and xanodaqa Hawolahu (TA) He dug a xanodaq, i. e. fosse, or moat, around it. (K, * TA.) [In the CK the words of this art. are with * in the place of d.]

xanodaqN xndq
A fosse, or moat, [such as is] dug around the walls of cities: arabicized, from kanodaho, (IDrd, K,) which is Persian: (IDrd:) pl. xanaAdiqu. (TA.) ― -b2- And A valley. (TA.)

muxanodiqN mxndq
One who makes a xanodaq [i. e. fosse, or moat]. (JK.)

xanodaquwqN xndqwq
Tall. (TA. [But perhaps this is a mistranscription for HanodaquwqN, q. v.])

xanaw~arN xnwr
: and Alxanaw~arN: and A^um~u xanaw~arK: see what follows, in four places.

xan~uwrN xnwr
and ↓xanaw~arN Any soft and weak tree: (K:) or such is called xnwrp [i. e. xan~uwrapN or Hanaw~arapN: each, without p, being app. a coll. gen. n.; and with p, a n. un.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, accord. to AHn, (TA,) The reeds of [which are made] arrows. (K.) ＝ -A2- A^um~u xan~uwrK (S, K) and A^um~u xin~aworK (K) The female hyena: (S, K:) or she is called by the latter appellation, accord. to Aboo-Riyásh: or, as some say, these are surnames of the hyena. (TA.) And The cow [probably the wild cow]. (Aboo-Riyásh, K.) ― -b2- Also Calamity, or misfortune. (S, K.) You say, waqaEa Alqawomu fiY A^um~i xan~uwrK The people, or party, fell into calamity, or misfortune. (L, TA. But see two other explanations in what follows.) ― -b3- And Plentifulness, and pleasantness or easiness, and softness or delicacy, of life; or a life of softness or delicacy, and ease, comfort, or affluence; syn. Aln~aEomapu: [in the CK Aln~iEomapu; which is in many instances in the CK, as I hold it to be in the present instance, erroneously substituted for Aln~aEomapu:] thus bearing two contrary significations: and Alxan~uwru and ↓Alxanaw~aru signify the same, such as is apparent; (K;) or, as some say, abundant. (TA.) Some explain the saying above-mentioned as meaning The people, or party, fell into a state of plenty, or abundance, and softness or delicacy or easiness of life. (TA.) ― -b4- And The present world; or the present life, or state of existence; as also ↓A^um~u xanaw~arK: (L:) or so Alxin~aworu and ↓Alxanaw~aru. (K.) ― -b5- And The deserts; syn. AlS~aHaAraY: and so accord. to some in the saying mentioned above. (TA.) ― -b6- And The podex, or the anus; syn. AlAisotu: (K:) but AHát doubts respecting the teshdeed of the n; [app. whether this letter be doubled, or the w;] Aboo-Sahl says that it is A^um~u xin~aworK [only]: and IKh says that it means the Aisot of the bitch. (TA.)

1 xaniza xnz
, aor.
xanaza
; (S, A, * Msb, K;) and xanaza, aor.
xanuza
; (Msb;) inf. n. of the former, xanazN, (S, Msb, K,) and of the former also, (K,) or of the latter, (Msb,) xunuwzN; (Msb, K;) It (flesh-meat, S, A, Msb, K, and a date, and a walnut, TA) became stinking: (S, A, K:) or altered [in odour] : (Msb:) or maggotty and stinking: (TA:) like xazina. (S.)

xanazN xnz
: see what next follows.

xanizN xnz
, applied to flesh-meat, (Msb, K,) and to a date, and a walnut, (TA,) Stinking: (K:) or altered [in odour]: (Msb:) or maggotty and stinking: (TA:) as also ↓xanazN. (Yaakoob, K.)

xunozuwapN xnzwh xnzwp
: see what next follows.

1 xanasa A^xns xns
, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.

, (Mgh, Msb,) or both, (K,) inf. n. xunuwsN, (A,) or xanosN, (Msb,) or both, (K, TA,) and xunaAsN, (TA,) He went, or drew, back or backwards; receded; retreated; retired; or retrograded: or he remained behind; held back; hung back; or lagged behind: syn. taA^ax~ara: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) Eanohu from him or it: (S, K:) or mino bayoni Alqawomi from among the company of people: and hid himself: (A:) or and shrank, or drew himself together: (TA:) and ↓Anxns signifies the same; (Msb, K;) and so ↓Axtns; and xanusa, aor.
xanusa
, is mentioned by Sgh: (TA:) or xanasa signifies he went back, &c., syn. tA^x~r: and also, he shrank, or drew himself together: (Mgh, Msb: *) and he hid himself; became hidden or absent. (TA.) You say, xanasa Alkawokabu (tropical:) The star returned, or went back, or retrograded: syn. rajaEa; a tropical signification: (A: [and in the TA it is said that xanosN is syn. with rujuwEN, and is tropical in this sense:]) or became hidden, (K, TA,) like a gazelle in its covert, (TA,) or like the devil when he hears the mention of God: (K, TA:) or became concealed in the day-time: (TA:) and xunuwsN signifies also the being, or becoming, depressed. (Ham p. 332.) And xanasa Eani Alqawomi He held back, or hung back, from the company of people; remained behind them, not going with them; syn, taxal~afa; (As, on the authority of an Arab of the desert, of the Benoo- 'Okeyl;) as also ↓Anxns. (K.) [This is said in the TA to be tropical; but why, I see not.] And xanasati Aln~axolu (assumed tropical:) The palm-trees were backward to receive fecundation, (taA^ax~arato Eano qabuwli Alt~aloqiyHi, lit, held back from receiving fecundation,) so that it had not any effect upon them, and they did not bear fruit that year. (TA.) And yaxonisu Al$~ayoTaAnu A_i*aA samiEa *ikora A@ll~`hi The devil shrinks when he hears the mention of God. (Msb.) And xanasa mino bayoni A^aSoHaAbihi He hid himself from among his companions. (TA.) And xanasa Ean~iY (tropical:) He, or it, [app. the latter,] became hid from me. (A.) And xanasa bihi He went away with him; took him away; so that he was not seen; (ISh, K;) as also bh ↓txn~s: (K:) and he hid him, or it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in four places. ＝ -A3- xanisa AlA^anofN, aor.
xanasa
, (Msb,) inf. n. xanasN, (S, A, Msb, K,) The nose was, or became, [camous, or camoys, i. e.,] depressed in its bone: (Msb:) or depressed in its bone, (A,) or contracted therein, (TA,) and wide in the end: (A, TA:) or retiring from the face, with a slight elevation in the end; (S, K, TA;) xanasN being nearly the same as faTasN: (TA:) or retiring towards the head, and rising from the lip, not being long nor prominent: or its bone lay close upon the elevated part of the cheek, and it was large in the end. (TA.) See also the inf. n. voce A^axonasu. ― -b2- xanisati Alqadamu, inf. n. xanasN, The foot was, or became, flat in the hollow part of the sole, and fleshy. (TA: but only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is there mentioned.)

He made him to go back or backwards; to recede, retreat, retire, or retrograde: or he put him, or placed him, or made him to be, behind, or after: or he made him to remain behind, hold back, hang back, or lag behind: or he kept him back: or he delayed, or retarded, him: syn. A^ax~arahu: (T, A, Msb, K:) as also ↓xanasahu, (Fr, T, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.

, (Msb,) [and app., accord. to the K,
xanusa
also,] inf. n. xanosN; (Msb;) but the former is the more common: (TA:) and (tropical:) hid him, or it: or made him, or it, to hide himself or itself; (A;) or he left behind, (As, S:) and went away from, (S,) him, or it: (As, S:) or both signify he contracted, or drew together, or made to contract or draw together, him [or it]: (Msb:) or the latter verb has this signification as well as that of A^ax~arahu: (Mgh:) [and so has the former also, as will be seen below:] and the former also signifies (tropical:) he hid, or concealed, him, or it; (A;) as also bihi ↓xanasa, as mentioned above. (TA.) You say, A^axonasotu Eanohu baEoDa Haq~ihi I kept back (A^ax~arotu) from him part of his right, or due. (Fr, TA.) And A^axonasuwA AlT~ariyqa (tropical:) They passed beyond the road: (AA, TA:) or left it behind them: (TA:) or passed beyond it and left it behind them. (A.) And A^a$aAra biA^arobaEK waA^axonasa A_ibohaAmahu, (A,) and ↓xanasahaA, (Mgh, Msb, K,) He [made a sign with four fingers and] contracted his thumb. (Mgh, Msb, K.) It is related of Mohammad, that he said, “ The month is thus and thus, ” [twice extending the fingers and thumb of each hand,] and that, the third time, A_iSobaEahu ↓xanasa, i. e., he contracted his finger, [meaning, one of his fingers,] to inform them that the month is nine and twenty [nights with their days]. (TA.)

The devil: (S, K:) an epithet applied to him, (Msb,) because he retires, or shrinks, or hides himself, (yaxonusu, S, Msb, K, i. e., yataA^ax~aru, as is implied in the S, or yanoqabiDu, Msb, or yagiybu, K,) at the mention of God; (S, Msb, K; *) being an intensive act. part. n. from xanasa. (Msb.)

xaAnisN xAns
Going back or backwards; receding; retreating; retiring; or retrograding: or remaining behind; holding back; hanging back; or lagging behind: syn. mutaA^ax~irN: pl. xun~asN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Alxun~asu, (in the Kur lxxxi. 15, S,) (tropical:) The stars; (S, K;) i. e., all of them; because they retire, or hide themselves, (taxonusu,) at setting; or because they become concealed in the day-time: (S:) or the planets: (S, K:) or the five stars, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Venus, and Mercury: (Fr, S, K, Jel:) because they return, (taxonusu, i. c., tarojiEu, Jel,) in their course: (Fr, S, Jel:) when you see a star [thereof] in the end of a sign of the zodiac, it returns to the beginning of it: (Jel:) or because of their retrogression; for they are the erratic stars (AlkawaAkibu AlmutaHay~aripu), which [at one time appear to] retrograde, and [at another time to] pursue a direct [and forward] course: (S:) or because they sometimes return (txns) in their course until they become concealed in the light of the sun: (TA:) or because they hide themselves, as the devil does at the mention of God. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And hence, i. e., from xaAnisN in the sense of mutaA^ax~irN, the saying in a trad. of El- Hajjáj, AlA_ibilu Dim~arN xin~asN, meaning, (assumed tropical:) [Camels are lean, and lank in the belly, and] patient of thirst. (TA.) ― -b4- And All~ayaAliY Alxun~asu The three nights of the lunar month during which the moon retires [from view]. (TA.)

A^axonasu *
[Having a camous, or camoys, nose;] having the configuration termed xanasN in the nose: (S, Msb, K:) [see xanisa AlA^anofu:] accord. to some, having a nose of which the bone is short and the end turning back towards its bone: (TA:) fem. xanosaA='u: (S, Msb:) pl. xunosN. (S, A.) ↓xanasN in its original application is in gazelles and bulls and cows: (TA:) all bulls and cows are xunos, (S, A, TA,) and so are all gazelles: (TA:) or ↓xunusN, with two dammehs, (K,) but written by Sh xunosN, (TA,) is used to signify gazelles: and bulls or cows: (K:) and xanosaA='u is an epithet applied to the wild cow: (K:) also A^axonasu, to the tick: (Sgh, K:) and the lion; and so ↓xin~awosN; (K;) which last is an epithet so applied as relating to his face and his nose: (Fr, TA:) and the last, ↓xn~ws, is also applied to a young pig: (As, TA:) or in this sense it is with S: (Fr, TA:) and ↓xanaAsN is syn, with xin~awosN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xunosN is metaphorically applied [as an
epithet] to arrows, in the following verse, describing a coat of mail:
lahaA EukanN tarud~u Aln~abola xunosFA
watohozaA^u biA@lomaEaAbili waA@loqiTaAEi
[It has folds which repel the arrows turned up at the points, and mock at the broad and long, and the small and broad, arrow-heads]. (TA.) ― -b3- qadamN xanosaA='u A foot flat in the hollow part of the sole, and fleshy. (TA.)

xinoSirN xnSr
(S, Msb, K) and xinoSarN, (A, K,) the latter [of a rare form,] like dirohamN, (TA,) The little finger: (S, A, K:) or the middle finger: (K:) the latter signification said by MF to be unknown; but it is mentioned in the L, as from the Book of Sb: (TA:) [and the little toe:] of the fem. gender: (Msb, K:) pl. xanaASiru: (Sb, S, K:) like firosinN, it has no pl. formed by the addition of At: (Sb:) its pl. is also used as a sing., as though every part were termed xnSr; as in the phrase A_in~ahu laEaZiymu AlxanaASiri [Verily he has a large little finger]. (Lh.) You say, fulaAnN tuvonaY bihi AlxanaASiru [The little fingers are bent in mentioning such a one with others of his class]: i. e., one begins with him in mentioning persons of his class. (Msb.) [See 1 in art. vnY.] And in like manner you say, Ead~uwhu biAlxinoSiri [They counted him with the little finger]: i. e., they commenced with him in counting. (MF.)

1 xanaEa A_ilayohi xnE Alyh xnE Alyp
, and lahu, (ISd,) [aor.
xanaEa
, ] inf. n. xunuwEN (S, ISd, K) and xanoEN; (ISd;) [and app. xaniEa, aor.
xanaEa
, inf. n. xanaEN; (see xanaEN, below; and xaniEN;)] He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, (S, ISd, K,) to him, and petitioned him, or solicited him, he, the latter, not being a fit person to be petitioned, or solicited: (ISd:) or xunuwEN signifies the being low, vile, base, abject, or submissive; almost always in an improper case. (Ham p. 44.) ― -b2- Accord. to Lth, (TA,) xanoEN signifies The act of playing, toying, or dallying, and conversing with one of the other sex, enticing, or striving to induce, the latter to yield to one's desire, and behaving in a soft, tender, or blandishing, manner. (K, TA.) You say, xanaEa Aln~isaA='a, [or more probably, liln~isaA='i,] He played, &c., with women, and behaved in a soft, tender, or blandishing, manner to them. (TK.) ― -b3- xanaEa, aor.
xanaEa
, (Lth, K,) inf. n. xanoEN and xunuwEN, (Lth,) also signifies He acted in a suspicious manner, or so as to induce suspicion or evil opinion; (K;) he acted vitiously, or immorally; or committed adultery, or fornication. (Lth, K.) You say, xanaEa A_ilayohaA He came to her for a vitious, or an immoral, purpose; or for the purpose of adultery, or fornication: (Lth, TA:) or, as some say, he listened to her. (TA.) ― -b4- And xanaEa bihi, aor.
xanaEa
, inf. n. xunuwEN, He acted perfidiously, unfaithfully, or treacherously, to him; or broke his compact, contract, covenant, or the like, with him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- xanaEa fulaAnFA A_ilaY Als~awo'api He, or it, invited such a one to that which was foul, abominable, or evil; as also xaDaEa. (TA in art. xDE.)

[app. inf. n. of xaniEa,] Lowness, vileness, baseness, abjectness, or submissiveness; almost always, in an improper case. (Ham p. 44.)

[app. part. n. of xaniEa,] Low, vile, base, abject, or submissive. (KL.) [See what next precedes.]

A thing that induces suspicion or evil opinion; (S, K;) a vitious, or an immoral, act; or adultery; or fornication. (K.) [See a remark on one of the pls. of xaAniEN.] You say, AiT~alaEato mino fulaAnK EalaY xanoEapK I became acquainted with, or got knowledge of, a vitious, or an immoral, act of such a one. (TA.) And waqaEa fiY xanoEapK He fell into a thing of which one is ashamed. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A vacant place. (O, L, K.) Necessity, or constraint: and excuse. (TA.) ― -b2- rajulN *uw xunuEaAtK A man in whom is corruptness, or vitiousness, or corrupt or vitious conduct. (TA.)

xanuwEN xnwE
Perfidious, unfaithful, or treacherous; one who breaks his compact, contract, covenant, or the like. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- One who turns away from, or shuns, or avoids, another. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

xanaAEapN xnAEh xnAEp
The state of being bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, ugly, or hideous; or excessively bad, &c. (TA.)

One who acts in a suspicious manner, or so as to induce suspicion or evil opinion; who acts vitiously, or immorally; or commits adultery, or fornication: (S, K:) pl. xunuEN (K, TA) and xanaEapN. (TA.) El-Aashà says,
humo AlxaDaArimu A_ino gaAbuwA wa A_ino $ahiduwA

[They are the bountiful, if they be absent and if they be present; and they do not see persons acting in a suspicious manner, &c., towards their wives]. (TA.) [The latter hemistich of this verse is cited in the S; in one copy of which I find yurawona in the place of yarawona: and it seems to be there implied that xunuEN is pl. of xunoEapN; but I do not know any instance of fuEulN as the measure of a pl. of a word of the measure faEolapN.] ― -b2- One who commits a foul action whereof the disgrace returns upon him, and is ashamed of it, and hangs down his head towards the ground. (As, on the authority of an Arab of the desert.)

A^axonaEu AlA^asomaA='i Einoda A@ll~`hi maliku AlA^amolaAki *
, (K,) or A_ilaY A@ll~`hi, (TA,) The vilest and most abasing (A^a*al~u and A^aqoharu) of names, (K,) for a man, and the most effectual to bring into a state of humility and humiliation, in the estimation of God, is “ king of kings; ” like [the Persian] $aAhino$aAho; because this name belongs to God himself: a trad., which is variously related: (TA:) accord. to different relations, thus, and A^anoxaEu, (K,) meaning “ most effectual to kill, and destroy, ” its owner, (TA,) and A^aboxaEu, [which means the same,] (K, TA, [in the CK AanojaEu,]) and A^axonaY, (K,) meaning “ most foul, abominable, or the like. ” (TA in art. xnY.)

muxan~aEN mxnE
applied to a camel, Broke; trained; rendered submissive, or manageable. (K, TA.) And in like manner applied to a place [app. as meaning Rendered easy to sit, or lie, upon; or, to travel]. (TA.)

xunofasN xnfs
and its variations: see what here follows.

xunofasaA='u xnfsA='
(S, Msb, K) [in two copies of the S, in which it is without the article, written without tenween, but in the Msb and K it has the article prefixed, and is therefore necessarily without tenween,] and xunofusaA=', (Msb, TA,) which is more common, (Msb,) [but this I doubt, for I have found it nowhere else,] and ↓xunofasN (S, K) and xunofusN (TA) and xinofisN, (K,) which last is of the dial. of the people of El-Basrah, (TA,) and xunofusapN and xunofusapN, (K,) [The black beetle: or a certain species thereof:] a well-known creeping thing; (Msb;) a certain insect, (S, K,) black, (K,) of fetid odour, smaller than the juEal, found in the bottoms of walls: (TA:) the first and second of these words are both applied to the male and the female: (Msb:) or xunofasN is applied to the male, (AA, Msb,) by some of the Arabs, (Msb,) and is syn. with EunoZabN and HunoZabN, (AA, TA,) and xunofusN is not disallowable, being agree-
able with analogy: (Msb:) and xunofasaA'apN is applied to the female, [which, if correct, shows xnfsA=' to be with tenween,] and so is xunofasapN: (S:) or xnfsA'p, with p, is not allowable; [and if so, xnfsA=' is without tenween;] (As, TA;) and xnfsp is [not applied to the female, but] used by the Benoo-Asad for xnfsA=', as though they made the p a substitute for the A: (Msb:) [and this seems to indicate that the A is a fem. A, grammatically speaking, and that the word is therefore without tenween:] the pl. is xanaAfisu. (Msb.) One says, huwa A^alaH~u mina AlxunofasaA='i [He is more persevering than the black beetle]: because it returns to thee as often as thou throwest it away. (TA.) [Accord. to the K, the n in the words of this art. is radical; but accord. to the S and Msb, augmentative.]

1 xanaqahu xnq xnqh xnqp
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
xanuqa
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. xaniqN (S Mgh, Msb, K) and xanoqN, (Msb, TA,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Msb,) or, accord. to El-Fárábee, the latter is not allowable, (Mgh,) He throttled him, or strangled him, i. e. squeezed his throat (Mgh, Msb) that he might die; (Msb;) [but it does not always mean he squeezed his throat so that he died; often meaning, simply, he, or it, throttled him, strangled him, or choked him; and frequently said of a disease in the throat, and of food;] and ↓xn~qhu signifies the same, (S, K,) [or has an intensive meaning,] and its inf. n. is taxoniyqN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlEaborapu ↓xan~aqatohu [and xanaqatohu] (assumed tropical:) Weeping [or sobbing] choked him; as though the tears throttled him. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And xuniqa He (a horse) was affected with the disease, or wind in the throat, termed xunaAqiy~ap. (TA.) ― -b4- And xanaqa Alwaqota, aor. as above, (assumed tropical:) He postponed, or deferred, and [so] straitened, the time: and xanaqa AlS~alaApa (assumed tropical:) He straitened the time of prayer by postponing it, or deferring it. (TA.)

2 xan~aqa
see 1, in two places. ― -b2- You say also, xn~q Als~araAbu AljibaAla, inf. n. taxoniyqN, (tropical:) The mirage nearly covered the heads of the mountains. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And xn~q AlA_inaA='a (tropical:) He filled the vessel: (K, TA:) or filled it up (sad~ada maloA^ahu): and in like manner, AlHawoDa [the watering-trough]. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.) ― -b4- And xn~q AlA^arobaEiyna (tropical:) He (a man) nearly attained to [the age of] forty [years]. (K, TA.)

see what next follows, in three places.

He was, or became, throttled, or strangled; i. e. he had his throat squeezed that he might die; (JK, * S, * Msb, K; *) [and simply he was, or became, throttled, strangled, or choked;] as also ↓Anxnq: (JK, * Msb:) or you say, ↓Anxnqt Al$~aApu binafosihaA [the sheep, or goat, became throttled, or strangled, or choked, by itself]: (S, K:) or ↓AlAinoxinaAqu signifies the having the xinaAq [q. v.] compressed upon one's throat: and AlAixotinaAqu, the compressing it upon one's own throat. xanoqN xnq
: see muxan~aqN.

xaniqN xnq
inf. n. of xanaqahu: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) ＝ -A2- and i. q. maxonuwqN q. v. (JK, K.)

xunuqN xnq
: see xinaAqN.

xuniAqN xnAq
[Quinsy;] a certain disease which pre vents the passage of the breath to the lungs and heart; (K;) as also [ ↓xunaAqapN thus in modern Arabic, and] ↓xun~aAqN: pl. xawaAniyqu (TA) [and xan~aAniyqu, thus in modern Arabic]. ― -b2- See also muxan~aqN, in three places.

A cord, (JK, S, Mgh, K,) or bow-string, or the like, (Mgh,) with which one is strangled; (JK, * S, * Mgh, K; *) also, metaphorically, termed xan~aAqK ↓mixonaqapu. : see maxonuwqN, in three places.

: see xunaAqN.

A certain disease in the throats of birds and horses: (K:) or a certain disease that attacks the bird in its head, and the horse in its throat, and chokes it: (JK:) or a certain disease, or wind, that attacks men and horses or similar beasts in the throat, and sometimes attacks birds in the head and throat, mostly appearing in pigeons. (TA.)

: see xaAniqN. ― -b2- Also One who sells fish [taken] with the xan~aAqap [q. v.]. (TA.)

: see xunaAqN.

A snare with which beasts of prey are taken (JK, TA) by the throat: and a snare with which fish are taken in El-Andalus. (TA.)

xaAniqN xAnq
One who strangles; (Msb, TA; *) as also ↓xan~aAqN: (Mgh, Msb:) or the latter signifies one whose office it is to strangle. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xaAniqu Al*~iy^obi and xaAniqu Aln~amiri and xaAniqu Alkalobi and xaAniqu Alkirosan~api [in the CK Alkarosan~apu] Four herbs: (K:) [the first and second, in the present day, wolfsbane, or aconite: or, as Golius says, referring for the former and latter respectively to Diosc. iv. 78 and 77, the former is the aconitum lycoctonon; and the latter, the aconitum pardalianches: the third, dogsbane, or colchicum; or, as Golius says, referring to Diosc. iv. 81, apocynon: and the fourth, strangle-weed, (because it strangles the kirosan~ap, or bitter vetch,) or broomrape, i. e., as Golius says, referring to Diosc. ii. 172 and Ibn-Beytár, orobanche:] the first is high (m$rf [but perhaps this should be mu$oriq i. e. shining]) in the leaves, downy, and resembling the dlb [?]: the second is like the tail of the scorpion, glistening, about a span [in height], and has not more than five leaves: each of these is of the [season called] rabiyE; and they are poisonous; they kill all animals; the *iy^ob and the namir being particularized only because of the quickness of its acting in them: Ibn-Seenà says, in the “ Kánoon, ” the leaves of xAnq Alnmr, when mixed with fat, and kneaded and baked with bread, and given as food to wolves and dogs and foxes and leopards (nmr), kills them: whence it seems that this may be two herbs or one herb. (TA.) ― -b3- xaAniqN signifies also (tropical:) A narrow road or ravine, in a mountain: (S, * K, * TA:) or a narrow place or pass, between two mountains, and between two tracts of sand. (JK.) [See also muxotanaqN.] ― -b4- And (tropical:) A narrow street; syn. zuqaAqN; (S, K, TA;) in the dial. of the people of ElYemen. (S, TA.) ― -b5- See also maxonuwqN, in two places.

xaAnaqaAhN xAnq xAnqAh xAnqAp
A convent inhabited by righteous and good men, and Soofees; an arabicized word, from [the Persian] xaAnaho GaAho; [and post-classical, for] El-Makreezee says that the xAnqAh was instituted in the fifth century of the Flight, for Soofee recluses to employ themselves therein in the service of God: (TA:) [pl. xawaAniqu.]

xaAanqaAhiY~N xAnqAhY xAnqAhy
A man of, or belonging to, a xaAnaqaAh. (TA.)

maxonaqN mxnq
: see muxan~aqN, in two places.

mixonaqapN mxnq mxnqh mxnqp
A necklace, syn. qilaAdapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) that surrounds the neck; (Mgh, Msb;) wherefore it is thus called; (Msb;) [i. e., because] it lies against the muxan~aq: pl. maxaAniqu. (TA.) ― -b2- See also xinaAqN. [And see ziraAdN.]

muxan~aqN mxnq
: see maxonuwqN. ― -b2- [Hence,] gulaAmN muxan~aqu AlxaSori (assumed tropical:) A boy slender in the waist. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also The part, of the neck, which is the place of the cord [or the like] called xinaAq [wherewith one is strangled]; (S, K; *) i. e., (TA,) the throat; (K, accord. to the TA; in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K ↓maxonaq;) and so ↓xunaAqN, (S, K, in the former said to be syn. with muxan~aqN,) and ↓xinaAqN (K) and ↓xanoqN. (TA; and so, accord. to the TA, in the K.) You say, A^axa*otu bimuxan~aqihi [I seized his throat]. (S.) And A^axa*ahu bimuxan~aqihi (K, accord. to the TA, but accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K ↓bimaxonaqihi,) and ↓bixunaAqihi and ↓bixinaAqihi, i. e. [He took him, or seized him,] by his throat. (K.) And A^axa*a bimuxan~aqihi (A in art. zrd) and ↓bixunaAqihi (S) [properly He, or it, seized his throat, or throttled him, or choked him; meaning] (tropical:) he, or it, straitened him; as also A^axa*a bimuzar~adihi. (A in art. zrd.) And A^axa*a minohu biAlmuxan~aqi (tropical:) He, or it, constrained him, and straitened him. (TA.) And balaga minohu Almuxan~aqa [properly It reached his throat; meaning (assumed tropical:) it straitened him, or distressed him]. (S.) balaga AlA^amoru Almuxan~aqa signifies the same as balaga Almu*am~ara, (A in art. *mr,) which means (assumed tropical:) The affair, or case, or event, reached a distressing pitch. (K in art. *mr.)

maxonuwqN mxnwq
and ↓xaniqN and ↓xaniyqN (JK, K) and ↓xaAniqN, applied to a man, [and to any animal, as also ↓muxan~aqN, Throttled, or strangled, i. e. having his throat squeezed that he may die; but not always meaning, so as to be killed thereby; often meaning, simply, throttled, strangled, or choked;] (JK;) all signify the same; from xanaqahu: (JK, K:) or ↓xaAniqN, in the place of ↓xaniyqN, signifies *w xnAq [app. meaning having a xinaAq, or cord, &c., by which he is throttled, or strangled, round his neck; or perhaps having a xunaAq, or quinsy]: (TA:) and ↓$aApN xaniyqapN and ↓munoxaniqapN signify a sheep, or goat, throttled, or strangled, i. e. having its throat squeezed that it may die: (Msb:) or the latter of these two means a sheep, or goat, throttled, or strangled, or choked, by itself (Ainoxataqato binafosihaA). (S, TA. [See 8.]) It is said in a prov., (Meyd,) Aifotadi maxonuwqu, (Meyd, K,) i. e. yaA maxonuwqu [Ransom thyself, O thou who art throttled, or strangled, or choked]; applied to any one distressed and constrained; (Meyd;) meaning free thyself from difficulty (K, TA) and harm: (TA:) or, as some relate it, AifotadaY maxonuwqN [One throttled, or strangled, or choked, ransomed himself]. (Meyd.)

muxotanaqN mxtnq
A narrow place or pass. (S, TA.) [See also xaAniqN, near the end of the paragraph.]

muxotaniqN mxtnq
(tropical:) A horse whose blaze occupies his jaws, (K, TA,) extending to the roots of his ears. (TA.)

$aApN munoxaniqapN *
: see maxonuwqN.

1 xanaA xAn xn xnA xnnA
, aor. yaxonuw, inf. n. xanowN and xanFA: see xaniYa, in the art. here following.

1 xaniYa xn xnY xny
(S, K) Ealayohi (S) fiY manoTiqihi (TA,) aor. yaxonaY, inf. n. xanFY; (TA;) as also xanaA, (JK, K,) aor. yaxonuw, (JK, TA,) inf. n. xanowN (K, TA) and xanFA; (JK, TA;) and ↓AxnY (JK, S, K) Ealayohi fiY manoTiqihi, (S, TA,) or fiY kalaAmihi, (JK,) He uttered foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, speech (JK, * S, K) against him. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- xanaY, (JK, K,) [aor. yaxoniY,] inf. n. xanoYN, (TA,) He cut, or severed, the trunk of a palm-tree (JK, K) with an axe; (JK;) as also xanaA^a. (JK, TA.)

4 A^axonaYa
see 1. ― -b2- AxnY Ealayohi also signifies He, (a man, S,) or it, (misfortune, Ham p. 430,) corrupted, or marred, his state. (S, Ham, TA.) And the same, (S,) or AxnY Ealayohimo, (JK, K,) said of time, or fortune, (JK, S,) It destroyed him, or them. (JK, S, K.) And the former, said of time, It became long to him. (K.) ― -b3- AxnY bihi signifies A^asolamahu waxafara *im~atahu [or, app., bi*im~atihi: a phrase which admits of two contr. meanings; He betrayed him, and broke his covenant, or the like; and he preserved him in safety, and fulfilled his covenant, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- AxnY AljaraAdu The locusts had many eggs. (AHn, K.) ― -b5- AxnY AlmaroEaY The pasturage had much and luxuriant herbage. (AHn, K. *)

xanFA xn xnA
[more properly written xanFY, originally an inf. n.,] Foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, speech: (S, TA, and Ham p. 489:) or the most foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, of speech. (JK, T, TA.) And ↓xnAyp [written without any syll. signs, app. xanaAyapN, like faHaA$apN,] is of the measure fEAlp from xanFA [and seems to be syn. therewith as an inf. n. or as a subst.]: it occurs in the saying of El-Katámee,
daEuwA Alt~amora laA tuvonuwA EalayohaA xnAypF
faqado A^aHosanota fiY jul~i maA bayonanaA Alt~amoru
[Leave ye dates: speak not of them in a foul manner, or speak not of them foul speech; for dates have benefited in most of what has occurred between us, or among us]. (TA.) ― -b2- xanaA Ald~ahori The calamities of time or fortune. (JK, K.)

kalaAmN xanK klAm xn
Foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene, speech; and kalimapN xaniyapN a foul, an abominable, an unseemly, or an obscene, word or expression or sentence: (S:) or most foul, &c.: (JK:) [or having a foul, an abominable, an unseemly, or an obscene, meaning; for] xanK is not a verbal epithet, since we know not xaniyati Alkalimapu, but a possessive epithet; like the instance, mentioned by Sb, in rajulN TaEimN, meaning *uw TaEaAmK; and nahirN, meaning [SaAHibu nahaArK or] sayamur~u biAln~ahaAri; &c. (TA.)

xnAyp xnAyh xnAyp
: see xanFA.

AxnY AlA^asomaA='i *
The most foul, or abominable, or unseemly, of names. (TA.) [See A^axonaEu.]

xaw~N xw
Hunger. (IAar, K.) [And so xawFY and xawaA='u, belonging to art. xwy; with which the present art. is intimately connected.] ＝ -A2- A wide valley: (K:) any wide valley in a soft, or plain, [low ground such as is termed] jaw~; (Az, TA;) as also xawFY: (Az, TA in art. xwY:) and low, or depressed, ground; (TA;) as also ↓xuw~apN: (JK, TA:) or the former, a soft place: (JK:) or soft ground; as in the saying, waqaEa garosuka bixaw~F What thou hast planted has chanced to be in soft ground, in which it will take root and not fail to be productive. (TA.)

[
xuw~N xw
, by a mistake in the CK, in art. xwY, is made to signify Honey: see xuwaA='N in that art.]

xw~p xwh xwp
[app. xaw~apN] Languor: occurring in a trad., in which it is said, wa A^axa*a A^abaA jaholK xw~pN falaA yanoTiqu [And a languor seized Aboo-Jahl, so that he spoke not]. (IAth, TA.)

xuw~apN xwh xwp
A vacant land. (K.) ― -b2- See also xaw~N. ＝ -A2- Also a dial. var. of A^uxuw~apN. (IAth, TA in art. Axw: see 1 in that art.)

xaA='N xA='
The name of the letter x, q. v.; as also xaA: [it is called xaA in a case of pause, and xaA='N when made a noun:] it is fem. and masc.: [its dim. is xayay~apN, meaning a x written small, or indistinct: (see HaA='N in art. HwA^:)] and its pl. is A^axowaA='N and A^axoyaA='N and xaAA=tN. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np.)

xaA='i bika EalayonaA xA=' bk ElynA
, (AZ * and S * and TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np, and K and TA in the present art.,) in which xaA='i is a Sawot [or noun significant of a sound], indecl., with kesr for its termination; (S, TA;) and xaAy^iY bk, as in the Book of the Nawádir by Ibn-Háni, (Az, TA,) in which latter, ISd says, the Y is not for a sign of the fem. gender, because the word is a Swt; and, as Sh says, on the authority of A'Obeyd, xaAy^ibika; but correctly written as in the Book of Ibn-Háni; (Az, TA;) Hasten thou [to us]: (AZ, Az, S, K, TA:) it is also used in addressing a female, and two persons, and a pl. number: (S, TA:) you say [xaA='i biki, and] xaAy^iY biki; and xA='i bikumaA, and xaAy^iY bikumaA; and [xaA='i bikumo, and] xaAy^iY bikumo. (TA.) In the saying of El-Kumeyt,
bixaAy^iY bika A@loHaqo yahotifuwna waHaY~a halo
[which app. means Calling out “ Hasten thou, come up with us, ” and “ Come, ” or “ come quickly, ” &c.,] it is held by Ibn-Selemeh to be used as an imprecation, meaning xibota [mayest thou be disappointed of attaining that which thou desirest]; the poet saying bixaAy^ibika for biA^amorika A@l~a*iY xaAba waxasira [meaning By thine affair that shall result in disappointment, and be an occasion of loss]: which, as you see, is at variance with the explanation of AZ. (S, TA.)

xaAy^iY~N *
and xaAwiY~N and xawiY~N [a mistranscription for xayawiY~N, like bayawiY~N and tayawiY~N] rel. ns. of xaA='N and xaA the names of the letter x. (TA in bAb AlAlf All~ynp.)

1 xaAba xAb
, aor. yaxuwbu, inf. n. xawobN, He was, or became, poor, needy, or indigent. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- See also xaAba in art. xyb.

xawobapN xwbh xwbp
A state of utter destitution, in which nothing remains in possession: so in the saying, A^aSaAbatohumo xawobapN [A state of utter destitution befell them]. (A'Obeyd, T.) ― -b2- Hunger: (AA, T, S, A, K:) pl. xawobaAtN. (TA.) So in the phrase, A^aSaAbatohu xawobapN [Hunger befell him]. (AA, S.) Sh knew not this word, and thought it to be a mistake for HawobapN; (T;) which latter signifies “ want. ” (S.) [See the latter word.] ＝ -A2- A tract of land upon which rain has not fallen, between two tracts of land watered by rain. (AA, S, K.) ― -b2- Land that is bad, (S,) in which is no pasture (S, K) nor water. (TA.) So in the saying, nazalonaA bixawobapK mina AlA^aroDi [We alighted in bad land, without pasture or water]. (S.) [See also HuwbapN.]

1 xaAta xAt
, (S, A, K,) aor. yaxuwtu, inf. n. xawotN (S, TA) and xawaAtapN; (TA;) and ↓AxtAt, (S, K,) and ↓AnxAt; (K;) He (a hawk, or falcon, S, K, and an eagle, A, TA) pounced down, or made a stoop, upon the prey, or quarry, (S, A, K,) to take it, or seize it, (S,) making a sound to be heard with his wings. (TA.) And xaAtati AlEuqaAbu, aor. taxuwtu, inf. n. xawaAtN, The eagle made a sound by the motion of its wings [in pouncing down]. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also xAt, (K,) inf. n. xawotN, (TA,) He (for instance an eagle, TA) seized, or snatched away, (K, TA,) a thing; (TA;) and so ↓txw~t, (IAar, K,) and ↓AxtAt. (TA in art. xyt [where this last is said to belong to the present art.].) You say of the hawk, AlT~ayora ↓AxtAt He seized, or snatched away, the birds: (TA in art. xyt:) and of the wolf, Al$~aApa ↓AxtAt (Fr, S, TA) He seized, or snatched away, the sheep or goat; (TA in art. xyt;) or he stole away the sheep or goat by stratagem. (Fr, S, K.) ― -b2- xAt maAlahu He (a man) lessened, or diminished, his property; or took from it by little and little; syn. tanaq~aSahu; (K;) as also maAlahu ↓txw~t, (S, K,) and txw~fhu: (S:) and xaAtahu maAlahu, aor. yaxuwtuhu and yaxiytuhu, [he lessened, or diminished, to him his property; or did so by taking from it by little and little;] both signify the same. (K in art. xyt.) ― -b3- And xAt He (a man, TA) lessened, diminished, or impaired, his provision of corn or food (miyratahu); or made it defective, or deficient. (K.) ＝ -A3- xAt, (aor. as above, Msb,) also signifies He (a man) broke his promise: (IAar, S, Msb, K:) and broke, or dissolved, his compact, contract, or covenant. (K.)

, (K,) inf. n. muxaAwatahu, (TA,) i. q. saAraqahu [i. e. He cast his eye furtively towards a spot between me and him; meaning, towards me: see similar phrases in art. dwn]. (K.)

5 taxaw~ata
see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 8, in two places.

7 A_inoxawata
see 1, first sentence.

8 A_ixotawata
see 1, in four places. ― -b2- One says also, AxtAt baladFA, and ↓txw~thu, He cut off for himself a land, or district. (IAar, TA in art. xwY.) ― -b3- And fulaAnN yaxotaAtu Hadiyva Alqawomi, (S, K, *) and ↓yataxaw~atu, (S,) Such a one takes of the discourse of the people, or party, and learns it by heart [one part after another]. (S, K. *) In [some of] the copies of the K, in the explanation of AxtAt AlHadiyva, for fataHaf~aZahu is erroneously put fataxaT~afahu. (TA.) ― -b4- And A_in~ahumo yaxotaATuwna All~ayoli, meaning yasoruwna wa yaqoTaEuwna AlT~ariyqa [Verily they journey by night, and make the road to be feared, relying upon their strength, and robbing and slaying men]. (S: [in two copies of which I find yasiyruwna in the place of yasoruwna.])

xawaAtN xwAt
The sound made by the motion of the wings of an eagle. (S, K. [In a copy of the S, I find it said that this word is fem., though its meaning is masc.; and the same is said in the TA, doubtless from another copy of the S; but this observation, which is omitted in one copy of the S in my possession, applies to xawaApN, mentioned in art. xwY in the S, as meaning SawotN.]) And A sound [absolutely]; (K;) as also ↓xawaAtahu: (TA:) or the sound, or noise, of thunder, and of a torrent, or flow of water. (AHn, K.) A poet says,
falaAHis~a A_il~aA xawaAtu Als~uyuwli
[And there was no sound but the noise of the torrents]; (AHn, TA;) which shows that we should read in the K waAls~ayoli; not wAlsylu, as in some copies. (TA.)

xawaAtapN xwAth xwAtp
: see the next preceding paragraph.

xaw~aAtN xwAt
A bold, daring, brave, or courageous, man. (S, K.) ― -b2- One who is always eating, but does not eat much. (K.) ＝ -A2- A great promisebreaker. (Msb.)

xaAy^itN *
[act. part. n. of 1]. xaAy^itapN signifies An eagle (EuqaAbN) pouncing down, or making a stoop, (S, K,) and thereby causing a sound to be heard. (S.) ＝ -A2- Breaking his promise; or one who breaks a promise. (Msb.)

xawoxN xwx xwxp
[The peach, or peaches;] a well-known kind of fruit, (K, TA,) which is eaten; (TA;) i. q. duraAqinN: (K in art. drqn:) sing., (K,) or n. un., (S,) ↓xawoxapN. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also what follows.

xawoxapN xwx xwxh xwxp
: see above. ＝ -A2- Also An aperture (S, A, Mgh, K) in a wall, (S, A, Mgh,) admitting the light (S, A, K) to a house, or chamber. (K.) ― -b2- A passage (muxotaraqN) between any two houses, not having a door, or gate: (K:) of the dial. of El-Hijáz; (TA;) [and of Egypt, where it is applied to a lane leading from one street or quarter to another: coll. gen. n. ↓xawoxN:] accord. to some, a passage (muxotaraqN) between any two things: and a small door-way between two houses, or chambers, with a door affixed to it. (L.) ― -b3- A wicket, or small door, (A, Mgh,) in a large door. (A.) [Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, explains it as meaning Fenestella in medio januæ.] ― -b4- [Also applied to A sluice in a rivulet: see daraqapN.] ― -b5- (tropical:) The anus; syn. duburN. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- A kind of green garment: (Az, K:) of the dial. of Mekkeh. (TA.)

2 xw~d xwd
, (L,) inf. n. taxowiydN, (S, L, K,) He (a camel, L) went quickly; or was quick in his pace or going: (S, L, K:) he went quickly, and threw out his legs: or, as some say, he shook, as though he were convulsed: and in like manner, a male ostrich: and sometimes it is said of a man, signifying as first explained above. (L.) ― -b2- xaw~ada raA^oluhu: see art. rA^l. ＝ -A2- He sent the stallion, fiYAlA_ibili among the camels. (L, K.) ＝ -A3- He obtained somewhat of food. (K.)

5 txw~d txwd
He (a camel) shook in going, by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (A.) ― -b2- It (a branch) inclined, (A, TA,) or bent. (K.)

xawodN xwd
, applied to a girl, (S,) or young woman, (L,) or a female, (A, K,) Soft, or tender, (S, A, L, K,) and youthful: (A:) or goodly, or beautiful, in make, and youthful, (L, K,) not yet of middle age: (L:) pl. xawodaAtN (L, K) and xuwdN; (S, L, K;) the latter like ludonN as pl. of ladonN, an epithet applied to a spear. (S, L.)

1 xaAra xAr
, aor. yaxuwru, (S, A, Mgh,) inf. n. xuwaArN (JK, S, A, Mgh, K *) and xaworN, (JK,) He (a bull) uttered his cry; [i. e. lowed, or bellowed;] (Lth, JK, S, A, Mgh, K;) this being its primary signification: (Er-Rághib:) the inf. n. xwAr, used agreeably with this explanation, occurs in the Kur xx. 90 [and vii. 146]: (S:) it signifies the loud crying [i. e. the lowing or bellowing] of a cow and of a calf: (Lth:) and the crying [i. e. bleating] of sheep, or that of goats, and of gazelles, (K,) and of any beast: (Er-Rághib:) and the sounding [i. e. whizzing] of arrows: (K:) of any of these, you say, xaAra, aor. and inf. n. as above. (TA.) [Hence,] lahu SawotN kaxuwaAri Alv~awori He has a voice like the bellowing of the bull. (A.) ― -b2- [And hence, (see 10,)] xAr Ealayohi (tropical:) He bent, turned, or inclined, towards him. (A.) ＝ -A2- xAr, aor. as above, (S, Msb,) inf. n. xuw^uwrN, (S, K, [for which Golius, as on these authorities, substitutes xuw^uwrapN,]) said of a man, (S,) and of anything, (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, weak, or feeble, (S, Msb, K,) and languid; (S, TA;) as also xawira, (TA,) aor. yaxowaru, (JK,) inf. n. xawarN; (S, * K, * TA;) and ↓xiw~ir, (JK, TA,) inf. n. taxowiyrN. (K.) xAr and xawira both signify It was soft, or fragile; said of anything, like a reed. (JK.) It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, lano yaxuwra qawiY~N maA daAma SaAHibuhaA banoziEu wayanozuw, meaning A possessor of strength (SaAHibu quw~apK) will not be weak as long as he can pull his bow and leap to his beast. (TA.) In a camel that is drinking, xawarN denotes, or implies, a quality that is praised; i. e. Patient enduring of thirst and fatigue: and a quality dispraised; i. e. the lacking patience to endure thirst and fatigue. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, said of heat, (S, TA,) and of cold, inf. n. xuw^uwrN and xuw^uwrapN, (JK,) (tropical:) It became faint; it remitted, or abated; (JK, S, TA;) and so xawira, inf. n. xawarN; and ↓xw~r. (TA.) And xAr Ean~aA, said of cold, It ceased from us; quitted us. (A.) ＝ -A3- xaArahu, (JK, S,) inf. n. xaworN, (S, K,) He hit, or hurt, his xaworaAn, (JK, S, K, *) in thrusting or piercing him with a spear or the like. (JK, S.)

2 xw~r xwr
: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- xw~rhu He attributed to him weakness, or feebleness, and languor. (TA.)

, (S, K,) inf. n. A_ixaArapN, (S,) [app., in its' primary acceptation, He caused him to utter a cry. (See 10.) ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) He bent, turned, or inclined, him, or it. (S, K.) You say, A^axaronaA AlmaTaAyaA A_ilaY mawoDiEi ka*aA (assumed tropical:) We bent, or turned, the riding-camels to such a place. (S.)

[Good, moral or physical; anything that is good, real or ideal, and actual or potential; and, being originally an inf. n., used as sing and pl.;] a thing that all desire; such as intelligence, for instance, and equity; (Er-Rághib, and so in some copies of the K;) [or goodness;] and excellence; and what is profitable or useful; benefit; (Er-Rághib;) contr. of $ar~N: (S, A, Msb:) pl. xuyuwrN, (Msb, K,) and also, accord. to the Msb, ↓xiyaArN: (TA:) [but this latter seems to be properly pl. only of xayorN used as an epithet (see below) and as a noun denoting the comparative and superlative degrees: it may however be used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant:] xyr is of two kinds: namely, absolute xyr, which is what is desired in all circumstances and by every person: and what is xyr [or good] to one and $r~ [or evil] to another; as, for instance, (Er-Rághib,) wealth, or property: (Zj, L in art. $d, Er-Rághib, K:) it has this last signification, namely wealth, or property, in the Kur, ii. 176 (S, TA) and ii. 274 and xxiv. 33 and xli. 49: or in the first and second of these instances it is thus called to imply the meaning of wealth, or property, that has been collected in a praiseworthy manner, or it means much wealth or property; and this is its meaning in the first of the instances mentioned above, agreeably with a trad. of 'Alee; and also in the Kur, c. 8: (TA:) [being used as a pl. (as well as a sing.), it may be also rendered good things:] and it is also used by the Arabs to signify horses; (K, * TA;) and has this meaning in the Kur, xxxviii. 31: (TA:) [it is often best rendered good fortune; prosperity; welfare; wellbeing; weal; happiness; or a good state or condition: and sometimes bounty, or beneficence.] rajulN qaliylu Alxayori means [A man possessing little, or no, good; possessing few, or no, good things; or poor: and in whom is little, or no, good or goodness; or niggardly: and also] a man who does little good: (TA in art. ES:) or [who does no good;] who is not near to doing good; denoting the nonexistence of good in him. (Msb in art. ql.) [Thus it sometimes means the same as rajulN laA xayora fiyhi A man in whom is no good or goodness; devoid of goodness; worthless.] And qil~apu xayorK means Poverty: and also niggardliness. (A and TA in art. jHd.) huwa mino A^aholi Alxayori waAlxiyri is explained voce xiyrN. EalaYyadaYi Alxayori waAlyumoni [May it be with the aid of good fortune and prosperity] is a prayer used with respect to a marriage. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) And A_in~aka maA waxayorFA means maEa xayorK, i. e., Mayest thou meet with, or attain, good. (K.) ― -b2- xayorN in the phrase fulaAnN xayorN resembles an epithet [like ↓xay~irN, and signifies Good; or possessing good]; (Akh, S;) therefore the fem. is xayorapN, of which the pl. is xayoraAtN, (Akh, S, Msb, *) as occurring in the Kur, lv. 70; and they do not [there] mean by it [the comparative or superlative signification of the measure] A^afoEalu: (Akh, S:) you say ↓rajulN xay~irN, (S, A, Msb,) meaning [A good man; or] a man possessing xayor [or good]; (Msb;) and rajulN xayorN: (S:) and in like manner, ↓AimoraA^apN xay~irapN and xayorapN, (S, Msb,) meaning [A good woman; or] a woman excellent in beauty and disposition: (Msb:) or xayorN and ↓xay~irN signify possessing much xayor [or good], (K,) applied to a man; (TA;) and in the same sense you say ↓rajulN xayoraY, and ↓xuwraY, and ↓xiyarY: and the fem. of the first is xayorapN; and of the second, ↓xay~irapN: (K:) and the pl. Emr.] ― -b3- xayorN is also used to denote superiority: one says, h`*aA xayorN mino h`*aA This is better than this: and in the dial. of the Benoo-'Ámir, ↓h`*aA A^axoyaru mino h`*aA, with A^, and in like manner, A^a$~aru; but the rest of the Arabs drop the A^ in each case: (Msb:) you say, minoka ↓huwa A^axoyaru [He is better than thou], and in like manner, A^a$~aru minoka; and huwa xayorN minoka, and in like manner, $ar~N minoka; and, [using the dim. form of xayorN,] minoka ↓xuyayorN, and in like manner, $urayorN minoka.
