Locusts before their wings are fullgrown: (Lth, * K, TA:) [see jaraAdN:] or when they have upon them streaks of different colours, white and yellow: (S, K:) or when they have changed from their first black or yellow colour to red: (As, K:) or when yellowness has appeared in their red colour, but some of the redness remains: (AHát, TA:) or [in the CK “ and ”] emaciated red locusts of the brood of the next preceding year: (K:) accord. to Lh, you say jaraAdN xayofaAnN, meaning locusts of different colours: (TA:) [but xyfAn is generally used as a subst.:] the n. un. is with p. (S.) ― -b2- Hence the n. un. is applied to a mare, as meaning (assumed tropical:) Brisk, sprightly, active, or agile, and leaping. (S, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also, app.,] xayofaAnN mina Aln~aAsi (assumed tropical:) A multitude of men. (Ibn-'Abbád, K. *) ＝ -A2- Also A certain plant of the mountains; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) a certain herb growing in the mountain, having no leaves, rising more than a cubit in height, having a sanamap [or head resembling an ear of corn], which is green in the upper part and white below, with a white awn, or beard. (L.)

A^axoyafu *
, applied to a horse, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and a camel, (TA,) and any animal, (S, TA,) Having one of the eyes blue and the other black: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) fem. xayofaA='u. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And, applied to a camel, Wide in the sheath of the penis. (S, K.) ― -b3- And the fem., applied to a she-camel, Wide in the udder, (K,) or in the skin thereof, (S, * K,) or only when it is empty of milk, and flaccid: pl. xayofaAwaAtN; (K;) which is extr., for a pl. like this belongs [regularly] only to a subst., and to an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.) ― -b4- The pl. of A^axoyafu is xiyfN and xuwfN, (K, TA, [the latter erroneously written in the CK xawofN,]) with kesr and damm. (TA.)

maxiyfN mxyf
: see art. xwf.

muxay~afN mxyf
[Diversified in colour]; applied by ElKumeyt to a horse of which one part was of the colour termed warod, and the rest jawon. (L and TA voce haDobN.)

mixoyaAfN mxyAf
A woman who brings forth one year a boy and another year a girl. (JK.)

1 xaAla xAl xAly
is syn. with Zan~a and tawah~ama: (TA:) you say, xaAla Al$~aYo'a, (Msb, K,) first pers. xilotu, (JK, S,) aor. yaxaAlu, (Msb, K,) first pers. A_ixaAlu and A^axaAlu, (JK, S, Msb, K, &c.,) the former irregular, (Msb,) but the more chaste of the two, (S,) and the more used, (Msb,) of the dial. of Teiyi, but commonly used by others also, (El-Marzookee, TA,) the latter of the dial. of Benoo-Asad, accord. to rule, (S, Msb,) but of weak authority, (K,) though some assert it to be the more chaste, (TA,) inf. n. xayolN (S, Msb, K) and xayolapN and xiylN (K) and xiylapN (S, K) and xaAlN and xayalaAnN, (K, TA, [the last accord. to the CK xayalaAlN,]) or, as in the T [and JK], xiylaAnN, (TA,) and xayoluwlapN and maxiylapN (S, K) and maxaAlapN; (K;) and xaAla Al$~aYo'a, aor. yaxiylu, is a dial. var. thereof; (Msb;) meaning Zan~apu [He thought, or opined, the thing: and sometimes (see I' Ak p. 109) he knew the thing: but it seems to have originally signified twh~m Al$Y'a, i. e. he surmised, or fancied, the thing: see xaAlN, below]. (S, Msb, K.) This verb, being of the class of Zan~a, occurs with an inchoative and an enunciative; if commencing the phrase, governing them; but if in the middle or at the end, it may be made to govern or to have no government. (S.) You say, A_ixaAlu zayodFA A^axaAka [and, if you will, zayodN A_ixaAlu A^axuwka and zayodN A^axuwka A_ixaAlu, I think Zeyd is thy brother and Zeyd I think is thy brother and Zeyd is thy brother I think]. (JK.) Hence the prov., mano yasomaEo yaxalo, (S, TA,) i. e. He who hears the things related of men and of their vices, or faults, will think evil of them: meaning that it is most safe to keep aloof from other men: or, accord. to some, it is said on the occasion of verifying an opinion. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 8. ＝ -A3- xAl EalaYAlmaAli, aor. yaxiylu: see xaAla in art. xwl. ＝ -A4- xAl said of a horse, (JK, K, TA,) aor. yaxaAlu, (K,) inf. n. xaAlN, (JK, K,) He limped, or halted, or was slightly lame. (JK, K. *)

2 taxoyiylN txyyl
signifies The imaging a thing in the mind, or fancying it; the forming an image, or a fancied image, thereof in the mind: (TA:) [and ↓taxay~ulN has the same, as well as a quasipass., signification.] You say, [ ↓xay~alotuhu fataxay~ala liY and] liY ↓fataxay~ala ↓taxay~alotuhu [I imaged it in the mind, or fancied it, and it became imaged in the mind to me, or an object of fancy to me]; like as you say, [Saw~arotuhu fataSaw~ara liY and] taSaw~arotuhu fataSaw~ara liY: (S:) for ↓taxay~ulN [as inf. n. of a quasi-pass. verb] signifies a thing's being imaged in the mind, or fancied: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and Al$~aYo'u lahu ↓txy~l means ta$ab~aha. (K. [And the same is indicated in the Msb.]) You say also, xuy~ila lahu ka*aA [Such a thing was imaged to him in the mind; i. e. such a thing seemed to him]; from Alwahomu and AlZ~an~u: (Msb:) and xuy~ila A_ilayohi A^an~ahu ka*aA (S) It was imaged to him [in the mind, i. e. it seemed to him,] that it was so; syn. $ub~iha; (PS;) from Alt~axoyiylu and Alwahomu: (S, TA:) and lahu A^an~ahu ka*aA ↓taxay~ala signifies [in like manner it became imaged &c.; i. e.] ta$ab~aha; as also ↓txAyl: (S:) and so the first of these three verbs is used in the Kur xx. 69. (TA.) And fulaAnN yamoDiY EalaY maA xay~alato, (JK and S in explanation of the phrase fulaAnN yamoDiY ↓EalaYAlmuxay~ali,) i. e. $ab~ahato [Such a one goes on, notwithstanding what (the mind, or the case,) may image to him, or what is fancied by him, of danger of difficulty; Aln~afosu, or AlHaAlu, accord. to Z, (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 94,) being understood]; meaning, notwithstanding peril, or risk; without any certain knowledge. (S.) Whence the prov.,
EalaYmaA xuy~ilato waEovu AlqaSiymi
i. e. I will go on, notwithstanding what the soft tracts abounding in sand in which the feet sink may be imagined to be: [or the right reading is probably xay~alato, i. e. notwithstanding what the soft tracts &c. may image to the mind, of danger or difficulty:] the t in xy~lt relates to the word wEv, which is [regarded as] pl. of waEovapN; and ElY is a connective of a suppressed verb, namely, A^amoDiY, with what follows it: the meaning is, I will assuredly venture upon the affair, notwithstanding its terribleness. (Meyd.) And AifoEalo *`lika EalaY maA xay~alato, i. e. EalaY maA $ab~ahato [Do thou that, notwithstanding what (the mind, or the case, as explained above,) may image to thee, of danger or difficulty]; (JK;) meaning, in any case. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xy~l liln~aAqapi, and ↓A^axoyala, He put a xayaAl [q. v.] near the she-camel's young one, in order that the wolf might be scared away from him, (JK, * S, K, *) and not approach him. (JK, S.) ― -b3- And xy~l fiyhi Alxayora He perceived, or discovered, in him an indication, or external sign, of good; as also ↓txy~lhu (K, TA) and txw~lhu: (TA: [see also 4 in art. xwl:]) or you say, Ealayohi ↓taxay~alato, (T, S, TA,) meaning I knew him; or knew his internal, or real, state; (taxab~arotuhu, T,
TA;) or I chose him; (Aixotarotuhu, S, TA;) and perceived, or discovered, in him an indication, or external sign, of good. (T, S, TA.) ― -b4- And xy~l Ealayohi, (S, Msb, K,) inf.n. taxoyiylN (Msb, K) and ↓taxay~ulN, (K,) [the latter anomalous, being properly inf. n. of taxay~ala,] He conveyed doubt, or suspicion, (Alt~uhomapa, S, K, or Alwahoma, Msb,) to him; so in the M, on the authority of AZ; (TA;) i. q. lab~asa Ealayohi [he made (a thing, or case) dubious to him]. (Msb.) ― -b5- And xy~lt EalayonaA Als~amaA='u The sky thundered and lightened [over us], and prepared to rain: but when the rain has fallen, the term ↓taxay~ulN [so in my two copies of the S, app. used as an inf. n. of the verb in this phrase, as in a case above, or perhaps a mistranscription for taxoyiylN, though it will be seen from what follows that xy~lt and txy~lt are both said of the sky in the same sense,] is not used: (S:) or xy~lt Als~amaA='u signifies the sky became clouded, but did not rain; (JK, and Har p. 36;) as also ↓AxAlt and ↓txy~lt and ↓xAylt: (Har ibid.:) or, as also ↓txy~lt (Msb, K) and ↓AxAlt, (Msb,) or ↓A^axoyalat, (K,) the sky prepared to rain, (Msb, K, TA,) and thundered and lightened, but did not yet rain: (TA:) or, accord. to Az, ↓AxAlt Als~amaA='u signifies the sky became clouded: (Msb, TA:) and Als~amaA='u ↓txy~lt the sky became clouded, and prepared to rain. (S.) [In like manner,] one says also, Als~aHaAbu ↓AxAlt and ↓A^axoyalat and ↓xAylt The clouds gave hope of rain: (S:) or Als~aHaAbapu ↓AxAlt the cloud showed signs of rain, so that it was thought [or expected] to rain. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- xy~l also signifies, (JK, TA,) or ↓txy~l, (Ham p. 39,) [or each of these,] He (a man) was cowardly, or weak-hearted, on the occasion of fight, (JK, TA, and Ham,) and did not act, or proceed, firmly, or steadily. (Ham.) And xy~l Eani Alqawomi and ↓A^axoyala, [but the former only is explained in this sense in the TA,] He held back from the people, or party, through cowardice: (K, TA:) so says Az, on the authority of' Arrám. (TA.)

3 xAylhu xAylh xAylp
, (JK, TA,) inf. n. muxaAyalapN, (S, K,) He vied with him, rivalled him, or imitated him, (JK, S, * K, * TA,) in pride and self-conceit; (JK;) did as he did. (TA.) ― -b2- xAylt Als~amaA='u, and Als~aHaAbu: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph.

4 AxAl A^xAl AxAl xAl
It (a thing) was, or became, dubious, or confused, or vague, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) Ealayohi to him. (JK, Mgh.) One says, h`*aA A^amorN laA yuxiylu [This is a thing, or an affair, or a case, that will not be dubious, &c.]. (S.) And laA yuxiylu *aAka EalaY A^aHadK That will not be dubious, &c., to any one. (JK.) ― -b2- AxAl Al$~aYo'u A_ilaY Alxayori, and Almakoruwhi, The thing exhibited an indication, or indications, of good, and of evil, or what was disliked or hated. (Msb.) [Hence,] AxAlt Als~amaA='u, and A^axoyalat: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph, in four places. And AxAlt Als~aHaAbu and A^axoyalat, or AxAlt Als~aHaAbapu: see, again, 2, in the latter part of the paragraph, in three places. ― -b3- And hence, in the opinion of ISd, the she-camel in this case being likened to clouds [giving hope, or showing signs, of rain], (TA,) AxAlt Aln~aAqapu (tropical:) The she-camel had milk in her udder, (JK, K, TA,) and was in good condition of body. (JK, TA.) ― -b4- AxAlt AlA^aroDu biAln~abaAti, (K,) or, as in the M, ↓AxtAlt, (TA,) (tropical:) The land became adorned, or embellished, with plants, or herbage. (K, TA. [See also 5.]) ＝ -A2- AxAl fiyhi xaAlFA mina Alxayori: see 4 in art. xwl; and see xaAlN, below. ― -b2- A^axoyalonaA and A^axalonaA We watched, or observed, or looked at, a cloud which it was thought would rain, to see where it would rain. (K, * TA.) And A^axalotu Als~aHaAbapu and A^axoyalotuhaA I saw the cloud to be such as gave hope of rain. (S. [See also 10.]) ＝ -A3- A^axoyala liln~aAqapi: see 2, in the middle of the paragraph. ＝ -A4- A^axoyala Eani Alqawomi: see 2, last sentence.

5 txy~l A^xAl txyl xyl
, as a trans. v., syn. with xay~ala; and its inf. n., syn. with taxoyiylN: see 2, first two sentences, in two places. ― -b2- txy~l fiyhi Alxayori, as syn. with xay~ala: and taxay~alotu Ealayohi: see 2, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also, as a quasipass. v., similar in signification to xuy~ila; and its inf. n.: see 2, first three sentences, in five places. ― -b2- And taxy~ulN used as an inf. n. of xay~ala Ealayohi: and app. as an inf. n. of xay~alato EalayonaA Als~amaA='u: see 2, latter half, in two places. ― -b3- txy~lt Als~amaA='u: see 2, latter half, in three places. ― -b4- txy~l as syn. with AxtAl: see the latter verb. ― -b5- [Hence, app.,] txy~lt AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The land became abundant in its plants, or herbage: (JK:) [and, (as is shown by an explanation of the part. n. of the verb, below,) (assumed tropical:) the land had its plants, or herbage, in a state of full maturity, and in blossom; and so ↓txAylt; whence,] a poet says,
taA^az~ara fiyhi Aln~ayotu Hat~aY taxaAyalato
rubaAhu waHat~aY maA turaY Al$~aA='u nuw~amaA
[The herbage in it became, or had become, tangled, or luxuriant, and strong, so that its hills were clad with plants in full maturity, and in blossom, and so that the sheep, or goats, were seen sleeping]. (S, TA. [In both, the meaning of the verb in this ex. is indicated by the context. See also 4, where a similar meaning is assigned to AxAlt or AxtAlt.]) ― -b6- taxay~ulN also signifies The being, or becoming, of various colours. (JK, Ham p. 39. *) [Hence the saying,] taxay~ala Algaroqu biAls~afori, i. e. [The desert, or far-extending desert] became of various colours with the travellers, by reason of the A=l [or mirage]. (JK.) ― -b7- Also The going on, or away; or acting with a penetrative energy; and being quick. (JK, Ham p. 39.) ― -b8- See also 2, last sentence but one.

6 taxaAoyala
see 2, third sentence: ― -b2- and 8, in two places: ― -b3- and see also 5, in two places.

8 AxtAl A^xtAl AxtAl {xtAl
He was proud, or haughty; or he behaved proudly, or haughtily; (S;) as also ↓xaAla, (JK, S,) aor. yaxiylu, (JK,) or yaxaAlu, (Ham p. 122,) and yaxuwlu, (JK, Ham,) inf. n. xaAlN and xawolN; (Ham;) and ↓txy~l and ↓txAyl: (K, TA:) or he was proud, or haughty, and selfconceited: (Msb:) and he walked with a proud, or haughty, and self-conceited, gait: (MA, KL:) said of a man, and of a horse: (Msb:) and ↓taxaAyulN signifies the behaving, or carrying oneself, with pride, or haughtiness, combined with slowness. (JK.) You say of a horse, yaxotaAlu fiY mi$oyatihi [He is proud and self-conceited in his gait]. (TA.) ― -b2- AxtAlt AlA^aroDu: see 4.

10 AstxAl Als~aHaAbapa AstxAl AlsHAbh AstxAl AlsHAbp
He looked at the cloud and thought it to be raining. (TA. [See also 4, last sentence but two.])

xaAlN xAl xAly
i. q. Zan~N and tawah~umN [meaning Thought, or opinion: and surmise, or fancy: though tawah~umN is often explained as syn. with Zan~N]: (K:) an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (TA.) So in the saying, A^aSaAba fihi xaAliY [My thought or opinion, or surmise or fancy, was right respecting him, or it]. (TK.) ― -b2- I. q. ― -b3- maxiylapN, q. v., (K,) [accord. to the TA, which is followed in this instance, as usual, by the author of the TK, as meaning firaAsapN: but this is a mistake: for whY AlfrAsp, the explanation in the TA, we should read wahiYa mina AlfiraAsapi; as is shown by its being there immediately added that one says, fiyhi xaAlFA ↓A^xaAla, explained in art. xwl; (see 4, and xaAlN, in that art.; and see also maxiylapN in the present art.;) and by what here follows:] AlxaAlN is syn. with AlmaxiylapN and Al$~iyapu. (JK.) ― -b4- For another sense in which it is syn. with maxiylapN see the latter word, below. ― -b5- A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; syn. xuluqN. (TA.) ― -b6- I. q. xuyalaA='u, q. v. (S, K *) ＝ -A2- A limping, or halting, or slight lameness, in a horse or similar beast: in this sense an inf. n. of xaAla. (JK, K. *) ― -b2- Gout; or gout in the foot or feet; syn. niqorisN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Lightning: (K:) [app. as being a sign, or token, of coming rain.] ― -b2- Clouds; syn. gayomN: (S:) or clouds (gym) lightening: (JK, M, TA:) and also rising, and seeming to one to be raining; and the single cloud (saHaAbap) is termed ↓muxiylapN: (JK:) or rising, and seeming to one to be raining, and then passing beyond one; but when having thunder, or lightning, therein, termed ↓muxiylapN, though not when the rain has gone therefrom: (Har p. 36, from the 'Eyn:) or clouds (saHaAbN) raining: (T, TA:) or clouds (sHAb) that fail not to fulfil their promise of rain; (K, * TA;) and a cloud of this description is termed ↓maxiylapN: (JK:) or in which is no rain, (K, TA,) though thought, when seen, to be raining. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A liberal, bountiful, or generous, man: (JK, T, M, K:) as being likened to the raining clouds, (T, TA,) or to the lightening clouds, (JK, M, TA,) which are so termed. (JK, T, M, TA.) ― -b4- A man in whom one sees an indication, or a sign, or token, of goodness. (K, TA.) ― -b5- Free from Alt~uhomap [as meaning what occasions suspicion]. (K.) ― -b6- A man who manages cattle, or camels &c., (K, TA,) and pastures them, (TA,) well: (K, TA:) or xaAlu maAlK
one who manages cattle, &c., and watches them, well. (JK.) And One who keeps to a thing, (K, TA,) and manages, orders, or regulates, it. (TA.) A king who manages, orders, or regulates, the affairs of his subjects. (JK.) [See also xaAlN in art. xwl.] ― -b7- An owner of a thing: (K:) from xaAlahu, aor. yaxuwlu, meaning “ he managed it, ” &c. (TA.) You say, mano xaAlu h`*aA Alfarasi Who is the owner of this horse? (TA.) [See xaAlN in art. xwl.] ― -b8- See also muxotaAlN, in three places. ― -b9- A man free from an attachment of love. (K.) ― -b10- A man having no wife. (K.) ― -b11- A man weak in heart and body: (K:) but this is most probably [xaAl~N,] with teshdeed, from xal~a laHomuhu, meaning “ he became lean. ” (TA.) ＝ -A4- As meaning A maternal uncle, it is mentioned in art. xwl. (TA.) ＝ -A5- A mole, syn. $aAmapN, (K,) a black $Amp, (TA,) upon the person; (S, K, Msb, TA;) [a thing resembling] a pimple in the face, inclining to blackness; (JK, T, Mgh, TA;) or a small black spot upon the person: (TA:) dim. ↓xuyayolN (JK, S) accord. to him who says maxiylN and maxoyuwlN [as meaning “ marked with many moles upon the person ”], (S,) and xuwayolN (JK, S, Msb) accord. to him who says maxuwlN, (S,) which shows it to be, in one dial., of the art. xwl [in which it is also mentioned]: (Msb:) pl. [of mult.] xiylaAnN (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] A^axiylapN. (Msb.) ＝ -A6- A garment, or cloth, of the garments, or cloths, of the juh~aAl [here meaning people of the Time of Ignorance]: (S:) a soft garment or cloth (JK, K, TA) of the garments or cloths of El-Yemen: (JK, TA:) and a [garment of the kind called] burod, of the fabric of El-Yemen, (K, TA,) red [or brown], with black lines or stripes, which used to be made in the first ages: but Az makes these two to be one: it has been mentioned before, in art. xwl, to which also it may belong. (TA.) ― -b2- A garment, or piece of cloth, with which a corpse is shrouded. (K.) ― -b3- The [kind of banner called] liwaA=' (JK, T, K) that is tied [to its spear-shaft] for a commander, (K,) or to denote one's having the authority of a prefect, commander, ruler, or the like: (T, TA:) [SM adds,] I do not think it to be so called for any other reason than that it was of the buruwd of the kind termed xaAlN. (TA.) [See also xaAlN in art. xwl.] ― -b4- The office of Khaleefeh; (K;) because belonging to one for whom a banner is tied [on the occasion of his appointment]. (TA.) ＝ -A7- A big mountain. (K.) ― -b2- And (as being likened thereto, TA) (assumed tropical:) A big camel: (JK, K:) pl. xiylaAnN: to such, a poet likens certain men, as resembling camels in their bodies and in their being devoid of intellect. (TA.) ― -b3- And A black stallion-camel. (IAar, K, * TA.) Mentioned also in art. xwl. (TA.) ＝ -A8- A place in which is no one, or no one by whose company one may be cheered. (K.) [Probably from xaAlK, part. n. of xalaA, aor. yaxoluw.] ― -b2- A small [hill such as is termed] A^akamap. (K.) ＝ -A9- The lijaAm [i. e. bit, or bit with its appertenances,] of a horse: (K:) app. a dial. var. of xawalN, q. v. (TA.) ＝ -A10- A certain plant, having a blossom, well known in Nejd. (K.)

xaAlK xAl xAly
, formed by transposition from xaAy^ilN: see muxotaAlN.

xayolN A^xyl xyl
Horses, (JK, S, K,) collectively; (JK, K;) as some say, (Msb,) applied to Arabian horses and [such as are of inferior breed, termed] baraA*iyn; (Mgh, Msb;) the males thereof and the females: (Mgh, TA: *) but of the fem. gender: (Msb, TA:) a quasi-pl. n., (Mgh,) having no sing. (Msb, K) formed of the same radical letters: (Msb:) or the sing. is ↓xaAy^ilN: (K:) so called because of their AixotiyaAl, (Msb, K, * TA, *) i. e. pride and self-conceit, (Msb,) in their gait: so says AO; but ISd says that this is not well known: (TA:) or because no one rides a horse without experiencing a feeling of pride: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl., (Msb, CK,) or pl. pl., (so in copies of the K and in the TA,) [of mult.,] xuyuwlN (S, * Msb, K) and xiyuwlN and [pl. of pauc.] A^axoyaAlN. (K.) And the dual form is used, [although xayolN has a pl. signification,] like as are [the duals A_ibilaAni and ganamaAni and] liqaAHaAni and jimaAlaAni. (ISd, TA.) One says, fulaAnN laAtusaAyaru xayolaAhu, or laAtuwaAqafu, (K, TA,) and laAtusaAyaru xayolaAhu walaA tuwaAqafu, (TA, and so in the CK,) [Such a one, his two troops of horses will not be competed with in going, or running, nor in standing still,] meaning (tropical:) he is not to be endured in respect of calumny and lying: (K, TA:) it is said of a great, or frequent, liar. (TA in art. syr.) And Alxayolu A^aEolamu mino furosaAnihaA [The horses are more knowing than their riders]; (Meyd, K;) a prov., (Meyd,) applied in relation to him of whom thou formest an opinion (Meyd, K, TA) that he possesses, or possesses not, what suffices, (TA,) and whom thou findest to be as thou thoughtest, (Meyd, K, TA,) or the contrary. (Meyd.) And Alxayolu A^aEolamu bafurosaAnihaA [The horses are possessed of most knowledge of their riders]; a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) seek thou aid of him who knows the case, or affair. (Meyd.) And Alxayolu tajoriY EalaY masaAwiyhaA, another prov. [explained in art. swA^]. (Meyd.) ― -b2- Also Horsemen, or riders on horses. (S, Msb, K.) Thus in the Kur [xvii. 66], waA^ajolibo Ealayohimo bixayolika wa rajolika. (S. [See 1 in art. jlb.]) ＝ -A2- See also xuyalaA='u.

xayalN A^xyl xyl

primarily signifies An incorporeal form or image; such as that which is imaged in sleep, and in the mirror, and in the heart or mind: then applied to the form of anything imaged; and to any subtile thing of a similar kind: (Er-Rághib, TA:) anything that one sees like a shadow: and the image of a man in a mirror, (T, Msb, TA,) and in water, (Msb,) and in sleep: (T, TA:) and a thing that sometimes passes by one, resembling a shadow: (T, Msb, TA:) xayaAlN and ↓xayaAlapN both signify the same; (JK, S, K;) i. e. i. q. TayofN [meaning an apparition; a phantom; a spectre; a fancied image; an imaginary form; and particularly a form that is seen in sleep]; (S, TA;) anything that one sees like a shadow [as the former word is explained above]; and a thing that is seen in sleep; (JK;) a form that is imaged to one in the mind when awake, and when dreaming: (K:) the former word is both masc. and fem.: (Ham p. 316:) pl. A^axiylapN (K) [a pl. of pauc.; and probably xiylaAnN also, as a pl. of mult., mentioned as one of the pls. of xayaAlN in another sense, below]. You say, taxay~ala liY xayaAluhu [His apparition, or phantom, &c., became imaged to me in my mind]. (Msb, TA.) And a poet says, (S,) namely, El-Bohturee, (TA,)
falasotu binaAzilK A_il~aA A^alam~ato
Alka*uwbu ↓biraHoliY A^awo xayaAlatuhaA
[And I do not alight but she visits my abode, or her false apparition]. (S.) ― -b2- [In philosophy it signifies] A faculty that retains what the fancy perceives of the forms of objects of sense after the substance has become absent, so that the fancy beholds them whenever it turns towards them: thus it is the store-house of the fancy: its place is the hinder part of the first venter of [the three which are comprised by] the brain. (KT. [In this sense, it is incorrectly written in Freytag's Lex. (in which only the Arabic words of the explanation are given, preceded by the rendering “ phantasia, ”) xiyAlN.]) ― -b3- The xayaAl of a bird is The shadow of himself which a bird sees when rising into the sky; whereupon he pounces down upon it, thinking it to be a prey, and finds it to be nothing: he is [the bird] called xaATifu Zil~ihi. (TA.) ― -b4- xayaAlN and ↓xayaAlapN signify also The person, or body, or corporeal form or figure which one sees from a distance, syn. $axoSN, (S, K,) of a man; and his aspect. (K.) ― -b5- And the former also signifies A piece of wood with black garments upon it, (S,) or with a black [garment of the kind called] kisaA=' upon it, (K,) which is set up to make the beasts and birds fancy it to be a man: (S, K:) or a piece of wood with a garment thrown upon it, which is set up for the sake of the sheep or goats, in order that the wolf, seeing it, may think it to be a man: (T, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^axiylapN (Ks, TA) and [of mult.] xiylaAnN. (TA.) A poet says,
A^axiY laA A^axaA liY gayoruhu gayora A^an~aniY
karaAEiY xayaAlK yasotaTiyfu bilaAfikori
(S, TA) [cited by J as an ex. of xyAl in the former of the senses explained in the sentence immediately preceding: but the meaning seems to be, My brother: I have no brother but he: but I am like one watching an image dressed up to decoy; going round about without reflection: for,] as some say, (TA,) raAEiY AlxayaAli means the young ostrich for which the sportsman sets up a xayaAl [i. e. an image dressed up to decoy], (JK, TA,) in order that it may become familiar therewith, and the sportsman may then take it, and the young ostrich may follow him.
